data.title: EQUIPMENT - ADJUSTMENT TO CLOTHING OR EQUIPMENT

paragraphs.context: Play shall not be stopped, nor the game delayed by reasons of adjustments to clothing, equipment, skates or sticks. The responsibility of maintaining clothing and equipment in proper condition shall be upon the Player. If adjustments are required, the Player shall leave the ice and play shall continue with a substitute. No delay shall be permitted for the repair or adjustment of Goalkeeper’s equipment. If adjustments are required, the Goalkeeper shall leave the ice and their place shall be taken by the substitute Goalkeeper immediately.

qas.question: What is the responsibility of a player regarding adjustments to their clothing or equipment during a game?

answers.text: Players are responsible for making adjustments to their clothing or equipment off the ice without delaying the game. Goalkeepers must also leave the ice for adjustments, with a substitute immediately taking their place.

qas.question: How should adjustments to a player's clothing or equipment be handled without causing a delay in the game?

answers.text: Adjustments to a player's clothing or equipment should be handled by having the player leave the ice, and play continues with a substitute to avoid delays in the game. Goalkeepers must also leave the ice for adjustments, with a substitute goalkeeper taking their place immediately.

qas.question: What action should a player take if they need to make adjustments to their skates during gameplay?

answers.text: If a player needs to make adjustments to their skates during gameplay, they should leave the ice, and play should continue with a substitute.

qas.question: In the case of a goalkeeper needing equipment adjustments, what is the procedure to ensure the game continues without delay?

answers.text: If a goalkeeper needs equipment adjustments during a hockey game, they must leave the ice immediately, and a substitute goalkeeper will take their place without delaying the game.

qas.question: How should a team handle a situation where a player needs to make adjustments to their stick during play?

answers.text: In hockey, if a player needs to make adjustments to their stick during play, they must leave the ice, and play continues with a substitute.

data.title: TYPES OF PENALTIES - CALLING OF PENALTIES

paragraphs.context: Should an infraction of the rules which would call for a Minor, Bench Minor, Major, Misconduct or Game Misconduct, be committed by a Player or Team Personnel of the side in control of the puck, the Referee shall immediately blow their whistle and penalize the offending Player or Team. Should an infraction of the rules which would call for a Minor, Bench Minor, Major, Misconduct or Game Misconduct be committed by Player or Team Personnel of the Team not in control of the puck, the Referee shall raise their arm to signal the delayed calling of a penalty. When the Team to be penalized gains control of the puck, the Referees will blow their whistle to stop play and impose the penalty on the offending Player or Team. When a Player, Team Manager, Coach or team personnel is ejected from the game for a violation of the playing rules, that individual must vacate the Players’ Bench area and may not, in any manner, further participate in the game. This includes directing the Team from the spectator area or by radio communications. Any violations shall be reported to the Proper Authorities.

qas.question: What action does the referee take if a player from the team in control of the puck commits an infraction that warrants a penalty?

answers.text: If a player from the team in control of the puck commits an infraction warranting a penalty, the referee will immediately blow the whistle and penalize the offending player or team.

qas.question: How does the referee signal a delayed penalty when an infraction is committed by a player from the team not in control of the puck?

answers.text: The referee signals a delayed penalty by raising their arm when an infraction is committed by a player from the team not in control of the puck.

qas.question: What happens when the team to be penalized gains control of the puck after a delayed penalty is signaled by the referee?

answers.text: When the team to be penalized gains control of the puck after a delayed penalty is signaled by the referee, play is stopped, and the penalty is imposed on the offending player or team.

qas.question: When a player is ejected from the game for a rule violation, what are they required to do in terms of their participation in the game?

answers.text: When a player is ejected from the game for a rule violation, they must leave the Players' Bench area and cannot participate in any way, including giving directions from the spectator area or through radio communications.

qas.question: How should any violations of the rules resulting in ejection of a player or team personnel be handled according to the context provided?

answers.text: Any violations of the rules resulting in ejection of a player or team personnel must be handled by immediately removing them from the game and prohibiting further participation in any capacity.

paragraphs.context: If the penalty to be imposed is a Minor Penalty and a goal is scored on the play by the non-offending side, the Minor Penalty shall not be imposed but Major Penalties shall be imposed in the normal manner regardless of whether or not a goal is scored. If two (2) or more Minor Penalties were to be imposed and a goal is scored on the play by the non-offending side, the Captain of the offending Team shall designate to the Referee which Minor Penalty(ies) will be assessed and which Minor Penalty will be washed out as a result of the scoring of the goal.

qas.question: What happens if a Minor Penalty is to be imposed and a goal is scored by the non-offending team on the play?

answers.text: If a Minor Penalty is to be imposed and a goal is scored by the non-offending team on the play, the Minor Penalty will not be imposed. However, Major Penalties will be imposed as usual. If multiple Minor Penalties were to be imposed and a goal is scored by the non-offending team, the Captain of the offending team must choose which Minor Penalty will be assessed, and one Minor Penalty will be canceled due to the goal.

qas.question: How are Major Penalties handled if a Minor Penalty is nullified due to a goal being scored by the non-offending team?

answers.text: If a Minor Penalty is nullified due to a goal being scored by the non-offending team, Major Penalties will still be imposed in the normal manner regardless of the goal.

qas.question: In the case of multiple Minor Penalties being called and a goal being scored by the non-offending team, who is responsible for designating which penalty will be assessed and which one will be washed out?

answers.text: The Captain of the offending team is responsible for designating which Minor Penalty will be assessed and which one will be washed out if multiple Minor Penalties are called and a goal is scored by the non-offending team.

qas.question: Does the scoring of a goal by the non-offending team impact the imposition of Minor Penalties in a hockey game?

answers.text: Yes, if a goal is scored by the non-offending team during a play where a Minor Penalty was to be imposed, the Minor Penalty will not be imposed.

qas.question: How does the rule regarding goals scored by the non-offending team affect the calling of penalties in a hockey match?

answers.text: When a goal is scored by the non-offending team during a Minor Penalty situation, the Minor Penalty is not imposed. However, Major Penalties are still enforced as usual. If multiple Minor Penalties are to be imposed and a goal is scored by the non-offending team, the Captain of the offending team designates which Minor Penalty will be assessed and which will be canceled due to the goal.

paragraphs.context: When the penalty to be imposed is applicable under Rule 47 for “Head-butting”, Rule 58 “Butt-ending”, Rule 60 “High-sticking” or Rule 62 “Spearing”, and a goal is scored, two (2) minutes of the appropriate penalty will be assessed to the offending Player. This will be announced as a Double-minor Penalty for the appropriate infraction and the Player will serve two (2) minutes only.

qas.question: What happens if a player commits a head-butting penalty and a goal is scored during the same play?

answers.text: If a player commits a head-butting penalty and a goal is scored during the same play, the player will receive a two-minute double-minor penalty for head-butting, and they will serve two minutes only.

qas.question: How long does a player serve for a double-minor penalty for high-sticking if a goal is scored during the penalty?

answers.text: If a goal is scored during a double-minor penalty for high-sticking, the player will serve two minutes only.

qas.question: Which specific penalties result in a double-minor penalty being assessed if a goal is scored during the penalty?

answers.text: Penalties for "Head-butting," "Butt-ending," "High-sticking," or "Spearing" result in a double-minor penalty if a goal is scored during the penalty.

qas.question: How is a double-minor penalty announced when a goal is scored during the penalty for butt-ending?

answers.text: A double-minor penalty for butt-ending is announced as a two-minute penalty when a goal is scored during the penalty.

qas.question: In the case of a spearing penalty and a goal being scored, how many minutes of penalty time does the offending player serve?

answers.text: The offending player serves two minutes of penalty time for a spearing penalty if a goal is scored.

paragraphs.context: When a Team is “short-handed” by reason of one or more Minor or Bench Minor Penalties, and the Referee signals a further Minor Penalty or penalties against the “short-handed” Team and a goal is scored by the non-offending side before the whistle is blown, then the goal shall be allowed. The penalty or penalties signaled shall be assessed and the first of the Minor Penalties already being served shall automatically terminate under Rule 16 – Minor Penalties. Major Penalties shall be imposed in the normal manner regardless of whether or not a goal is scored. Should a Minor or Bench Minor Penalty be signaled against a Team already “short-handed” by reason of a Major Penalty, but before the play can be stopped to assess the Minor or Bench Minor Penalty, and a goal is scored by the non-offending side, the signaled Minor or Bench Minor Penalty shall not be imposed due to the scoring of the goal. Should a penalty be signaled against a Team already “short-handed” by reason of one or more Minor or Bench Minor Penalties, and the signaled penalty would result in the awarding of a “Penalty Shot”, but before the Referee can stop play to award the “Penalty Shot”, the non-offending Team scores a goal, then the signaled penalty (that would have resulted in a “Penalty Shot”) shall be assessed as a Minor (Double-minor or Major) Penalty and the first of the Minor Penalties already being served shall automatically terminate: (Rule 16 – Minor Penalties)

qas.question: What happens if a team is short-handed due to Minor or Bench Minor Penalties, and the Referee signals a further Minor Penalty against them, but a goal is scored by the non-offending side before the whistle is blown?

answers.text: If a team is short-handed due to Minor or Bench Minor Penalties and the Referee signals a further Minor Penalty against them, but a goal is scored by the non-offending side before the whistle is blown, the goal shall be allowed. The penalty signaled will be assessed, and the first Minor Penalty being served will automatically end.

qas.question: How are Major Penalties handled when a team is short-handed and a goal is scored by the non-offending side before the play is stopped?

answers.text: If a team is short-handed and a goal is scored by the non-offending side before play is stopped, the goal shall be allowed. The penalty signaled will be assessed, and the first of the Minor Penalties being served will end. Major Penalties are imposed as usual, regardless of a goal being scored.

qas.question: If a team is already short-handed due to a Major Penalty and a Minor or Bench Minor Penalty is signaled against them, but a goal is scored by the non-offending side before the play is stopped, what is the outcome?

answers.text: If a team is already short-handed due to a Major Penalty and a Minor or Bench Minor Penalty is signaled against them, but a goal is scored by the non-offending side before the play is stopped, the goal shall be allowed, and the signaled Minor or Bench Minor Penalty shall not be imposed.

qas.question: What occurs if a penalty is signaled against a team already short-handed by Minor or Bench Minor Penalties, and the signaled penalty would result in a "Penalty Shot," but a goal is scored by the non-offending team before play is stopped for the penalty shot?

answers.text: If a penalty is signaled against a team already short-handed by Minor or Bench Minor Penalties, and the signaled penalty would result in a "Penalty Shot," but a goal is scored by the non-offending team before play is stopped for the penalty shot, the signaled penalty that would have resulted in a "Penalty Shot" shall be assessed as a Minor (Double-minor or Major) Penalty.

qas.question: In what situation would a signaled penalty that would have resulted in a "Penalty Shot" be assessed as a Minor (Double-minor or Major) Penalty instead, and what happens to the first of the Minor Penalties already being served in this case?

answers.text: If a penalty signaled for a "Penalty Shot" is nullified due to a goal being scored by the non-offending team before the shot is taken, it will be assessed as a Minor (Double-minor or Major) Penalty instead. The first of the Minor Penalties already being served will automatically terminate in this case.

paragraphs.context: When Players are penalized at a stoppage of play so as to result in one or more penalties being placed on the penalty time clock to one Team, the ensuing “face-off” shall be conducted at one of the two Face-off Spots in the offending Team’s End Zone. There are only three (3) exceptions to this application: (I) when a penalty is assessed after the scoring of a goal – “face-off” shall be conducted at Center ice; (II) when a penalty is assessed at the end (or start) of a period – “face-off” shall be conducted at Center ice; (III) when the defending Team is penalized, and the attacking Players enter the Attacking Zone beyond the outer edge of the End Zone Face-off Circle – “face-off” shall be conducted in the Neutral Zone. The Team awarded the “Power-Play” will have the choice of which End Zone spot the “face-off” will take place at to start the “Po­wer-Play”. When an infringement of a rule has been committed by Players of both Teams in the play resulting in the stoppage, the ensuing “face-off” will be conducted at the nearest Face-off Spot in that zone. (Rule 76 – FACE-OFF Locations)

qas.question: Where is the face-off conducted when a penalty is assessed after the scoring of a goal?

answers.text: When a penalty is assessed after the scoring of a goal in hockey, the face-off is conducted at Center ice.

qas.question: In what situations is the face-off conducted at Center ice according to the rule?

answers.text: The face-off is conducted at Center ice in two situations according to the rule: after a penalty is assessed following a goal and when a penalty is assessed at the end or start of a period.

qas.question: When the defending Team is penalized and the attacking Players enter the Attacking Zone beyond the outer edge of the End Zone Face-off Circle, where is the face-off conducted?

answers.text: When the defending team is penalized and the attacking players enter the Attacking Zone beyond the outer edge of the End Zone Face-off Circle, the face-off is conducted in the Neutral Zone.

qas.question: Who has the choice of determining the End Zone spot for the face-off when a Team is awarded a Power-Play?

answers.text: The Team awarded the Power-Play has the choice of determining the End Zone spot for the face-off.

qas.question: What determines the location of the face-off when an infringement of a rule has been committed by Players of both Teams resulting in a stoppage of play?

answers.text: When an infringement of a rule is committed by Players of both Teams resulting in a stoppage of play, the location of the face-off will be conducted at the nearest Face-off Spot in that zone.

answers.text: A player serves a two-minute penalty for a Minor Penalty before being allowed back on the ice.

paragraphs.context: “Short-handed” means that the Team is below the numerical strength of its opponent on the ice at the time the goal is scored. The Minor or Bench Minor Penalty which terminates automatically is the one with the least amount of time on the clock. Thus Coincident Minor Penalties to both Teams do not cause either side to be “short-handed” – see Rule 19 – Coincidental Penalties. If while a Team is “short-handed” by one or more Minor or Bench Minor Penalties, the opposing Team scores a goal, the first of such penalties shall automatically terminate. This rule shall also apply when a goal is awarded. This rule does not apply when a goal is scored on a “Penalty Shot” (i.e., offending Team’s penalized Player(s) do not get released on the scoring of a goal on a “Penalty Shot”). Minor Penalty expiration criteria: (I) Is the Team scored against “short-handed”? (II) Is the Team scored against serving a Minor Penalty on the clock? If both criteria are satisfied, the Minor Penalty with the least amount of time on the clock shall terminate except when “Coincidental Penalties” are being served. When the Minor Penalties of two Players of the same Team terminate at the same time, the Captain of that Team shall designate to the Referee which of such Players will return to the ice first and the Referee will instruct the Penalty Timekeeper accordingly.

qas.question: What does it mean for a team to be considered "short-handed" in hockey?

answers.text: In hockey, a team is considered "short-handed" when they have fewer players on the ice than their opponent due to penalties.

qas.question: Which penalty automatically terminates if a team is "short-handed" and the opposing team scores a goal?

answers.text: The penalty that automatically terminates if a team is "short-handed" and the opposing team scores a goal is the one with the least amount of time remaining on the clock.

qas.question: When does a minor penalty automatically terminate if the opposing team scores a goal while the penalized team is "short-handed"?

answers.text: A minor penalty automatically terminates if the opposing team scores a goal while the penalized team is "short-handed" by one or more penalties. The penalty with the least time remaining on the clock is the one that ends.

qas.question: In what situation do coincident minor penalties to both teams not result in either team being "short-handed"?

answers.text: Coincident minor penalties to both teams do not result in either team being "short-handed."

qas.question: How does the expiration of minor penalties work when two players from the same team have penalties that end at the same time?

answers.text: When two players from the same team have penalties that end at the same time, the team's captain must designate to the referee which player will return to the ice first.

paragraphs.context: Referees shall have the option to review all plays that result in the assessment of a Double-minor Penalty for ”High-sticking” for the purpose of, 1. Confirming the call on the ice or 2. Nullifying the call on the ice. Such reviews will be conducted exclusively by the Referee(s) on the ice in consultation with other On-ice Official(s), as appropriate, using the technology (for example, a handheld tablet or a television or computer monitor) specified in and provided pursuant. (Rule 38.5 – Process for Reviewing) Communication between the Video Review Operation and the On-ice Officials shall be limited to contact between the appropriate Video Review Consultant and the Referee to ensure the Referee is receiving any and all video they might request, as well as the appropriate replay angles they may need to review the penalty call. There shall be no contact or consultation except between the On-ice Official(s) and the Video Review Operation. The Referee shall only have the following options following Video Review of their own call: (I) Confirming the call on the ice or; or (II) Nullifying the call on the ice. Note: This rule is only applied in certain IIHF Championships. ( » For more information regarding implementation of video review system refer to IIHF Event Codes.)

qas.question: What is the communication protocol between the Video Review Operation and the On-ice Officials during the review process?

answers.text: The communication protocol between the Video Review Operation and the On-ice Officials during the review process is limited to contact between the Video Review Consultant and the Referee. The Referee can request video and replay angles for reviewing a Double-minor Penalty for "High-sticking" and has the options to confirm or nullify the call on the ice.

qas.question: What are the only two options available to the Referee following a Video Review of their own call for a Double-minor Penalty for "High-sticking"?

answers.text: The only two options available to the Referee following a Video Review of their own call for a Double-minor Penalty for "High-sticking" are: 1. Confirming the call on the ice or 2. Nullifying the call on the ice.

paragraphs.context: When “Coincidental Minor Penalties” or “Coincidental Minor Penalties of Equal Duration” are imposed against Players of both Teams, the penalized Players shall all take their places in the Penalty Boxes and such penalized Players shall not leave the Penalty Box until the first stoppage of play following the expiry of their respective penalties. Where Goalkeepers are involved, refer to (Rule 27.1 – Goalkeeper Penalties ➔) Immediate substitution shall be made for an “Equal Number of Minor Penalties or “Coincidental Minor Penalties of Equal Duration” to each Team penalized and the penalties of the Players for which substitutions have been made shall not be taken into account for the purpose of the “Delayed Penalty” rule (Rule 26 – Delayed Penalties) When multiple penalties are assessed to both Teams, “Equal Numbers of Minor and Major Penalties” shall be eliminated using the “Coincidental Penalty” rule and any differential in time penalties shall be served in the normal manner and displayed on the penalty time clock accordingly – see Rule 19.5 – Applying the Coincidental Penalty Rule. If there is no differential in time penalties, all Players will serve their allotted penalty time, but will not be released until the first stoppage of play following the expiration of their respective penalties. For “Coincidental Penalties” that carry over into, or are assessed during Overtime, see (Rule 84 – Overtime Operations)

qas.question: What must penalized players do when coincidental minor penalties are imposed against players of both teams?

answers.text: Penalized players must stay in the penalty box until the first stoppage of play after their penalties expire when coincidental minor penalties are imposed against players of both teams.

qas.question: When can penalized players leave the penalty box following the expiry of their respective penalties in the case of coincidental minor penalties?

qas.question: How are goalkeepers involved in coincidental minor penalties handled according to the rule?

qas.question: How are equal numbers of minor and major penalties eliminated using the coincidental penalty rule when multiple penalties are assessed to both teams?

Any time penalty differentials are served normally, and players are released after the first stoppage of play following the expiration of their penalties.

answers.text: All players will be released from the penalty box after the first stoppage of play following the expiry of their respective penalties.

paragraphs.context: When “Coincidental Major Penalties” or “Coincidental Penalties of Equal Duration”, including a Major Penalty, are imposed against Players of both Teams, the penalized Players shall all take their places in the Penalty Boxes and such penalized Players shall not leave the Penalty Boxes until the first stoppage of play following the expiry of their respective penalties. Immediate substitutions shall be made for an “Equal Number of Major Penalties”, or “Coincidental Penalties of Equal Duration” including a Major Penalty to each Team penalized, and the penalties of the Players for which substitutions have been made shall not be taken into account for the purpose of the Delayed Penalty. (Rule 26 – Delayed Penalties) In such situations, if one or both Players have received a Game Misconduct in addition to their Major Penalties, no substitutes are required to take their places in the Penalty Boxes.

qas.question: What must penalized players do when Coincidental Major Penalties are imposed against players of both teams?

answers.text: Penalized players must remain in the penalty boxes until the first stoppage of play after their penalties expire. Substitutions are made for an equal number of major penalties, and the penalized players' penalties are not counted for delayed penalties.

qas.question: When can penalized players leave the Penalty Boxes following the expiry of their respective penalties?

answers.text: Penalized players can leave the Penalty Boxes following the expiry of their penalties after the first stoppage of play.

qas.question: What happens if one or both players receive a Game Misconduct in addition to their Major Penalties during Coincidental Major Penalties?

answers.text: If one or both players receive a Game Misconduct in addition to their Major Penalties during Coincidental Major Penalties, no substitutes are required to take their places in the Penalty Boxes.

qas.question: How are immediate substitutions handled for Coincidental Penalties of Equal Duration, including a Major Penalty?

answers.text: For Coincidental Penalties of Equal Duration, including a Major Penalty, penalized players stay in the Penalty Boxes until the first stoppage of play after their penalties expire. Immediate substitutions are made for an equal number of major penalties or coincidental penalties of equal duration for each team. If a player receives a Game Misconduct with a Major Penalty, no substitutes are needed.

qas.question: Are the penalties of players for which substitutions have been made taken into account for the purpose of Delayed Penalty during Coincidental Major Penalties?

answers.text: No, the penalties of players for which substitutions have been made are not taken into account for the purpose of Delayed Penalty during Coincidental Major Penalties.

paragraphs.context: During the last five (5) minutes of regulation time, or at any time in Overtime, when a Minor Penalty (or Double-minor Penalty) is assessed to one Player of Team A, and a Major Penalty is assessed to one Player of Team B at the same stoppage of play, the three (3)-minute (or one (1)-minute) differential shall be served immediately as a Major Penalty. This is also applicable when “Coincidental Penalties” are negated, leaving the aforementioned examples. The Team must place the penalized Player or replacement Player in the Penalty Box immediately. The differential will be recorded on the penalty clock as a three (3) minute or a one (1) minute penalty (as applicable) and served in the same manner as a Major Penalty. This rule shall be applied regardless as to the on-ice strength of the two Teams at the time the above outlined penalties are assessed.

answers.text: If a Minor Penalty is assessed to one Player of Team A and a Major Penalty is assessed to one Player of Team B during the last five minutes of regulation time, the three-minute differential will be served immediately as a Major Penalty by the penalized Player or a replacement Player from the same team.

paragraphs.context: When multiple penalties are assessed to both Teams at the same stoppage of play, the following rules are to be utilized by the Referees to determine the on-ice strength for both Teams: (I) Cancel as many Major Penalties as possible; (II) Cancel as many Minor, Bench Minor and or Double-minor Penalties as possible.

paragraphs.context: A Major Penalty shall be imposed on any Player who commits a physical foul and who recklessly endangers the fouled Player in a way that, at the discretion of the Referee, such Player would not be sufficiently sanctioned by imposing a Minor or Double-minor Penalty. Such assessment of reckless endangerment shall be based on the severity of the infraction, severity of the contact, the degree of violence and the general reprehensibility involved. For the first (1) Major Penalty in any one game, the offender, except the Goalkeeper, shall be ruled off the ice for five (5) minutes during which time no substitute shall be permitted. When one Player receives a Major Penalty and a Minor Penalty at the same time, the Major Penalty shall be served first by the penalized Player (or substitute for the Goalkeeper), except under (Rule 19.2 – Coincidental Major Penalties) are in effect, in which case the Minor Penalty will be recorded and served first.

Such reviews will be conducted exclusively by the Referee(s) on the ice in consultation with other On-ice Official(s), as appropriate, using the technology (for example, a handheld tablet or a television or computer monitor) specified in and provided pursuant to: (Rule 38.5 – Process for Reviewing) Communication between the Video Review Operation and the On-ice Officials shall be limited to contact between the appropriate Video Review Consultant and the Referee to ensure the Referee is receiving any and all video they might request, as well as the appropriate replay angles they may need to review the penalty call. There shall be no contact or consultation except between the On-ice Official(s) and the Video Review Operation. The Referee shall only have the following options following Video Review of their own call: (I) confirming their original Major Penalty call; or (II) reducing their original Major Penalty call to a lesser penalty for the same infraction. (III) nullifying the original Major Penalty altogether. Note : This rule is only applied in certain IIHF Championships. ( » For more information information regarding implementation of video review system refer to IIHF Event Codes.)

answers.text: The specific exception to the rule allowing on-ice video review of major penalties related to fighting situations is that only situations falling under Rule 46.5 – Dangerous puncher – “Sucker puncher” can be reviewed. No other situations under Rule 46 – Fighting can be reviewed.

paragraphs.context: A Player receiving a Misconduct Penalty does not cause their Team to play “short-handed” unless they also receive a Minor or Major Penalty in addition to the Misconduct Penalty. When a Player receives a Minor Penalty and a Misconduct Penalty at the same time, the penalized Team shall immediately put a substitute Player in the Penalty Box and they shall serve the Minor Penalty without change. Should the opposing Team score during the time the Minor Penalty is being served, the Minor Penalty shall terminate (unless (Rule 15.4 – Short-handed Team) – Goal Scored is applicable) and the Misconduct to the originally penalized Player shall start immediately. When a Player receives a Major Penalty and a Misconduct Penalty at the same time, the penalized Team shall immediately place a substitute Player in the Penalty Box and no replacement for the penalized Player shall be permitted to enter the game except from the Penalty Box.

paragraphs.context: The Referee shall announce the reason for the assessed “Penalty Shot” and shall have the Skater selected by the Team entitled to take the “Penalty Shot” announced over the Public Address System. The puck shall then be placed on the Center Face-off Spot and the Player taking the “Penalty Shot” will, on the instruction of the Referee, by blowing their whistle, play the puck from there and shall attempt to score on the Goalkeeper. The puck must be kept in motion towards the opponent’s Goal Line and once it is shot, the play shall be considered complete. No goal can be scored on a rebound of any kind (an exception being the puck off the Goal Post or crossbar, then the Goalkeeper and then directly into the goal), and any time the puck crosses the Goal Line or comes to a complete stop, the “Penalty Shot” shall be considered complete. The “lacrosse-like move” whereby the puck is picked up on the blade of the stick and “whipped” into the net shall be permitted provided the puck is not raised above the height of the shoulders at any time and when released, is not carried higher than the crossbar. (Rule 80.1 – High-sticking the Puck) The “spin-o-rama type move” where the Player completes a 360° turn as they approach the goal, shall not be permitted. Should a Player perform such a move during the “Penalty Shot”, the shot shall be stopped by the Referee and no goal will be the result. Only a Player designated as a Goalkeeper or alternate Goalkeeper may defend against a “Penalty Shot”. The Goalkeeper must remain in their crease until the Player taking a “Penalty Shot” has touched the puck. If at the time a “Penalty Shot” is awarded, the Goalkeeper of the penalized Team has been removed from the ice to substitute another Player, the Goalkeeper shall be permitted to return to the ice before the “Penalty Shot” is taken. The Team against whom the “Penalty Shot” has been assessed may replace their Goalkeeper to defend against the shot, however, the substitute goalkeeper is required to remain in the game until the next stoppage of play. While the “Penalty Shot” is being taken, Players of both sides shall withdraw to the sides of the Rink and in front of their own Player’s Bench.

qas.question: What must the Referee do before a "Penalty Shot" is taken?

answers.text: Before a "Penalty Shot" is taken, the Referee must announce the reason for the penalty, select the Skater to take the shot, have them announced over the Public Address System, place the puck on the Center Face-off Spot, and instruct the Player to play the puck towards the opponent's Goal Line to attempt to score on the Goalkeeper.

qas.question: Where is the puck placed before a Player takes a "Penalty Shot"?

answers.text: The puck is placed on the Center Face-off Spot before a Player takes a "Penalty Shot" in hockey.

qas.question: What is the specific rule regarding scoring on a rebound during a "Penalty Shot"?

answers.text: During a "Penalty Shot," a goal cannot be scored on a rebound except if the puck hits the goal post or crossbar, then the goalkeeper, and goes directly into the net.

qas.question: What type of move is permitted during a "Penalty Shot" as long as the puck is not raised above shoulder height?

answers.text: During a "Penalty Shot," a player can perform a "lacrosse-like move" where the puck is picked up on the blade of the stick and "whipped" into the net, as long as the puck is not raised above shoulder height.

qas.question: Who is allowed to defend against a "Penalty Shot" according to the rules?

answers.text: Only a Player designated as a Goalkeeper or alternate Goalkeeper is allowed to defend against a "Penalty Shot" according to the rules.

paragraphs.context: In all cases where a “Penalty Shot” has been awarded, the “Penalty Shot” shall be taken by a Skater selected by the Coach or Captain of the non-offending Team from any non-penalized Skater of their Team. Such selection shall be reported to the Referee and cannot be changed.

answers.text: The Coach or Captain of the non-offending team is responsible for selecting the player to take a Penalty Shot in a hockey game.

qas.question: Can the designated player for a Penalty Shot be changed once they have been selected by the Coach or Captain?

answers.text: No, the designated player for a Penalty Shot cannot be changed once they have been selected by the Coach or Captain.

qas.question: What type of player can be chosen to take a Penalty Shot according to the rule?

answers.text: A Skater selected by the Coach or Captain of the non-offending Team from any non-penalized Skater of their Team can take a Penalty Shot according to the rule.

qas.question: What is the process for reporting the selected player for a Penalty Shot to the Referee?

answers.text: To report the selected player for a Penalty Shot to the Referee, the Coach or Captain of the non-offending Team must choose a Skater from their Team and inform the Referee. Once reported, the selection cannot be changed.

qas.question: Is it mandatory for the designated player for a Penalty Shot to be a non-penalized Skater from the non-offending Team?

answers.text: Yes, it is mandatory for the designated player for a Penalty Shot to be a non-penalized Skater from the non-offending Team.

paragraphs.context: Should the Goalkeeper leave their Crease prior to the Player taking the “Penalty Shot” touching the puck, or committing any infraction, the Referee shall allow the “Penalty Shot” to be taken. If the “Penalty Shot” fails, the Referee shall permit the “Penalty Shot” to be taken over again. When an infraction worthy of a Minor Penalty is committed by the Goalkeeper during the “Penalty Shot” causing it to fail, no penalty is assessed but the Referee shall permit the “Penalty Shot” to be taken over again. Should a Goalkeeper commit a second (2nd) violation and the “Penalty Shot” fails, they shall be assessed a Misconduct Penalty and the Referee shall permit the “Penalty Shot” to be taken over again. A third (3rd) such violation shall result in the Goalkeeper being assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty and a goal shall be awarded. When a Major Penalty is committed by the Goalkeeper that causes the shot to fail, the Referee shall permit the “Penalty Shot” to be taken over again and the appropriate penalties shall be assessed to the Goalkeeper. The Goalkeeper may attempt to stop the “Penalty Shot” in any manner except by throwing their stick or any object, deliberately removes their helmet and/or face mask, or by deliberately dislodging the goal, in which case a goal shall be awarded. During the “Penalty Shot”, should the Goalkeeper, in an attempt at making a save, dislodge the goal accidentally, the Referee shall make one of the following determinations: (I) Award a goal if they deem the Player would have scored into the area normally occupied by the net had it not been dislodged. (II) Allow the “Penalty Shot” to be re-taken if they do not score or it could not be determined if the puck would have entered the area normally occupied by the net. (III) If the goal becomes dislodged after the puck has crossed the Goal Line thus ending the “Penalty Shot”, the above determinations do not apply, the “Penalty Shot” is complete. If, while a “Penalty Shot” is being taken, any Player, Coach or team personnel of the opposing Team interferes with or distracts the Player taking the “Penalty Shot” and, because of such action, the “Penalty Shot” fails, a second (2nd) attempt shall be permitted. The Referee shall impose a Bench Minor Penalty to the offending Team, and if a Player on the Bench is responsible, a Misconduct Penalty on the Player responsible shall be assessed. When a Coach or team personnel is guilty of such an act, a Game Misconduct Penalty shall be assessed on the responsible person and the matter will be reported to the Proper Authorities for possible further disciplinary action. If, while the “Penalty Shot” is being taken, any Player, Coach or team personnel of the Team taking the “Penalty Shot” interferes with or distracts the Goalkeeper defending the “Penalty Shot” and, because of such action, the shot is successful, the Referee shall rule no goal and shall impose a Bench Minor Penalty to the offending Team. If while the “Penalty Shot” is being taken a spectator throws any object onto the ice that in the judgment of the Referee interferes with the Player taking the “Penalty Shot” or the Goalkeeper defending the “Penalty Shot”, they shall permit the “Penalty Shot” to be taken again. For incidents involving stick measurements refer to: (Rule 10.5 Sticks Measurement) and (Rule 10.6 – Sticks Measurement – Prior to Penalty Shot)

qas.question: What happens if the Goalkeeper leaves their Crease before the Player takes the Penalty Shot?

answers.text: If the Goalkeeper leaves their crease before the Player takes the Penalty Shot, the Referee shall allow the Penalty Shot to be taken.

qas.question: How many violations can a Goalkeeper commit during a Penalty Shot before being assessed a Misconduct Penalty?

answers.text: A Goalkeeper can commit two violations during a Penalty Shot before being assessed a Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: What penalties are assessed to the Goalkeeper if they commit a Major Penalty during a Penalty Shot?

answers.text: If a Goalkeeper commits a Major Penalty during a Penalty Shot causing it to fail, the Referee will allow the shot to be retaken and assess the appropriate penalties to the Goalkeeper.

qas.question: What actions are prohibited for the Goalkeeper during a Penalty Shot that would result in a goal being awarded?

answers.text: The Goalkeeper is prohibited from throwing their stick or any object, deliberately removing their helmet and/or face mask, or deliberately dislodging the goal during a Penalty Shot. If any of these actions occur, a goal will be awarded to the opposing team.

qas.question: What penalties are imposed if a Player, Coach, or team personnel interferes with the Player taking a Penalty Shot, causing it to fail?

answers.text: If interference by a Player, Coach, or team personnel causes a Penalty Shot to fail, a second attempt is permitted. The offending Team receives a Bench Minor Penalty, and if a Player is responsible, a Misconduct Penalty is assessed. If a Coach or team personnel is at fault, a Game Misconduct Penalty is given, with potential further disciplinary action.

paragraphs.context: If a goal is scored from a “Penalty Shot”, the puck shall be faced-off at Center ice. If a goal is not scored, the puck shall be faced-off at either of the end Face-off Spots in the zone in which the “Penalty Shot” was attempted, except when another rule dictates the “face-off” location should be in an alternate location, such as when the “point men” enter the zone beyond the outer edge of the End-Zone Face-off Circle or when the attacking Team has been penalized on the same play. (Rule 76.2 – Face-off Locations)

qas.question: Where is the puck faced-off if a goal is scored from a Penalty Shot?

answers.text: If a goal is scored from a Penalty Shot in hockey, the puck is faced-off at Center ice.

qas.question: What determines the face-off location if a goal is not scored from a Penalty Shot?

answers.text: If a goal is not scored from a Penalty Shot, the face-off location will be at either of the end Face-off Spots in the zone where the Penalty Shot was attempted, unless another rule specifies a different location.

qas.question: In which situations would the face-off location after a Penalty Shot be different from the standard locations?

answers.text: The face-off location after a Penalty Shot would be different from the standard locations if a goal is not scored, in which case the puck would be faced-off at either of the end Face-off Spots in the zone where the Penalty Shot was attempted, unless another rule specifies an alternate location.

qas.question: If a Penalty Shot is attempted and the attacking team is penalized on the same play, where is the puck faced-off?

answers.text: If a Penalty Shot is attempted and the attacking team is penalized on the same play, the puck is faced-off at either of the end Face-off Spots in the zone where the Penalty Shot was attempted.

qas.question: When can the face-off location after a Penalty Shot be at Center ice?

answers.text: The face-off location after a Penalty Shot can be at Center ice if a goal is scored.

paragraphs.context: Should a goal be scored from a “Penalty Shot”, a further penalty to the offending Player shall not be applied unless the offense for which the “Penalty Shot” was awarded is a Major or Misconduct Penalty, in which case the appropriate penalty shall be imposed. If the offense for which the “Penalty Shot” was awarded would normally incur a Minor Penalty, then regardless of the outcome of the “Penalty Shot”, no further Minor Penalty shall be served. If the offense for which the “Penalty Shot” was awarded was to incur a Double-minor Penalty, or where the offending Team is assessed an additional Minor Penalty on the same play, the first Minor Penalty is not assessed since the “Penalty Shot” was awarded to restore the lost scoring opportunity.The second Minor Penalty would be assessed and served regardless of whether the “Penalty Shot” results in a goal. This will be announced as a Double-minor Penalty for the appropriate infraction and the Player will serve two (2) minutes only. No penalty shall expire when a goal is scored against a Team on a “Penalty Shot”. Should two (2) “Penalty Shots” be awarded to the same Team at the same stoppage of play (two (2) separate infractions), only one (1) goal can be scored or awarded at a single stoppage of play. Should the first “Penalty Shot” result in a goal, the second “Penalty Shot” would not be taken but the appropriate penalty would be assessed and served for the infraction committed.

qas.question: What happens if a goal is scored from a Penalty Shot for an offense that would normally incur a Minor Penalty?

answers.text: If a goal is scored from a Penalty Shot for an offense that would normally incur a Minor Penalty, no further Minor Penalty shall be served regardless of the outcome of the Penalty Shot.

qas.question: When is a further penalty applied to the offending Player after a goal is scored from a Penalty Shot?

answers.text: A further penalty is applied to the offending Player after a goal is scored from a Penalty Shot only if the offense for which the Penalty Shot was awarded is a Major or Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: If a Penalty Shot is awarded for an offense that would result in a Double-minor Penalty, how are the penalties handled if a goal is scored?

answers.text: If a Penalty Shot is awarded for an offense that would result in a Double-minor Penalty and a goal is scored, the first Minor Penalty is not assessed. The second Minor Penalty is assessed and served regardless of the goal. The Player serves two minutes for the Double-minor Penalty.

qas.question: What happens if a team is assessed an additional Minor Penalty on the same play where a Penalty Shot is awarded?

answers.text: If a team is assessed an additional Minor Penalty on the same play where a Penalty Shot is awarded, the first Minor Penalty is not assessed. The second Minor Penalty will be assessed and served regardless of the outcome of the Penalty Shot.

qas.question: Can a team score more than one goal from Penalty Shots awarded at the same stoppage of play for separate infractions?

answers.text: No, a team cannot score more than one goal from Penalty Shots awarded at the same stoppage of play for separate infractions. If the first Penalty Shot results in a goal, the second Penalty Shot will not be taken, and the appropriate penalty will be assessed for the infraction committed.

paragraphs.context: If the infraction upon which the “Penalty Shot” is based occurs during actual playing time, the “Penalty Shot” shall be awarded and taken immediately in the usual manner notwithstanding any delay occasioned by a slow whistle by the Referee to allow play to continue until the attacking side has lost possession of the puck to the defending side, to which this delay results in the expiry of the regular playing time in any period. The time required for the taking of a “Penalty Shot” shall not be included in the regular playing time or Overtime.

qas.question: When is a Penalty Shot awarded and taken if the infraction occurs during actual playing time?

answers.text: A Penalty Shot is awarded and taken immediately if the infraction occurs during actual playing time, even if it results in the expiry of regular playing time or Overtime.

qas.question: How does a slow whistle by the Referee affect the timing of a Penalty Shot?

answers.text: A slow whistle by the Referee does not affect the timing of a Penalty Shot. The Penalty Shot must be taken immediately, regardless of any delay caused by the Referee allowing play to continue until the attacking team loses possession. The time taken for the Penalty Shot is not counted towards regular playing time or Overtime.

qas.question: Is the time required for the taking of a Penalty Shot included in the regular playing time or Overtime?

answers.text: The time required for the taking of a Penalty Shot is not included in the regular playing time or Overtime.

qas.question: What happens if the delay caused by a slow whistle results in the expiry of the regular playing time in any period during a Penalty Shot?

answers.text: If a slow whistle causes the expiry of regular playing time during a Penalty Shot, the Penalty Shot will still be taken immediately, and the time taken for the shot will not count towards regular playing time or overtime.

qas.question: Can play continue until the attacking side loses possession of the puck to the defending side before a Penalty Shot is taken?

answers.text: Yes, play can continue until the attacking side loses possession of the puck to the defending side before a Penalty Shot is taken, even if it results in the expiry of regular playing time in any period.

paragraphs.context: When a Player, in the Neutral or Attacking Zone, in “control” of the puck (or who could have obtained “possession and control” of the puck) and having no other opponent to pass than the Goalkeeper, is fouled from behind, thus preventing a reasonable scoring opportunity, a “Penalty Shot” shall be awarded to the non-offending Team. Nevertheless, the Referee shall not stop play until the attacking Team has “lost possession” of the puck to the defending Team. The intention of this rule is to restore a reasonable “scoring opportunity” which has been lost. If, however, the Player fouled is able to recover and obtain a “reasonable scoring opportunity” (or a Teammate is able to gain a reasonable scoring opportunity), no “Penalty Shot” should be awarded but the appropriate penalty should be signaled and assessed if a goal is not scored on the play. “Control of the puck” means the act of propelling the puck with the stick, hand, or feet. In order for a “Penalty Shot” to be awarded for a Player being fouled from behind, the following four (4) criteria must have been met: (I) The infraction must have taken place in the Neutral or Attacking Zone (i.e., over the puck carrier’s own Blue Line); (II) The infraction must have been committed from behind (except a foul committed from the front by the Goalkeeper on a “breakaway” situation); (III) The Player in “possession and control” (or, in the judgment of the Referee, the Player clearly would have “obtained possession and control” of the puck) must have been denied a reasonable chance to score. The fact that the Player got a shot off does not automatically eliminate this play from the “Penalty Shot” consideration criteria. If the infraction was from behind and the Player was denied a “more reasonable scoring opportunity” due to the infraction, then the “Penalty Shot” should still be awarded; (IV) The Player in “possession and control” (or, in the judgment of the Referee, the Player clearly would have “obtained possession and control”) must have had no opposing Player between themself and the Goalkeeper. If, in the opinion of the Referee, a Player makes contact with the puck first and subsequently trips the opponent in so doing, no “Penalty Shot” will be awarded, but a Minor Penalty for “tripping” shall be assessed. It should be noted that if the attacking Player manages to get around the Goalkeeper and has no defending Player between them and the “open goal”, and they are fouled from behind by the Goalkeeper or another defending Player, no goal can be awarded since the Goalkeeper is still on the ice. A “Penalty Shot” would be awarded.

qas.question: What must happen for a "Penalty Shot" to be awarded to the non-offending Team when a Player is fouled from behind in the Neutral or Attacking Zone?

answers.text: For a "Penalty Shot" to be awarded to the non-offending Team when a Player is fouled from behind in the Neutral or Attacking Zone, the Player must be in control of the puck, have no other opponent to pass than the Goalkeeper, be denied a reasonable scoring opportunity, and have no opposing Player between themself and the Goalkeeper.

qas.question: Under what circumstances should a "Penalty Shot" not be awarded even if a Player is fouled from behind and denied a reasonable scoring opportunity?

answers.text: A "Penalty Shot" should not be awarded if a Player is fouled from behind and denied a reasonable scoring opportunity, but is able to recover and obtain a reasonable scoring opportunity or if a teammate gains a reasonable scoring opportunity.

qas.question: What are the four criteria that must be met for a Player to be awarded a "Penalty Shot" after being fouled from behind in the Neutral or Attacking Zone?

answers.text: For a Player to be awarded a "Penalty Shot" after being fouled from behind in the Neutral or Attacking Zone, the four criteria are: (I) Infraction in the Neutral or Attacking Zone, (II) Foul committed from behind, (III) Denial of a reasonable scoring chance, and (IV) No opposing Player between the fouled Player and the Goalkeeper.

qas.question: When is a Minor Penalty for "tripping" assessed instead of awarding a "Penalty Shot" when a Player is fouled from behind in a scoring opportunity?

answers.text: A Minor Penalty for "tripping" is assessed instead of a Penalty Shot when a Player makes contact with the puck first and subsequently trips the opponent in a scoring opportunity.

qas.question: In what situation would a goal not be awarded even if an attacking Player is fouled from behind by the Goalkeeper or another defending Player while having no defending Player between them and the open goal?

answers.text: A goal would not be awarded if an attacking player is fouled from behind by the goalkeeper or another defending player when there is no defending player between them and the open goal, and the goalkeeper is still on the ice.

paragraphs.context: A goal will be awarded to the attacking Team when the opposing Team has taken their Goalkeeper off the ice and an attacking Player has “possession and control of the puck” (or “would have gained possession and control”) in the Neutral or Attacking Zone, without a defending Player between themself and the opposing goal, and they are “prevented from scoring” as a result of an infraction committed by the defending Team. (Rule 25.3 – Infractions when Goalkeeper is Off the Ice)

qas.question: When will a goal be awarded to the attacking team according to the rule on AWARDED GOALS?

answers.text: A goal will be awarded to the attacking team when their player has possession and control of the puck in the Neutral or Attacking Zone, with no defending player between them and the opposing goal, and is prevented from scoring due to an infraction by the defending team while the opposing team's goalkeeper is off the ice.

qas.question: In what situation will an attacking player be awarded a goal if the opposing team's goalkeeper is off the ice?

answers.text: An attacking player will be awarded a goal if the opposing team's goalkeeper is off the ice and the attacking player is prevented from scoring due to an infraction committed by the defending team.

qas.question: What conditions must be met for an attacking team to be awarded a goal when the opposing team's goalkeeper is off the ice?

answers.text: For an attacking team to be awarded a goal when the opposing team's goalkeeper is off the ice, the attacking player must have possession or control of the puck in the Neutral or Attacking Zone, with no defending player between them and the opposing goal, and be prevented from scoring due to an infraction by the defending team.

qas.question: Which zone must the attacking player be in to be eligible for an awarded goal when the opposing team's goalkeeper is off the ice?

answers.text: The attacking player must be in the Neutral or Attacking Zone to be eligible for an awarded goal when the opposing team's goalkeeper is off the ice.

qas.question: What must happen for an attacking player to be prevented from scoring and for an awarded goal to be given to the attacking team?

answers.text: For an attacking player to be prevented from scoring and for an awarded goal to be given to the attacking team, the opposing team must have their goalkeeper off the ice, the attacking player must have possession or control of the puck in the Neutral or Attacking Zone without a defending player in between, and the attacking player must be prevented from scoring due to an infraction committed by the defending team.

paragraphs.context: A goal will be awarded when an attacking Player with “an imminent scoring opportunity”, is “prevented from scoring” as a result of a defending Player displacing the Goal Post, either “deliberately or accidentally” and it must be determined that the puck would have entered the Goal between the normal position of the Goal Posts. (Rule 63.7 – Awarded Goal)

qas.question: When will a goal be awarded under Rule 63.7 regarding infractions when the goalkeeper is on the ice?

answers.text: A goal will be awarded under Rule 63.7 when a defending player displaces the goal post, deliberately or accidentally, preventing an attacking player with an imminent scoring opportunity from scoring, and it is determined that the puck would have entered the goal between the normal position of the goal posts.

qas.question: What conditions must be met for an attacking player to be awarded a goal due to a defending player displacing the goal post?

answers.text: An attacking player must have an imminent scoring opportunity and be prevented from scoring by a defending player displacing the goal post, either deliberately or accidentally. It must be determined that the puck would have entered the goal between the normal position of the goal posts for a goal to be awarded.

qas.question: What type of opportunity must an attacking player have for a goal to be awarded if the goal post is displaced by a defending player?

answers.text: An attacking player must have an imminent scoring opportunity for a goal to be awarded if the goal post is displaced by a defending player.

qas.question: Can a goal be awarded if a defending player accidentally displaces the goal post while an attacking player has an imminent scoring opportunity?

answers.text: Yes, a goal can be awarded if a defending player accidentally displaces the goal post while an attacking player has an imminent scoring opportunity, as long as it is determined that the puck would have entered the goal between the normal position of the goal posts.

qas.question: How is it determined whether a puck would have entered the goal between the normal position of the goal posts for an awarded goal under Rule 63.7?

answers.text: To determine if a puck would have entered the goal between the normal position of the goal posts for an awarded goal under Rule 63.7, it must be established that the attacking player had an imminent scoring opportunity and was prevented from scoring due to the defending player displacing the goal post, either deliberately or accidentally.

paragraphs.context: If, when the opposing goalkeeper has been removed from the ice, a player in control of the puck (or who could have obtained possession and control of the puck) in the neutral or attacking zone is tripped or otherwise fouled with no opposition between him and the opposing goal, thus preventing a reasonable scoring opportunity, the Referee shall immediately stop play and award a goal to the attacking team. A list of the infractions that shall result in an awarded goal when the goalkeeper has been removed for an extra attacker can be found in Table 12.

qas.question: What action will the Referee take if a player in control of the puck is tripped or fouled in the neutral or attacking zone with no opposition between him and the opposing goal when the opposing goalkeeper has been removed from the ice?

answers.text: The Referee will award a goal to the attacking team if a player in control of the puck is tripped or fouled in the neutral or attacking zone with no opposition between him and the opposing goal when the opposing goalkeeper has been removed from the ice.

qas.question: When will the Referee award a goal to the attacking team according to the rule on infractions when the goalkeeper is off the ice?

answers.text: The Referee will award a goal to the attacking team if a player is fouled in the neutral or attacking zone with no opposition between him and the opposing goal, preventing a reasonable scoring opportunity, while the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice.

qas.question: In what specific scenario will a player be awarded a goal if they are fouled in the neutral or attacking zone with no opposition between them and the opposing goal when the opposing goalkeeper is not on the ice?

answers.text: A player will be awarded a goal if they are fouled in the neutral or attacking zone with no opposition between them and the opposing goal when the opposing goalkeeper is not on the ice, preventing a reasonable scoring opportunity.

qas.question: What type of infractions listed in Table 12 will result in an awarded goal for the attacking team when the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice?

answers.text: Infractions listed in Table 12 that will result in an awarded goal for the attacking team when the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice are those that prevent a reasonable scoring opportunity for a player in control of the puck in the neutral or attacking zone with no opposition between them and the opposing goal.

qas.question: How does the rule on awarded goals apply when a player is prevented from having a reasonable scoring opportunity due to being tripped or fouled with no opposition between them and the opposing goal while the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice?

answers.text: If a player is tripped or fouled with no opposition between them and the opposing goal while the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice, the rule states that the Referee shall stop play and award a goal to the attacking team.

paragraphs.context: A goal will be awarded when a Goalkeeper attempts to stop a “Penalty Shot” by throwing their stick or any other object at the Player taking the “Penalty Shot” or by dislodging the goal (either deliberately or accidentally) or removes their face mask to force an interruption. (Rule 63.7 – Awarded Goal)

qas.question: What action by a Goalkeeper during a Penalty Shot will result in an awarded goal according to Rule 63.7?

answers.text: A Goalkeeper throwing their stick or any object at the player, deliberately dislodging the goal, or removing their face mask during a Penalty Shot will result in an awarded goal according to Rule 63.7.

qas.question: When will a goal be awarded during the course of a Penalty Shot as per the rule on infractions outlined in the context?

answers.text: A goal will be awarded during a Penalty Shot if the Goalkeeper throws their stick or any object at the player, dislodges the goal intentionally or accidentally, or removes their face mask to cause a stoppage.

qas.question: According to the rule on awarded goals in Penalty Shots, what will lead to a goal being awarded if a Goalkeeper throws their stick at the Player taking the shot?

answers.text: If a Goalkeeper throws their stick at the Player taking a Penalty Shot, a goal will be awarded according to Rule 63.7.

qas.question: In what situations will a goal be awarded during a Penalty Shot if the Goalkeeper dislodges the goal, based on the rule provided?

answers.text: A goal will be awarded during a Penalty Shot if the Goalkeeper dislodges the goal, whether deliberately or accidentally, as per Rule 63.7.

qas.question: What specific action by a Goalkeeper during a Penalty Shot will result in an awarded goal according to the rule on infractions detailed in the context?

answers.text: A Goalkeeper throwing their stick or any object at the Player during a Penalty Shot will result in an awarded goal according to Rule 63.7.

paragraphs.context: If a third (3rd) Player of any Team is penalized while two (2) Players of the same Team are serving penalties, the penalty time of the third (3rd) Player shall not commence until the penalty time of one (1) of the two (2) Players already penalized has elapsed. The third (3rd) penalized Player must proceed at once to the Penalty Box. They may be substituted for on the ice to keep the “on-ice strength” at no less than three (3) Skaters for their Team. When the penalties of two (2) Players of the same Team will expire at the same time, the Captain of that Team will designate to the Referee which Player will return to the ice first and the Referee will instruct the Penalty Timekeeper accordingly (this is done to expedite the release of a Player from the Penalty Box when the opposing Team scores on the “Power-Play”).

qas.question: What happens if a third player from a team is penalized while two players from the same team are already serving penalties?

answers.text: If a third player from a team is penalized while two players from the same team are already serving penalties, the penalty time of the third player will start once one of the two players serving penalties has elapsed. The third player must go to the Penalty Box immediately and can be substituted on the ice to maintain at least three skaters. If the penalties of the two players expire simultaneously, the team's captain will choose which player returns first.

qas.question: When does the penalty time for the third penalized player begin in the scenario described in the rule?

answers.text: The penalty time for the third penalized player begins after one of the two already penalized players' penalty time has elapsed.

qas.question: How many skaters must a team maintain on the ice when a third player is penalized while two players are already serving penalties?

answers.text: When a third player is penalized while two players are already serving penalties, the team must maintain at least three skaters on the ice.

qas.question: Who is responsible for designating which player returns to the ice first when two players' penalties expire at the same time?

answers.text: The team's Captain is responsible for designating which player returns to the ice first when two players' penalties expire at the same time.

qas.question: Why does the referee need to be informed by the team captain about which player should return to the ice first in the case of simultaneous penalty expirations?

answers.text: The team captain informs the referee about which player should return to the ice first in case of simultaneous penalty expirations to expedite the release of a player from the penalty box when the opposing team scores on the power play.

paragraphs.context: When any Team has three (3) Players serving penalties at the same time and because of the Delayed Penalty rule, a substitute for the third (3rd) offender is on the ice, none of the three (3) penalized Players in the Penalty Box may return to the ice until play has stopped. When play has been stopped, the Player whose penalty has fully expired may return to the ice. During the play, the Penalty Timekeeper shall permit the penalized Players to return to the ice, in the order of expiration of their penalties, but only when the penalized Team is entitled to have more than four (4) Players on the ice. Otherwise, these Players must wait until the first stoppage of play after the expiration of their penalties in order to be released from the Penalty Box.

qas.question: What happens if a team has three players serving penalties at the same time due to delayed penalties and a substitute for the third offender is on the ice?

answers.text: If a team has three players serving penalties at the same time with a substitute on the ice due to delayed penalties, none of the penalized players can return to the ice until play stops. The player whose penalty has fully expired can then return first, followed by the others when the team is entitled to have more than four players on the ice or at the first stoppage of play after their penalties expire.

qas.question: When can a penalized player return to the ice if their penalty has fully expired during play?

answers.text: A penalized player can return to the ice when their penalty has fully expired during play only after the first stoppage of play following the expiration of their penalty.

qas.question: How does the Penalty Timekeeper determine when penalized players can return to the ice in the order of expiration of their penalties?

answers.text: The Penalty Timekeeper determines when penalized players can return to the ice based on the order of expiration of their penalties, allowing them back during play only if the team is entitled to have more than four players on the ice; otherwise, they must wait for the first stoppage of play after their penalties expire.

qas.question: What must happen for penalized players to be released from the Penalty Box if the penalized team is not entitled to have more than four players on the ice?

answers.text: Penalized players can only be released from the Penalty Box after the first stoppage of play following the expiration of their penalties if the team is not allowed to have more than four players on the ice.

qas.question: In what situation can a player whose penalty has fully expired return to the ice during play?

paragraphs.context: A Goalkeeper shall not be sent to the Penalty Box for an offense which incurs a Minor Penalty, but instead, the Minor Penalty shall be served by another member of their Team who was on the ice when the offense was committed. This Player is to be designated by the Coach of the offending Team through the playing Captain and such substitute shall not be changed. A penalized Player may not serve a Goalkeeper’s penalty. If the Goalkeeper is involved in Coincidental Penalties being assessed and as a result, their Team is required to play “short-handed” due to additional penalties assessed to the Goalkeeper, the Player designated to serve the additional time penalties assessed to the Goalkeeper may be any Player as designated by the Coach of the offending Team through the Captain.

paragraphs.context: A Goalkeeper shall not be sent to the Penalty Box for an offense which incurs a Major Penalty, but instead, the Major Penalty shall be served immediately by another member of their Team who was on the ice when the offense was committed. This Player is to be designated by the Coach of the offending Team through the Captain and such substitute shall not be changed. When a Goalkeeper is assessed a Major Penalty plus a Game Misconduct, which is coincidental with a Major Penalty to the opposing Team, no Player is required to serve the Goalkeeper’s penalties in the Penalty Box, since they have been ejected from the game. Should a Goalkeeper incur two (2) Major Penalties in one game (results an automatic Game Misconduct Penalty), they shall be ruled off the ice for the balance of the game and their place shall be taken by a member of their own Team, or by a regular substitute Goalkeeper who is available. Such Player will be allowed the Goalkeeper’s full equipment.

paragraphs.context: A Minor Penalty shall be imposed on a Goalkeeper who leaves the immediate vicinity of their Goal Crease during an altercation. However, should the altercation occur in or near the Goalkeeper’s crease, the Referee should direct the Goalkeeper to a neutral location and not assess a penalty for leaving the immediate vicinity of the Goal Crease. Equally, if the Goalkeeper is legitimately outside the immediate vicinity of the Goal Crease for the purpose of proceeding to the Players’ Bench to be substituted for an extra attacker, and they subsequently become involved in an altercation, the Minor Penalty for leaving the crease would not be assessed. In addition, during stoppages of play in the game, they must not proceed to their Players’ Bench for the purpose of receiving a replacement stick or equipment or repairs thereto, or due to an injury, or to receive instructions, without first obtaining permission to do so from the Referee. Otherwise, they must be replaced by the substitute Goalkeeper immediately (without any delay) or be assessed a Bench Minor Penalty. (Rule 63 – Delaying the Game)

qas.question: What penalty shall be imposed on a Goalkeeper who leaves the immediate vicinity of their Goal Crease during an altercation?

paragraphs.context: A Goalkeeper shall not play the puck outside of the goalkeeper restricted area behind the net. Should the Goalkeeper play the puck outside of the goalkeeper restricted area behind the Goal Line, a Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” shall be imposed. The determining factor shall be the position of the puck. The Minor Penalty will not be assessed when a Goalkeeper plays the puck while maintaining skate contact with their Goal Crease. The designated trapezoidal area is marked with lines behind each goal. The lines run diagonally from the Goal Line to the Boards behind the goal. The outer dimension at the Goal Line is 6.80 m and at the Boards 8.60 m.

qas.question: How is the goalkeeper restricted area behind the net defined in hockey rules?

answers.text: The goalkeeper restricted area behind the net in hockey rules is defined by the trapezoidal area marked with lines behind each goal. The area's outer dimensions are 6.80 m at the Goal Line and 8.60 m at the Boards. Goalkeepers are not allowed to play the puck outside this designated area, or they risk a Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game."

qas.question: What are the dimensions of the trapezoidal area behind each goal in hockey?

answers.text: The trapezoidal area behind each goal in hockey has dimensions of 6.80 meters at the Goal Line and 8.60 meters at the Boards.

qas.question: What is the determining factor for assessing a Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" if a Goalkeeper plays the puck outside of the goalkeeper restricted area?

answers.text: The determining factor for assessing a Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" if a Goalkeeper plays the puck outside of the goalkeeper restricted area is the position of the puck relative to the designated trapezoidal area behind the net.

paragraphs.context: The Referees shall have general supervision of the game and shall have full control of all off-ice Game Officials and Players during the game, including stoppages; and in case of any dispute, their decision shall be final. As there is a human factor involved in blowing the whistle to stop play, the Referee may deem the play to be stopped slightly prior to the whistle actually being blown. The fact that the puck may come loose or cross the Goal Line prior to the sound of the whistle has no bearing if the Referee has ruled that the play had been stopped prior to this happening. In the event of any dispute regarding time or the expiration of penalties, the matter shall be referred to the Referee for adjustment and their decision shall be final. They may use the Video Review Consultant to assist in rendering the final decision. (Rule 37 – Video Review) and (Rule 38 – Coach’s Challenge)

paragraphs.context: It shall be the duty of the Referees to impose such penalties as are prescribed by the rules for infractions thereof and they shall give the “final on-ice decision” in matters of disputed goals. The Referees may consult with the Linespersons before making their decision. The Referees shall not halt the game for any infractions of the rules concerning Rule 83 – Off-side, or any violation of Rule 81 – Icing. Determining infractions of these rules is the duty of the Linespersons unless, by virtue of some unforeseen issue, the Linesperson is prevented from doing so in which case the duties of the Linesperson shall be assumed by a Referee until play is stopped. paragraphs.context: The Referees shall have announced over the Public Address System information regarding the legality of an apparent goal. If applicable, the Official Scorekeeper, with the assistance of the Video Review Consultant, will confirm the “goal scorer” and any Players deserving of an “assist”. (Rule 78 – Goals) The Referees shall have announced the reason for not allowing a goal every time the goal signal light is turned on in the course of play over the Public Address System. This shall be done at the first stoppage of play regardless of any standard signal given by the Referees when the goal signal light was put on in error (if the red goal light is mandatory and in place). The Referees shall report the name or number of the “goal scorer” and also report any Player deserving an “assist” for that goal. If applicable, the Referees shall report the “goal scorer” only and the Official Scorekeeper, with the assistance of the Statistic staff will confirm the “goal scorer” and any Player deserving an “assist”. The name of the “goal scorer” and any Player entitled to an “assist” will be announced over the Public Address System.
