paragraphs.context: The IIHF will designate an Off-ice Official to serve in the role of Video Review Consultant in every arena for every game. The Video Review Consultant will be located in a secluded area in the upper level of the building with an unobstructed view of both goals. The location must be large enough to seat four (4) people (Video Review Consultant, Video Review Technician, Officiating Coach and IIHF Officiating Representative) and must have space for necessary monitors, replay and recording equipment. The Video Review Consultant and Officiating Coach shall both have access to all replays that may be available from all available broadcasts of the game. The Video Review Consultant and Officiating Coach shall also be equipped with state-of-the-art communications systems that will allow direct and immediate access to the Off-ice Official(s) at the Penalty Box and the On-ice Official(s). ( » For more information refer to IIHF Technology Codes & Regulations.)

qas.question: Where is the designated location for the Video Review Consultant to be situated during a game?

answers.text: The designated location for the Video Review Consultant during a game is a secluded area in the upper level of the building with an unobstructed view of both goals, large enough to seat four people and equipped with necessary monitors and communication systems.

qas.question: How many people are allowed to be seated in the secluded area where the Video Review Consultant operates?

answers.text: The secluded area where the Video Review Consultant operates is allowed to seat four (4) people.

qas.question: Who are the individuals that have access to all replays available from the game broadcasts?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant and Officiating Coach have access to all replays available from the game broadcasts.

qas.question: What type of communications systems are the Video Review Consultant and Officiating Coach equipped with for immediate access to officials on and off the ice?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant and Officiating Coach are equipped with state-of-the-art communications systems for immediate access to officials on and off the ice.

qas.question: According to the rule, what specific equipment must be present in the location where the Video Review Consultant operates?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant's location must have seating for four people and space for monitors, replay, and recording equipment.

paragraphs.context: Every goal shall be reviewed by the Video Review Consultant. If there is a need to delay the resumption of the play following an apparent goal, the Off-Ice Official at ice level will be alerted to signal one of the Referees to delay the Center-ice “face-off” for a moment. Once the Video Review Consultant has reviewed the video and confirmed that the goal is valid, the Off-Ice Official at ice level should signal to the Referee to resume play. If an expanded review is required on any potential goal, the Video Review Consultant shall instruct that the in-arena horn be sounded and the Public Address Announcer will make an announcement that the “play is under review.” Once the play has been reviewed and deemed a goal, the goal will be announced in the normal manner. If the review reveals that the goal should be disallowed, the Referee shall announce the reason for the disallowed goal. When the Video Review Consultant observes an incident involving a potential goal that was undetected by the On-ice Officials, the Off-ice Official will contact the Referee at the first stoppage of play and inform them that a review of the play is in progress. When a video review is initiated, the Public Address Announcer will make an announcement that “the play is under review.” Should the Video Review Consultant be able to determine that a goal has been scored through the use of video replay, and play on the ice has nonetheless continued, the Video Review Consultant shall instruct that the in-arena horn be sounded to stop play immediately, and the goal will be awarded. Should the first stoppage of play following an apparent goal coincide with the end of a period, the On-ice Official(s) will instruct both Teams to remain at their respective Players’ Bench until the Video Review of the play can be completed. If the review reveals that the goal should be counted, the clock (including penalty time clocks, if applicable) shall be reset to the time the goal was scored. If the review reveals that no goal was scored, no adjustment to the time clock(s) will be made. Only one goal can be awarded at any stoppage of play. If  an  apparent goal was scored by Team A and is subsequently confirmed as a goal by Video Review,  any goal scored by Team B during the period of time between the apparent goal by Team A and the stoppage of play (Team B’s goal), the Team B goal will not be awarded. If the apparent goal by Team A is deemed to have entered the goal illegally (e.g., a “distinct kicking motion”), the goal will be disallowed. No goal will be awarded to Team B either in this circumstance since the play should have been stopped at the time of the apparent goal. The clock (including penalty time clocks, if applicable) shall be reset to the time of Team A’s apparent goal – whether awarded or disallowed. Any penalties signaled during the period of time between the apparent goal and the next stoppage of play shall be assessed in the normal manner, except when a Minor Penalty is to be assessed to the Team scored upon and is therefore nullified by the scoring of the goal – refer to (Rule 16.2. – Minor Penalties) (Rule 18.2. – Double-minor Penalties) If an infraction happens after the first stoppage of play following an apparent goal (infraction after the whistle) by either Team, it is assessed and served in the normal manner regardless as to the decision rendered by Video Review. When the Referee indicates there is a Video Review in progress, all Players (with the exception of the Goalkeepers) should proceed to their respective Players’ Bench immediately, and failure to do so may result in a Game Misconduct Penalty for offending Player(s) and shall be reported to the Proper Authorities. Any potential goal requiring Video Review must be reviewed prior to and/or during the next stoppage of play. No goal may be awarded (or disallowed) as a result of a Video Review once the play has resumed. The Video Review Consultant will connect directly with the Referee(s) at ice level to assist with the review of any close play or disputed goal. The On-ice Officials (Referees or Linespersons) decision shall be final. ( » For more information refer to IIHF Technology Codes & Regulations.)

qas.question: Who is responsible for reviewing every goal in a hockey game according to the rule context?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant is responsible for reviewing every goal in a hockey game.

qas.question: What action should the Off-Ice Official at ice level take if there is a need to delay play following an apparent goal?

answers.text: The Off-Ice Official at ice level should signal one of the Referees to delay the Center-ice "face-off" if there is a need to delay play following an apparent goal. Once the Video Review Consultant confirms the goal is valid, the Off-Ice Official should signal the Referee to resume play.

qas.question: How is the resumption of play signaled to the Referee once the Video Review Consultant confirms a valid goal?

answers.text: The resumption of play is signaled to the Referee by the Off-Ice Official at ice level once the Video Review Consultant confirms a valid goal.

qas.question: What should happen if the Video Review Consultant determines that a goal should be disallowed according to the rule context?

answers.text: If the Video Review Consultant determines that a goal should be disallowed, the Referee will announce the reason for the disallowed goal.

qas.question: What penalty may result for Players who fail to proceed to their respective Players’ Bench immediately when a Video Review is in progress, as per the rule context?

answers.text: Players who fail to proceed to their respective Players’ Bench immediately during a Video Review may receive a Game Misconduct Penalty.

paragraphs.context: The following situations are subject to Video Review: (I) Puck crossing the Goal Line (II) Puck in the net prior to the goal frame being dislodged or if the criteria’s for allowing a goal after a dislodged net is met. (III) Puck in the net prior to (or after) the expiration of time at the end of a period (IV) With the use of a foot/skate, a “distinct kicking motion” was evident (V) Puck deliberately directed, batted, or thrown into the net by an attacking Player by any means (and with any part of their body) other than with their stick – excl. foot/skate – see (IV) above. (VI) Puck deflected directly into the net of an On-ice Official (VII) Puck struck or deflected into the net with a high-stick, above the height of the crossbar (VIII) Puck entering the net in a proper manner through goal mouth (ensuring puck did not enter net improperly through net meshing or underneath the net frame, etc.) (IX) Puck entering the net as the culmination of a continuous play where the result of the play was unaffected by any whistle blown by the Referee upon their losing sight of the puck; and (X) The legitimacy of all potential goals on “Penalty Shot” or “Penalty Shot” Shootout attempts to ensure compliance with applicable rules (e.g., Goalkeeper leaving crease prior to puck touch at Center ice, Goalkeeper throwing stick, Goalkeeper dislodging goal, shooter cradling puck above the normal height of the shoulders, shooter performing illegal “spin-o-rama” move, Skater’s continued forward advancement of puck, “double-tap”/ “rebound”, etc.) The Coach's Challenge according to Rule 38 – Coach’s Challenge will only be used at selected IIHF Championships. Additional Video Review when Coach’s Challenge is not used: (XI) The Referees may review at their own discretion scoring plays involving potential “Interference on the Goalkeeper”. (Rule 69 – Interference on the Goalkeeper) ( » For more information regarding implementation of video review system refer to IIHF Event Codes.)

qas.question: What are the specific goal situations subject to Video Review according to the rule context?

answers.text: The specific goal situations subject to Video Review are: (I) Puck crossing the Goal Line, (II) Puck in the net before the goal frame is dislodged or if criteria for a goal after a dislodged net are met, (III) Puck in the net before or after the period ends, (IV) A distinct kicking motion with the foot/skate, (V) Puck deliberately directed into the net by any means other than the stick, (VI) Puck deflected into the net by an On-ice Official, (VII) Puck struck into the net with a high-stick, (VIII) Puck entering the net properly, (IX) Puck entering the net

qas.question: When can a goal be disallowed if the puck is in the net prior to the goal frame being dislodged?

answers.text: A goal can be disallowed if the puck is in the net prior to the goal frame being dislodged, subject to Video Review under the specified criteria.

qas.question: In what scenarios can a goal be reviewed if the puck enters the net before or after the expiration of time at the end of a period?

answers.text: A goal can be reviewed if the puck enters the net before or after the expiration of time at the end of a period.

qas.question: When is a goal subject to Video Review if a player uses their foot or skate to make a distinct kicking motion?

answers.text: A goal is subject to Video Review if a player uses their foot or skate to make a distinct kicking motion.

qas.question: Under what circumstances can a goal be reviewed if the puck is deliberately directed, batted, or thrown into the net by an attacking player using any part of their body other than their stick?

answers.text: A goal can be reviewed if the puck is deliberately directed, batted, or thrown into the net by an attacking player using any part of their body other than their stick, excluding the foot/skate, as per the Video Review rule (V).

paragraphs.context: Plays that involve a puck entering the net as a direct result of a “distinct kicking motion” shall be ruled “no goal”. A “distinct kicking motion,” for purposes of Video Review, is one where the video makes clear that an attacking Player has deliberately propelled the puck with a kick of their foot or skate and the puck subsequently enters the net.  A goal cannot be scored on a play where an attacking Player propels the puck with their skate into the net (even by means of a subsequent deflection off another Player, unless from a stick of a skater) using a “distinct kicking motion”. A goal also cannot be scored on a play where an attacking Player kicks any equipment (stick, glove, helmet, etc.) at the puck, including kicking the blade of their own stick, causing the puck to cross the Goal Line. A puck that deflects into the net off an attacking Player’s skate who does not use a “distinct kicking motion” shall be ruled a “good goal”. A puck that is directed into the net by an attacking Players’ skate shall also be ruled a “good goal”, as long as no “distinct kicking motion” is evident. (Rule 49.2. – Kicking / Goals)

qas.question: What is the ruling if a player deliberately propels the puck with a kick of their foot or skate into the net?

answers.text: If a player deliberately propels the puck with a kick of their foot or skate into the net, it shall be ruled as "no goal" due to a "distinct kicking motion."

qas.question: Can a goal be scored if an attacking player kicks any equipment at the puck, causing it to cross the Goal Line?

answers.text: No, a goal cannot be scored if an attacking player kicks any equipment at the puck, causing it to cross the Goal Line.

qas.question: When is a goal considered to be a "good goal" if the puck deflects into the net off an attacking player's skate?

answers.text: A goal is considered a "good goal" if the puck deflects into the net off an attacking player's skate without a distinct kicking motion.

qas.question: Is a goal allowed if a puck is directed into the net by an attacking player's skate without a distinct kicking motion?

answers.text: Yes, a goal is allowed if a puck is directed into the net by an attacking player's skate without a distinct kicking motion.

qas.question: How is a "distinct kicking motion" defined for the purpose of Video Review in hockey?

answers.text: A "distinct kicking motion" in hockey is defined as when a player deliberately propels the puck with a kick of their foot or skate, leading to the puck entering the net. This action results in the play being ruled as "no goal" during Video Review.

paragraphs.context: The determining factor for high stick Video Review is where the puck makes contact with the stick in relation to the crossbar. If the puck makes contact with a portion of the stick that is at or below the level of the crossbar (despite some other portion of the stick being above the crossbar) and enters the goal, the goal shall be allowed. (Rule 80.3. – High-sticking the Puck)

qas.question: What is the determining factor for a high stick Video Review in hockey?

answers.text: The determining factor for a high stick Video Review in hockey is whether the puck makes contact with a portion of the stick that is at or below the level of the crossbar when entering the goal.

qas.question: How is the level of the crossbar relevant in determining a high stick goal during a Video Review?

answers.text: The level of the crossbar is relevant in determining a high stick goal during a Video Review because if the puck makes contact with a portion of the stick that is at or below the level of the crossbar, the goal will be allowed, even if other parts of the stick are above the crossbar.

qas.question: If a portion of the stick is at or below the level of the crossbar, can a goal scored with that portion be allowed in a high stick situation?

answers.text: Yes, a goal scored with a portion of the stick at or below the level of the crossbar can be allowed in a high stick situation if the puck makes contact with that portion of the stick and enters the goal.

qas.question: According to the rule, what happens if the puck makes contact with a portion of the stick that is at or below the level of the crossbar and enters the goal?

answers.text: If the puck makes contact with a portion of the stick that is at or below the level of the crossbar and enters the goal, the goal shall be allowed.

qas.question: In a high stick Video Review, what is the specific condition under which a goal scored with a portion of the stick below the crossbar is allowed?

answers.text: A goal scored with a portion of the stick below the crossbar is allowed if the puck makes contact with that part of the stick, even if other parts of the stick are above the crossbar.

paragraphs.context: Video Review may be used to establish the correct time on the clock. Any loss of time on the game or penalty clocks due to a false “face-off”, a “face-off” violation or a puck going out of play must be replaced. The Video Review Consultant may be consulted or may intervene with Onand Off-Ice Officials directly, as appropriate, to ensure that any loss of time on the game or penalty clocks due to these situations is properly replaced. (Rule 76.8 – Face-off Procedure / Verification of Time) (Rule 85.7 – Puck Out of Bounds / Verification of Time) In the event of any dispute regarding time, the matter shall be referred to the Video Review Consultant for adjustment, and its decision shall be final. The Game Timekeeper shall assist to verify game time via an additional timing device (IIHF-approved stopwatch). In the event a Video Review shows that a goal was scored prior to the play being stopped, the Video Review Consultant will inform the Game Timekeeper and Official Scorekeeper of the time of the goal and the amount of playing time left to be re-set on the Game Clock and penalty time clocks (if applicable). (Rule 34.7 – Game Timekeeper / Verification of Time)

qas.question: When can Video Review be used to verify the correct time on the clock in a hockey game?

answers.text: Video Review can be used to verify the correct time on the clock in a hockey game when there is a dispute or loss of time due to a false face-off, face-off violation, or a puck going out of play.

qas.question: What situations may cause a loss of time on the game or penalty clocks that would require replacement according to the rule?

answers.text: Loss of time on the game or penalty clocks that require replacement include false face-offs, face-off violations, and pucks going out of play.

qas.question: Who has the authority to consult or intervene with On and Off-Ice Officials to ensure proper replacement of lost time on the clocks due to specific situations?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant has the authority to consult or intervene with On and Off-Ice Officials to ensure proper replacement of lost time on the clocks due to specific situations in hockey.

qas.question: How is a dispute regarding game time resolved according to the rule?

answers.text: A dispute regarding game time is resolved by referring the matter to the Video Review Consultant for adjustment, with their decision being final. The Game Timekeeper assists in verifying game time using an approved stopwatch.

qas.question: What action is taken by the Video Review Consultant if a goal is scored prior to the play being stopped, as shown by a Video Review?

answers.text: If a goal is scored prior to the play being stopped, the Video Review Consultant will inform the Game Timekeeper and Official Scorekeeper of the time of the goal and the amount of playing time left to be re-set on the Game Clock and penalty time clocks (if applicable).

paragraphs.context: In IIHF Championships where Video Review is not used, Goal Judges behind both nets shall be used. There shall be one Goal Judge situated behind each goal (or in an area designated and approved by the IIHF), in properly protected areas, if possible, so that there can be no interference with their activities. They shall not change goals during the game. The Goal Judge shall signal, normally by means of red light, a decision as to whether the puck passed between the Goal Posts and entirely over the Goal Line. The only decision the Goal Judge must make is whether the puck actually entered the net, not how or when it went in. The light must be illuminated for a period of five (5) seconds each time the puck enters the net regardless of circumstances. It is up to the Referee to make the final decision. ( » For more information refer to IIHF Technology Codes & Regulations.)

qas.question: What is the specific role of the Goal Judge behind the nets in IIHF Championships where Video Review is not available?

answers.text: The specific role of the Goal Judge behind the nets in IIHF Championships without Video Review is to signal with a red light whether the puck crossed the Goal Line and entered the net. They do not determine how or when the puck went in, and their decision is advisory, with the final call made by the Referee.

qas.question: How does the Goal Judge signal a decision regarding whether the puck crossed the Goal Line and entered the net?

answers.text: The Goal Judge signals a decision by illuminating a red light for five seconds when the puck passes between the Goal Posts and entirely over the Goal Line, indicating that the puck entered the net.

qas.question: What is the duration for which the red light must be illuminated by the Goal Judge each time the puck enters the net?

answers.text: The red light must be illuminated for a period of five (5) seconds each time the puck enters the net.

qas.question: Can the Goal Judge change goals during the game according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: No, the Goal Judge cannot change goals during the game according to IIHF Championships rules.

qas.question: Who has the final authority to make the decision regarding a goal when the Goal Judge signals that the puck has entered the net?

answers.text: The Referee has the final authority to make the decision regarding a goal when the Goal Judge signals that the puck has entered the net in IIHF Championships where Video Review is not used.

paragraphs.context: The Video Review mechanism triggered by the Coach’s Challenge can only be utilized in “good goal / no goal” situations and is intended to be extremely narrow in scope. In all Coach’s Challenge situations, the original call on the ice will be overturned if, and only if, a conclusive and irrefutable determination can be made on the basis of video evidence that the original call on the ice was clearly not correct. If a review is not conclusive and/or there is any doubt whatsoever as to whether the call on the ice was correct, the original call on the ice will be confirmed. ( » For more information refer to IIHF Technology Codes & Regulations.)

qas.question: In what specific situations can the Video Review mechanism be triggered by a Coach's Challenge according to the rule?

answers.text: The Video Review mechanism triggered by a Coach's Challenge can only be used in "good goal / no goal" situations.

qas.question: What is the intended scope of the Video Review mechanism triggered by the Coach's Challenge, as stated in the rule?

answers.text: The Video Review mechanism triggered by the Coach's Challenge is limited to "good goal / no goal" situations and aims to overturn the original call only if conclusive evidence proves it was clearly incorrect.

qas.question: Under what conditions will the original call on the ice be overturned in a Coach's Challenge situation, based on the rule?

answers.text: The original call on the ice will only be overturned in a Coach's Challenge situation if conclusive and irrefutable video evidence shows that the call was clearly incorrect.

qas.question: What criteria must be met for a conclusive and irrefutable determination to be made in order to overturn the original call on the ice in a Coach's Challenge scenario?

answers.text: For a conclusive and irrefutable determination to overturn the original call on the ice in a Coach's Challenge scenario, the video evidence must clearly show that the original call was incorrect. If there is any doubt or lack of clear evidence, the original call will be confirmed.

qas.question: How is the original call on the ice handled if a review is inconclusive or if there is any doubt regarding its correctness in a Coach's Challenge situation, according to the rule?

answers.text: If a review is inconclusive or there is doubt regarding the original call on the ice in a Coach's Challenge situation, the original call on the ice will be confirmed according to the rule.

paragraphs.context: A Team may only request a Coach’s Challenge to review the following scenarios: (I) “Off-side”-Play Leading to a Goal A play that results in a “goal” call on the ice where the defending Team claims that the play should have been stopped by reason of an “Off-side” infraction by the attacking Team. (Rule 83 – Off-side) (II) Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Attacking Zone Leading to a Goal A play that results in a “goal” call on the ice where the defending Team claims that the play should have been stopped by reason of any play occurring in the Attacking Zone that should have resulted in a play stoppage caused by the attacking Team but did not. The one exception to this provision is when the puck is played out from the playing area by either team and goes unnoticed by the on-ice officials; (III) Scoring Plays Involving Potential “Interference on the Goalkeeper” Either: (1) A play that results in a “goal” call on the ice where the defending Team claims that the goal should have been disallowed due to “Interference on the Goalkeeper” (Rule 69 – Interference on the Goalkeeper;) or (2) A play that results in a “no goal” call on the ice despite the puck having entered the net, where the On-ice Officials have determined that the attacking Team was guilty of “Interference on the Goalkeeper” but where the attacking Team claims: • There was no actual contact of any kind initiated by an attacking Player with the Goalkeeper; • The attacking Player was pushed, shoved or fouled by a defending Player which caused the attacking Player to come into contact with the Goalkeeper; or • The attacking Player’s positioning within the Goal Crease did not impair the Goalkeeper’s ability to defend their goal and, in fact, had no discernable impact on the play.

qas.question: What specific scenarios can a Team request a Coach’s Challenge to review according to the rule on SITUATIONS SUBJECT TO COACH’S CHALLENGE?

answers.text: A Team can request a Coach’s Challenge to review scenarios involving: (I) an "Off-side" infraction leading to a goal, (II) a missed game stoppage event in the attacking zone leading to a goal, and (III) scoring plays involving potential "Interference on the Goalkeeper."

qas.question: In what situation can a Team challenge a play that resulted in a “goal” call due to an alleged “Off-side” infraction by the attacking Team?

answers.text: A Team can challenge a play resulting in a "goal" call due to an alleged "Off-side" infraction by the attacking Team.

qas.question: When can a Team challenge a play that led to a “goal” call because of a missed game stoppage event in the Attacking Zone caused by the attacking Team?

answers.text: A Team can challenge a play that led to a "goal" call due to a missed game stoppage event in the Attacking Zone caused by the attacking Team, except when the puck is played out from the playing area unnoticed by the officials.

qas.question: Under what circumstances can a Team challenge a scoring play involving potential “Interference on the Goalkeeper” according to the rule?

answers.text: A Team can challenge a scoring play involving potential "Interference on the Goalkeeper" when they believe the goal should have been disallowed due to interference on the goalkeeper, as outlined in Rule 69.

qas.question: What are the exceptions to the provision allowing a Team to challenge a play where the puck is played out from the playing area and goes unnoticed by the on-ice officials?

answers.text: The exception to challenging a play where the puck is played out from the playing area and goes unnoticed by the on-ice officials is when the defending Team claims that the play should have been stopped due to an infraction in the Attacking Zone that was missed by the officials.

paragraphs.context: All Coach’s Challenges must be initiated by notice verbally communicated to a Referee prior to the Center ice “face-off” following a “goal” or, in the case of a “no goal” call by reason of “Interference on the Goalkeeper,” prior to the resumption of play. Teams may not unduly delay the resumption of play while evaluating whether or not to initiate a Coach’s Challenge. Any such delay or delay tactics may result in the denial of a right to Challenge and, at the discretion of the Referee, may also result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delaying the Game”. (Rule 63 – Delaying the Game) In order to expedite the review process, Coaches initiating a Coach’s Challenge are required to provide to the Referee, with reasonable specificity, both the reason for their Coach’s Challenge (i.e., the actual infraction that is being claimed) and the approximate time on the clock when the purported infraction transpired. Failure to provide this information with reasonable specificity may result in the denial of a right to a Coach’s Challenge. Only one Coach’s Challenge per Team per stoppage will be permitted.

qas.question: When must a Coach’s Challenge be initiated according to the rule?

answers.text: A Coach's Challenge must be initiated by verbally notifying a Referee before the next center ice face-off following a goal or before play resumes after a no-goal call due to interference on the goalkeeper. Teams must not delay play excessively when deciding to challenge, or they risk losing the right to challenge and may receive a Bench Minor Penalty for Delaying the Game.

qas.question: What action may result if a team unduly delays the resumption of play while considering a Coach’s Challenge?

answers.text: Unduly delaying the resumption of play while considering a Coach's Challenge may result in the denial of the right to challenge and potentially a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delaying the Game."

qas.question: What information must a Coach provide to the Referee when initiating a Coach’s Challenge?

answers.text: A Coach must provide the Referee with the reason for the challenge (specific infraction claimed) and the approximate time on the clock when the incident occurred when initiating a Coach's Challenge in hockey.

qas.question: How many Coach’s Challenges are teams allowed per stoppage?

answers.text: Teams are allowed one Coach’s Challenge per stoppage.

qas.question: What potential penalty could a team face for delaying the game while evaluating whether to initiate a Coach’s Challenge?

answers.text: A team could face a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delaying the Game" if they unduly delay the resumption of play while evaluating whether to initiate a Coach’s Challenge.

paragraphs.context: The IIHF Technology Department in cooperation with the Organizer will make available in all arenas suitable technology (for example, a handheld tablet or a television or computer monitor) that will allow the On-ice Officials, in conjunction with the Video Review Consultant, to review video replays of the play giving rise to the Coach’s Challenge. To the extent practical and possible, the replays made available to the On-ice Officials will be the same replays that are being utilized by the Video Review Consultant. Once a Coach’s Challenge has been initiated, the Video Review Consultant will immediately establish contact with the On-ice Official(s) responsible for the call (or non-call) on the ice via the headset and will inquire and discuss with the On-ice Official(s), prior to the On-ice Official reviewing any video, the following: (I) the On-ice Official’s “final call on the ice”; and (II) what the On-ice Official(s) observed on the play. The Video Review Consultant will be involved both in communicating with the On-ice Officials via the headset and with providing input to the On-ice Officials (Referees and Linespersons). The On-ice Officials are responsible for making the “final” decision. The “on-ice call” will then be reviewed simultaneously by the appropriate On-ice Official(s) at ice level and by the Video Review Consultant using any and all replays at their disposal. After their joint review and consultation, the On-ice Officials (Referees or Linespersons) will render the decision on whether to uphold or overturn the original “call on the ice”. Once a decision is made, the Referee will inform the Penalty Timekeeper/Public Address Announcer and will make the announcement on the ice.

qas.question: Who is responsible for making the final decision after a Coach's Challenge has been initiated?

answers.text: The On-ice Officials are responsible for making the final decision after a Coach's Challenge has been initiated in hockey.

qas.question: What technology is made available in all arenas for the On-ice Officials to review video replays during a Coach's Challenge?

answers.text: Handheld tablets or television/computer monitors are made available in all arenas for On-ice Officials to review video replays during a Coach's Challenge.

qas.question: Prior to reviewing any video replays, what information does the Video Review Consultant discuss with the On-ice Official(s) responsible for the call?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant discusses the On-ice Official's "final call on the ice" and what the On-ice Official observed on the play before reviewing any video replays.

qas.question: How is the decision on whether to uphold or overturn the original call made after a Coach's Challenge?

answers.text: The decision on whether to uphold or overturn the original call after a Coach's Challenge is made jointly by the On-ice Officials (Referees or Linespersons) and the Video Review Consultant following a review of all available replays.

qas.question: What is the process for communication between the Video Review Consultant and the On-ice Officials during a Coach's Challenge review?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant communicates with the On-ice Officials via headset to discuss the final call on the ice and observations before reviewing video replays. The On-ice Officials make the final decision on whether to uphold or overturn the call after a joint review with the Video Review Consultant.

paragraphs.context: Teams may initiate a Coach’s Challenge on appropriate plays at any time during the game.

qas.question: When can teams initiate a Coach's Challenge during a hockey game?

answers.text: Teams can initiate a Coach's Challenge at any time during a hockey game.

qas.question: What type of plays are considered appropriate for a Coach's Challenge according to the rule?

answers.text: Answer: Teams can use a Coach's Challenge for appropriate plays at any point in the game.

qas.question: Is there a specific time limit within which teams must initiate a Coach's Challenge?

answers.text: Teams can initiate a Coach's Challenge at any time during the game.

qas.question: Who has the authority to decide whether a play is appropriate for a Coach's Challenge?

answers.text: The team's coach has the authority to decide whether a play is appropriate for a Coach's Challenge.

qas.question: Can a Coach's Challenge be initiated by a team at any point during the game, regardless of the score or period?

answers.text: Yes, a Coach's Challenge can be initiated by a team at any point during the game, regardless of the score or period.

paragraphs.context: In cases where a Challenge has been initiated for an “Off-side-Play Leading to a Goal” or a “Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Offensive Zone Leading to a Goal”, and a determination is made that the GOAL call on the ice should be overturned, the goal will be disallowed and the clock will be re-set to the time at which the play should have been stopped for the missed infraction. In such cases, a “face-off” will ensue in the ice location where it would have otherwise occurred had the on-ice infraction been called properly. If one or more penalties (Minor or Major) are assessed between the time of the missed infraction and the Video Review that disallows the apparent goal, the offending Team(s) (and responsible Player(s)) will still be required to serve the penalty(ies) identified and assessed, and the time of the penalty(ies) will be recorded as the time at which the play should have been stopped for the missed infraction. In cases where a Challenge has been initiated for a “goal” call on the ice where the defending Team claims that the goal should have been disallowed due to the “Interference on the Goalkeeper,” as described in (Rule 69 – Interference on the Goalkeeper) and a determination is made that the “call on the ice” should be overturned, the goal will be disallowed, and a “face-off” will ensue in the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone. The Video Review process on these plays will be utilized exclusively for purposes of overturning a “goal” call on the ice – it will not be utilized for any other purpose, including, specifically, for assessing Minor or Major Penalties for Goalkeeper Interference. In cases where a Challenge has been initiated for a “no goal” call on the ice despite the puck having entered the net, where the On-ice Officials have determined that the attacking Team was guilty of “Interference on the Goalkeeper,” and a determination is made that the “call on the ice” should be overturned, the goal will be allowed an  a “face-off” will ensue at Center ice. (Rule 69 – Interference on the Goalkeeper) If a penalty for “Interference on a Goalkeeper” was indicated and based on the Video Review, no such action was committed by the attacking Player, no penalty shall be assessed for such an infraction. All other penalties not related to “Interference on a Goalkeeper” should be assessed and served in a normal manner. On the other hand, penalties not indicated cannot be assessed due to the Video Review.

qas.question: What happens if a Coach's Challenge is successful for an "Off-side-Play Leading to a Goal" or a "Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Offensive Zone Leading to a Goal"?

answers.text: If a Coach's Challenge is successful for an "Off-side-Play Leading to a Goal" or a "Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Offensive Zone Leading to a Goal," the goal will be disallowed, the clock will be reset to the time of the missed infraction, and a face-off will occur at the appropriate location. Any penalties assessed during that time will still be enforced, with the penalty time recorded as when the infraction should have been called.

qas.question: How is a goal affected if a Coach's Challenge is initiated for a "goal" call due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper" and the call on the ice is overturned?

answers.text: If a Coach's Challenge is initiated for a "goal" call due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper" and the call on the ice is overturned, the goal will be disallowed, and a face-off will occur in the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone. The Video Review process is solely used to overturn the "goal" call and not for assessing penalties for Goalkeeper Interference.

qas.question: What is the procedure for a face-off if a Coach's Challenge results in a disallowed goal due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper"?

answers.text: If a Coach's Challenge results in a disallowed goal due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper," a face-off will occur in the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone.

qas.question: If a penalty is assessed between the missed infraction and the Video Review that disallows a goal, what action must the offending Team(s) and responsible Player(s) take?

answers.text: If a penalty is assessed between a missed infraction and a Video Review that disallows a goal, the offending Team(s) and responsible Player(s) must still serve the penalty(ies) identified and assessed. The time of the penalty(ies) will be recorded as the time at which the play should have been stopped for the missed infraction.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Video Review process in cases where a Coach's Challenge is initiated for a "no goal" call despite the puck entering the net due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper"?

answers.text: The purpose of the Video Review process in cases where a Coach's Challenge is initiated for a "no goal" call due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper" is to determine if the call on the ice should be overturned. If the call is overturned, the goal will be allowed, and a face-off will occur at Center ice.

paragraphs.context: If a Team initiates a Coach’s Challenge for any of the enumerated scenarios in Rule 38.2 above and such Challenge does not result in the “final call on the ice” being overturned, the Team exercising such Challenge shall be assessed a Bench Minor Penalty (2 minutes) for Delaying the Game. If a Team that has already initiated one or more Coach’s Challenges that were unsuccessful, initiates a Coach’s Challenge for any of the enumerated scenarios in Rule 38.2 above and such Challenge does not result in the original call on the ice being overturned, the Team exercising such a Coach’s Challenge shall be assessed a Double-Bench Minor Penalty (4 minutes) for Delaying the Game. Note: If a situation cannot be reviewed by the on-ice officials due to a technical error (e.g. a "black screen"), the "final call on the ice" will stand. In this case, the Coach's Challenge will be considered “unsuccessful” but no Bench Minor Penalty will be assessed on the team that initiated the challenge

qas.question: What penalty is assessed to a Team if their Coach's Challenge does not result in the "final call on the ice" being overturned?

answers.text: If a Team's Coach's Challenge does not result in the "final call on the ice" being overturned, the Team will be assessed a Bench Minor Penalty (2 minutes) for Delaying the Game.

qas.question: How long is the Bench Minor Penalty for Delaying the Game if a Team's Coach's Challenge is unsuccessful?

answers.text: The Bench Minor Penalty for Delaying the Game if a Team's Coach's Challenge is unsuccessful is 2 minutes.

qas.question: What happens if a Team initiates a Coach's Challenge for the second time and it is unsuccessful in overturning the original call on the ice?

answers.text: If a Team initiates a Coach's Challenge for the second time and it is unsuccessful in overturning the original call on the ice, the Team will be assessed a Double-Bench Minor Penalty (4 minutes) for Delaying the Game.

qas.question: How is a Double-Bench Minor Penalty different from a regular Bench Minor Penalty in the context of a Coach's Challenge?

answers.text: A Double-Bench Minor Penalty is different from a regular Bench Minor Penalty in a Coach's Challenge because it results in a 4-minute penalty for Delaying the Game, while a regular Bench Minor Penalty is only 2 minutes.

qas.question: Under what circumstances will a Team not be assessed a Bench Minor Penalty for Delaying the Game even if their Coach's Challenge is unsuccessful?

answers.text: A Team will not be assessed a Bench Minor Penalty for Delaying the Game if their Coach's Challenge is unsuccessful due to a technical error preventing the on-ice officials from reviewing the situation.

paragraphs.context: The standard for overturning the call in the event of a “goal” call on the ice is that the On-ice Officials (Linespersons), after reviewing any and all available replays and consulting with the Video Review Consultant, determine that one or more Players on the attacking Team preceded the puck into the Attacking Zone prior to the goal being scored and that, as a result, the play should have been stopped for an “Off-side” infraction; where this standard is met, the goal will be disallowed. Goals will only be subject to review for a potential “Off-side” infraction if the puck does not come out of the Attacking Zone again between the time of the “Off-side” infraction and the time the goal is scored.

qas.question: What is the standard for overturning a "goal" call on the ice in the case of an "Off-side" challenge?

answers.text: To overturn a "goal" call due to an "Off-side" challenge, the standard is that the attacking team's players must have entered the Attacking Zone before the puck, leading to the goal being scored. If this is confirmed by the on-ice officials and video review, the goal will be disallowed.

qas.question: Who is responsible for determining if one or more Players on the attacking Team preceded the puck into the Attacking Zone prior to a goal being scored?

answers.text: The On-ice Officials, after reviewing replays and consulting with the Video Review Consultant, are responsible for determining if one or more Players on the attacking Team preceded the puck into the Attacking Zone prior to a goal being scored.

qas.question: When will a goal be disallowed based on an "Off-side" infraction according to the applicable standards for a coach's challenge?

answers.text: A goal will be disallowed based on an "Off-side" infraction if one or more attacking players precede the puck into the Attacking Zone before the goal is scored, and the play should have been stopped for off-side.

qas.question: Under what circumstances will goals be subject to review for a potential "Off-side" infraction?

answers.text: Goals will be subject to review for a potential "Off-side" infraction if one or more attacking players precede the puck into the Attacking Zone before the goal is scored, and if the puck does not leave the Attacking Zone again before the goal is scored.

qas.question: What must happen between the time of the "Off-side" infraction and the time the goal is scored for the goal to be subject to review for an "Off-side" infraction?

answers.text: For a goal to be subject to review for an "Off-side" infraction, the puck must not exit the Attacking Zone again between the time of the infraction and the goal being scored.

paragraphs.context: The standard for overturning the call in the event of a “goal” call on the ice is that the On-ice Officials (Referees), after reviewing any and all available replays and consulting with the Video Review Consultant determine that the play should have been stopped for a event caused by the attacking team, but was not at some point after the puck entered the Attacking Zone but prior to the goal being scored; where this standard is met, the goal will be disallowed. Potential infractions that would require a play stoppage in the Attacking Zone by the attacking team, includes but may not be limited to: (Rule 79 – Hand Pass;) (Rule 80 – High-sticking the Puck; and) (Rule 85 – Puck Out of Bounds) . Such infractions will only serve as a basis for overturning a “goal” call on the ice if Video Review can conclusively establish that a game stoppage event had occurred in the Attacking Zone and was missed by the On-ice Official(s). Where the infraction at issue was a missed penalty call subject to the judgment or discretion of the On-ice Official(s), such infraction cannot result in the “goal” call on the ice being overturned, even if upon review, the On-ice Official(s) would have made a different call. Goals will only be reviewed for a potential “Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Attacking Zone” if the puck does not come out of the Attacking Zone again between the time of the “Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Attacking Zone” and the time the goal is scored.

qas.question: What is the standard for overturning a "goal" call on the ice in the event of a "Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Attacking Zone" challenge?

answers.text: To overturn a "goal" call on the ice due to a "Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Attacking Zone" challenge, the On-ice Officials must determine that an infraction by the attacking team in the Attacking Zone went unnoticed and should have stopped play before the goal was scored. This includes infractions like hand passes, high-sticking the puck, or the puck going out of bounds. The goal will be disallowed only if video review conclusively shows that a game stoppage event was missed by the officials.

qas.question: Which potential infractions in the Attacking Zone by the attacking team could lead to a play stoppage and potentially result in a goal being disallowed?

answers.text: Potential infractions in the Attacking Zone by the attacking team that could lead to a play stoppage and potentially result in a goal being disallowed include hand pass, high-sticking the puck, and puck going out of bounds.

qas.question: When will an infraction that was a missed penalty call not result in a "goal" call on the ice being overturned, according to the rule?

answers.text: An infraction that was a missed penalty call will not result in a "goal" call on the ice being overturned if the missed penalty call is subject to the judgment or discretion of the On-ice Official(s).

qas.question: Under what circumstances will goals be reviewed for a potential "Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Attacking Zone"?

answers.text: Goals will be reviewed for a potential "Missed Game Stoppage Event in the Attacking Zone" if the attacking team commits an infraction that should have stopped play, such as a hand pass, high-sticking the puck, or the puck going out of bounds, between the time the puck enters the Attacking Zone and the goal being scored.

qas.question: What must Video Review conclusively establish in order for an infraction to serve as a basis for overturning a "goal" call on the ice?

answers.text: Video Review must conclusively establish that a game stoppage event caused by the attacking team was missed by the On-ice Officials in the Attacking Zone between the puck entering and the goal being scored in order to overturn a "goal" call on the ice.

paragraphs.context: The standard for overturning the call in the event of a “goal” call on the ice is that the On-ice Officials (Referees), after reviewing any and all replays and consulting with the Video Review Consultant, determine that the goal should have been disallowed due to “Interference on the Goalkeeper,” as described in (Rule 69 – – Interference on the Goalkeeper;) where this standard is met, the goal will be disallowed. The standard for overturning the call in the event of a “no goal” call on the ice is that the On-ice Officials (Referees), after reviewing any and all replays and consulting with the Video Review Consultant, determine that the goal on the ice should have been allowed because either: (I) There was no actual contact of any kind initiated by the attacking Player with the Goalkeeper; or (II) The attacking Player was pushed, shoved or fouled by the defending Player causing the attacking Player to come into contact with the Goalkeeper; or (III) The attacking Player’s positioning within the Goal Crease did not impair the Goalkeeper’s ability to defend their goal and, in fact, had no discernable impact on the play; where this standard is met, the goal will be allowed.

qas.question: What is the standard for overturning a "goal" call on the ice due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper" as outlined in the COACH’S CHALLENGE rule?

answers.text: To overturn a "goal" call on the ice due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper" as outlined in the COACH’S CHALLENGE rule, the standard is that the On-ice Officials must determine, after reviewing replays and consulting with the Video Review Consultant, that the goal should have been disallowed according to Rule 69 – Interference on the Goalkeeper.

qas.question: According to the applicable standards for a potential "Interference on the Goalkeeper" challenge, what must the On-ice Officials determine in order to disallow a goal that was called on the ice?

answers.text: To disallow a goal called on the ice due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper," the On-ice Officials must determine that the goal should have been disallowed based on the criteria outlined in Rule 69 - Interference on the Goalkeeper.

qas.question: In the context of a "no goal" call on the ice, what criteria must be met for the On-ice Officials to overturn the call and allow the goal to stand?

answers.text: For the On-ice Officials to overturn a "no goal" call and allow the goal to stand, they must determine that there was no contact initiated by the attacking player with the goalkeeper, or that the attacking player was pushed, shoved, or fouled by the defending player leading to contact with the goalkeeper, or that the attacking player's positioning did not impair the goalkeeper's ability to defend the goal.

qas.question: How do the On-ice Officials and the Video Review Consultant collaborate to make a decision regarding a potential "Interference on the Goalkeeper" challenge?

answers.text: The On-ice Officials and the Video Review Consultant collaborate by reviewing replays and consulting to determine if a goal should be disallowed due to "Interference on the Goalkeeper" based on Rule 69.

qas.question: According to the details provided, what are the specific scenarios in which a goal that was initially waved off as "no goal" could be allowed after review in relation to the attacking Player's actions?

answers.text: A goal initially waved off as "no goal" could be allowed after review if: (I) There was no contact initiated by the attacking Player with the Goalkeeper; (II) The attacking Player was pushed, shoved, or fouled by the defending Player into the Goalkeeper; or (III) The attacking Player's positioning in the Goal Crease did not affect the Goalkeeper's ability to defend.

paragraphs.context: A Player, Coach or team personnel shall not challenge or dispute the rulings of an Official before, during or after a game, on or off the ice and any location while in the arena and its connected premises. A Player, Coach or team personnel shall not display “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” including, but not limited to, obscene, profane or abusive language or gestures, comments of a personal nature intended to degrade an Official or persist in disputing a ruling after being told to stop or after being penalized for such behavior. Note: When such conduct is directed at any one other than an official, (Rule 75 – Unsportsmanlike Conduct) shall be applied.

qas.question: Can a Player challenge or dispute the rulings of an Official during a game?

answers.text: No, a Player cannot challenge or dispute the rulings of an Official during a game.

qas.question: What type of conduct is considered "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" towards an Official according to the rule?

answers.text: "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" towards an Official includes challenging or disputing rulings, using obscene language or gestures, making personal degrading comments, and persisting in disputing a ruling after being warned or penalized.

qas.question: Is it permissible for a Coach to use obscene language towards an Official off the ice in the arena premises?

answers.text: No, it is not permissible for a Coach to use obscene language towards an Official off the ice in the arena premises.

qas.question: What should a Player do if they are told to stop disputing a ruling by an Official?

answers.text: If a Player is told to stop disputing a ruling by an Official, they should comply immediately and refrain from persisting in challenging the decision.

qas.question: How should team personnel behave towards an Official after being penalized for disputing a ruling?

answers.text: Team personnel should show respect towards an Official after being penalized for disputing a ruling by refraining from challenging or displaying unsportsmanlike conduct, including obscene language or gestures, personal degrading comments, or persisting in disputing the ruling.

paragraphs.context: A Minor Penalty for “Unsportmanslike Conduct – Abuse of Officials” shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) Any Player who challenges or disputes the ruling of an Official. Any identifiable Player who uses obscene, profane or abusive language or gestures directed at any Onor Off-ice official. Note: An additional Game Misconduct Penalty for use of obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks (Rule 39.5 – Game Misconduct Penalty) (II) Any Player or Players who bang the Boards or glass with their sticks or other objects at any time, or who, in any manner show disrespect for an Official’s decision. If this is done in order to get the attention of the On-ice Officials for a legitimate reason (i.e.  serious injury, illness, etc.), then discretion must be exercised by the Referees. (III) When a Captain, Alternate Captain or any other Player comes off the Players’ Bench to question or protest a ruling by an Official on the ice. (IV) If a Player bangs the Boards or glass in protest of an Off-ice Official’s ruling. (V) If a penalized Player is assessed an additional “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” penalty either before or after they begins serving their original penalty(ies), the additional Minor Penalty is added to their unexpired time and served consecutively. (VI) If a penalized Player does not go directly to the Penalty Box or Dressing Room as instructed by an On-ice Official.

qas.question: What specific actions can result in a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials" according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: Actions that can result in a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials" include challenging or disputing an official's ruling, using obscene language or gestures towards officials, banging the boards or glass in disrespect, leaving the bench to protest a ruling, and failing to follow instructions to go to the penalty box or dressing room.

qas.question: When can a Player be assessed a Minor Penalty for using obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures directed at any On or Off-ice official?

answers.text: A Player can be assessed a Minor Penalty for using obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures directed at any On or Off-ice official when they challenge or dispute the ruling of an Official or show disrespect for an Official's decision.

qas.question: Under what circumstances can a Player bang the Boards or glass with their sticks without being penalized for showing disrespect for an Official's decision?

answers.text: A Player can bang the Boards or glass with their sticks without being penalized for showing disrespect for an Official's decision if it is done to get the attention of the On-ice Officials for a legitimate reason, such as a serious injury or illness.

qas.question: What is the consequence for a Captain, Alternate Captain, or any other Player who comes off the Players' Bench to question or protest a ruling by an Official on the ice?

answers.text: The consequence for a Captain, Alternate Captain, or any other Player who comes off the Players' Bench to question or protest a ruling by an Official on the ice is a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials."

qas.question: How is an additional "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" penalty handled if a penalized Player is assessed one before or after they begin serving their original penalty(ies)?

answers.text: If a penalized Player is assessed an additional "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" penalty before or after they begin serving their original penalty(ies), the additional Minor Penalty is added to their unexpired time and served consecutively.

paragraphs.context: A Bench Minor Penalty for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials” shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) Any Coach or team personnel who bangs the Boards or glass with a stick or other object at any time, showing disrespect for an Official’s decision. If this is done in order to get the attention of the On-ice Officials for a legitimate reason (i.e. serious injury, illness, etc.), then discretion must be exercised by the Referees. (II) Any Player, Coach, or team personnel interferes in any manner with any Game Official including the Referees, Linespersons, Game or Penalty Timekeepers or Goal Judges in the performance of their duties. (III) Any Player, Coach, or non-playing person misuses technology (tablet, etc.) to challenge a Game Officials decision.

qas.question: What specific actions can result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials" according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: Actions that can result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials" include banging the boards or glass to show disrespect for an official's decision, interfering with any game official, and misusing technology to challenge a game official's decision.

qas.question: When can a Coach or team personnel bang the Boards or glass with a stick or other object without being assessed a Bench Minor Penalty for disrespecting an Official's decision?

answers.text: A Coach or team personnel can bang the Boards or glass with a stick or other object without being assessed a Bench Minor Penalty if it is done to get the attention of the On-ice Officials for a legitimate reason, such as a serious injury or illness. Referees must use discretion in such cases.

qas.question: Who can be penalized with a Bench Minor Penalty for interfering with Game Officials in the performance of their duties, as outlined in the rule context?

answers.text: Players, coaches, or team personnel can be penalized with a Bench Minor Penalty for interfering with Game Officials in the performance of their duties.

qas.question: In what situation would the Referees need to exercise discretion when a Coach or team personnel bangs the Boards or glass with a stick or other object?

answers.text: The Referees would need to exercise discretion when a Coach or team personnel bangs the Boards or glass with a stick or other object to get the attention of the On-ice Officials for a legitimate reason, such as a serious injury or illness.

qas.question: How can a Player, Coach, or non-playing person misuse technology to challenge a Game Official's decision and be subject to a Bench Minor Penalty according to the rule context?

answers.text: A Player, Coach, or non-playing person can be subject to a Bench Minor Penalty for misusing technology, such as a tablet, to challenge a Game Official's decision according to the rule context.

paragraphs.context: Misconduct Penalties for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials” shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) Any Player who persists in the use of obscene, profane or abusive language towards any Onor Off-ice official for which they has already been assessed a Minor Penalty. Note: A Game Misconduct Penalty for use of obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks (Rule 39.5 – Game Misconduct Penalty) (II) Any Player who intentionally knocks or shoots the puck out of the reach of an Official who is retrieving it. (III) Any Player who, after being assessed a Minor Penalty for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct”, persists in challenging or disputing the ruling of an Official. (IV) Any Player or Players who bang the Boards or glass with their sticks or other objects at any time, showing disrespect for an Official’s decision, for which they have already been assessed a Minor or Bench Minor Penalty for “Unsportmanslike Conduct”. (V) Any Player or Players who, except for the purpose of taking their positions in the Penalty Box, enter or remain in the Referee’s Crease while they are reporting to or consulting with any Game Official including the other Referee, the Linespersons, Game Timekeeper, Penalty Timekeeper, Official Scorekeeper or Public Address System Announcer. (VI) A Misconduct Penalty (or Game Misconduct Penalty at the discretion of the Referee) shall be imposed on any Player who deliberately throws any equipment out of the playing area. When this is done in protest of an official’s ruling, a Minor Penalty plus a Game Misconduct Penalty shall be assessed (Rule 39.5 – Game Misconduct Penalty) (VII) Any Player who, after previously being assessed a Minor Penalty for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” for banging the Boards or glass in protest of an Off-ice Official’s ruling. (VIII) In general, participants displaying this type of behavior are assessed a Minor Penalty, then a Misconduct Penalty and then a Game Misconduct Penalty if they persist.

qas.question: What type of penalties are assessed for persisting in the use of obscene, profane, or abusive language towards an on or off-ice official after already receiving a Minor Penalty?

answers.text: Persisting in the use of obscene, profane, or abusive language towards an on or off-ice official after already receiving a Minor Penalty can result in a Misconduct Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials."

qas.question: What penalty is given to a player who intentionally knocks or shoots the puck out of the reach of an official who is retrieving it?

answers.text: A player who intentionally knocks or shoots the puck out of the reach of an official who is retrieving it will receive a Misconduct Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials."

qas.question: What penalty is imposed on a player who persists in challenging or disputing the ruling of an official after being assessed a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct"?

answers.text: A player who persists in challenging or disputing the ruling of an official after being assessed a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" will receive a Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: What penalty is given to players who bang the boards or glass with their sticks or other objects in protest of an official's decision after already receiving a Minor or Bench Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct"?

answers.text: Players who bang the boards or glass with their sticks or other objects in protest of an official's decision after already receiving a Minor or Bench Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" will be given a Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: What penalty is imposed on players who enter or remain in the Referee's Crease while reporting to or consulting with any game official, except for the purpose of taking their positions in the Penalty Box?

answers.text: Players who enter or remain in the Referee's Crease while reporting to or consulting with any game official, except for taking their positions in the Penalty Box, will receive a Misconduct Penalty.

paragraphs.context: Game Misconduct Penalties for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct – Abuse of Officials” shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) Any Player who, after being assessed a Misconduct Penalty, persists in challenging or disputing the ruling of an Official. (II) When a Coach or non-playing Team Personnel uses obscene, profane or abusive language or gesture directed at any On or Off-ice Official or uses the name of any Official coupled with any vociferous remarks, after already being assessed a Bench Minor Penalty (Rule 39.3 (ii)), this Coach or non-playing Team Personnel is to be assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty and the situation reported to the Proper Authorities for further action. When this type of conduct occurs by any player, coach or non-playing team personnel after the expiration of the game, on or off the ice, the Game Misconduct shall be applied without the necessity of having been assessed a Penalty for ”Unsportsmanlike Conduct” previously in the game. (III) Any Player who deliberately applies physical force in any manner against an Official, in any manner, where such actions were likely to cause injury to the latter to an Official, physically demeans, or deliberately applies physical force to an Official solely for the purpose of getting free of such an Official during or immediately following an altercation shall receive a Game Misconduct Penalty and the guidelines set out in (Rule 40 – Physical Abuse of Officials) are to be applied. (IV) Any Player who, having entered the Penalty Box, leaves the Penalty Box prior to the expiration of their penalty for the purpose of challenging an Official’s ruling, shall be assessed. This rule does not replace any other more severe penalty that may be imposed for leaving the Penalty Box for the purpose of starting or participating in an altercation. (Rule 70 – Leaving the Players Bench or Penalty Box) (VI) Any Player, Coach or team personnel who throws or shoots any equipment or other object in the general direction of an Official but does not come close to making any contact. This action may occur on or off the ice. (VII) In general, participants displaying this type of behavior are assessed a Minor Penalty, then a Misconduct Penalty and then a Game Misconduct Penalty if they persist. (VIII) Any Player, Coach or team personnel spits, smears blood or directing obscene, profane, or abusive language, use of obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks at an Official, during or after a game, on or off the ice and any location while in the arena and its connected premises.

paragraphs.context: A boarding penalty shall be imposed on any Player who checks or pushes a defenseless opponent in such a manner that causes the opponent to hit or impact the Boards violently or dangerously.The severity of the penalty, based upon the impact with the Boards, shall be at the discretion of the Referee. There is a considerable amount of judgment involved in the application of this rule by the Referees. The responsibility is on the Player applying the check to ensure their opponent is not in a defenseless position and if so, they must avoid or minimize contact. However, in determining whether such contact could have been avoided, the circumstances of the check, including whether the opponent put themself in a vulnerable position immediately prior to or simultaneously with the check or whether the check was unavoidable can be considered. This balance must be considered by the Referees when applying this rule. Any unnecessary contact with a Player playing the puck on an obvious “icing” or “off-side” play which results in that Player hitting or impacting the Boards is “boarding” and must be penalized as such. In other instances where there is no contact with the Boards, it should be treated as “charging”.

paragraphs.context: A penalty shall be imposed on a Player who skates, jumps into an opponent, or charges an opponent in any manner. Charging shall mean the actions of a Player who either jumps to check an opponent, builds up speed by taking multiple strides immediately prior to making contact and / or travels an excessive distance with the sole purpose of delivering such a hit and / or violently checks an opponent in any manner. A “charge” may be the result of a check into the Boards, into the goal frame or in open ice. Any unnecessary contact with a Player playing the puck on an obvious “icing” or “off-side” play which results in that Player hitting or impacting the Boards is “boarding” and must be penalized as such. In other instances where there is no contact with the Boards, it should be treated as “charging.” This rule is superseded by all similar actions regarding an “illegal hit to the head”, except those related to “fighting”. A penalty shall be imposed on a Player who charges a Goalkeeper while the Goalkeeper is within their Goal Crease. A Goalkeeper is not “fair game” just because they are outside the Goal Crease area. The appropriate penalty should be assessed in every case where an opposing Player makes unnecessary contact with a Goalkeeper. However, incidental contact, at the discretion of the Referee, will be permitted when the Goalkeeper is in the act of playing the puck outside their Goal Crease, provided the attacking Player has made a reasonable effort to avoid such contact.

qas.question: What actions constitute charging according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: Actions that constitute charging include skating or jumping into an opponent, building up speed before making contact, traveling an excessive distance to deliver a hit, or violently checking an opponent in any manner. Charging can occur in various situations, such as checking into the boards, the goal frame, or in open ice. Charging a goalkeeper while they are within the goal crease is also penalized.

qas.question: How is charging defined in relation to a player's movements prior to making contact with an opponent?

answers.text: Charging is defined as a player building up speed by taking multiple strides immediately before making contact with an opponent, traveling an excessive distance with the intent to deliver a hit, or violently checking an opponent in any manner.

qas.question: When should a penalty be imposed for charging in the context of a player making contact with an opponent playing the puck on an obvious "icing" or "off-side" play?

answers.text: A penalty for charging should be imposed when a player makes unnecessary contact with an opponent playing the puck on an obvious "icing" or "off-side" play, resulting in the opponent hitting or impacting the boards.

qas.question: Is charging superseded by all similar actions regarding an "illegal hit to the head" according to the rule context?

answers.text: Yes, charging is superseded by all similar actions regarding an "illegal hit to the head" according to the rule context.

paragraphs.context: A check from behind is a check delivered to a vulnerable Player who is not aware of the impending hit, therefore unable to protect or defend themself from such a hit and contact is made on the back part of the body. A Player who hits an opponent from behind into the Boards, the Goal Net, or on open ice in any manner (i.e., high-sticking, cross-checking, etc.) shall be penalized according to this rule. When a Player being bodychecked, intentionally turns their back towards an opponent and puts themself in a vulnerable position immediately before a bodycheck, to create a “checking from behind” situation, no penalty for “checking from behind” shall be assessed. However, other penalties may still be assessed.

paragraphs.context: “Clipping” or a “low-hit” is the act of throwing the body across or below the knees of an opponent from any direction. A Player may not deliver a check in a “clipping” manner, nor lower their own body position to deliver a check on or below an opponent’s knees. An illegal “low-hit” is a check that is delivered by a Player who may or may not have both skates on the ice, with their sole intent to check the opponent in the area of their knees. A Player may not lower their body position to deliver a check to an opponent’s knees. A Player may not crouch down near the Boards to avoid being bodychecked and as a result, causes an opponent to tumble over them.

paragraphs.context: ”Fighting” is not part of international ice hockey’s DNA. Players who willingly participate in a “brawl / fight”, so-called “willing combatants”, shall be penalized accordingly by the Referee(s) and may be ejected from the game. Further Supplementary Discipline may be imposed. A “fight” shall be deemed to have occurred when at least one (1) Player punches or attempts to punch an opponent repeatedly or when two (2) Players wrestle in such a manner as to make it difficult for the Linespersons to intervene and separate the combatants. Any Player who persists in continuing or attempting to continue a “fight or altercation” after they have been ordered by the Referee to stop, or who resists a Linesperson in the discharge of their duties shall, at the discretion of the Referee, incur at least a Major Penalty (“Fighting”) plus an automatic Game Misconduct Penalty (5’+GMP) in addition to any additional penalties imposed. The Referees are provided very wide latitude in penalties they may impose under this rule. This is done intentionally to enable them to differentiate between the obvious degrees of responsibility of the participants either for starting the “fight or persisting in continuing the fight”. The discretion provided should be exercised rationally. For Players, Coaches or Team Personnel leaving the Players' Benches or the Penalty Boxes, see (Rule 70 – Leaving the Players’ Bench or Penalty Box)

qas.question: What actions constitute a "fight" according to the rule on Fighting in ice hockey?

answers.text: A "fight" in ice hockey occurs when at least one player punches or attempts to punch an opponent repeatedly, or when two players wrestle in a way that hinders intervention by officials.

qas.question: How are players who willingly participate in a fight, known as "willing combatants," penalized according to the rule?

answers.text: Players who willingly participate in a fight, known as "willing combatants," are penalized by the Referee(s) with at least a Major Penalty ("Fighting") and an automatic Game Misconduct Penalty (5’+GMP). They may also be ejected from the game and face further Supplementary Discipline.

qas.question: What penalties may be imposed on a player who persists in continuing a fight after being ordered to stop by the Referee?

answers.text: A player who persists in continuing a fight after being ordered to stop by the Referee may incur at least a Major Penalty ("Fighting") and an automatic Game Misconduct Penalty (5’+GMP), along with potential additional penalties at the discretion of the Referee.

qas.question: How are Referees empowered to differentiate between the degrees of responsibility of participants in a fight according to the rule?

answers.text: Referees are empowered to differentiate between the degrees of responsibility of participants in a fight by exercising wide discretion in penalties imposed, allowing them to distinguish between those who start the fight and those who persist in continuing it.

qas.question: In what situations may a player incur a Major Penalty and an automatic Game Misconduct Penalty under the rule on Fighting in ice hockey?

answers.text: A player may incur a Major Penalty and an automatic Game Misconduct Penalty under the rule on Fighting in ice hockey when they persist in continuing or attempting to continue a fight after being ordered to stop by the Referee, or resist a Linesperson in their duties.
