data.title: OTHER INFRACTIONS - INTERFERENCE ON THE GOALKEEPER

paragraphs.context: This rule is based on the premise that an attacking Player’s position, whether inside or outside the Goal Crease, should not, by itself, determine whether a goal should be allowed or disallowed. In other words, goals scored while attacking Players are standing in the Goal Crease may, in appropriate circumstances be allowed. Goals should be disallowed only if: (I) an attacking Player, either by their positioning or by a "relevant contact”, impairs the Goalkeeper’s ability to move freely within their Goal Crease or defend their goal; or (II) an attacking Player initiates intentional or deliberate contact with a Goalkeeper, inside or outside of their Goal Crease. “Incidental contact” with a Goalkeeper will be permitted, and resulting goals allowed, when such contact is initiated outside of the Goal Crease, provided the attacking Player has made a reasonable effort to avoid such contact. The rule will be enforced exclusively in accordance with the on-ice judgement of the Referee(s), but may be subject to a Video Review: (Rule 37 – Video Review) when applicable or to a Coach’s Challenge (Rule 38 – Coach’s Challenge) For purposes of this rule, “contact / relevant contact” whether "incidental or otherwise", shall mean any contact that is made between or among a Goalkeeper and attacking Player(s), whether by means of a stick or any part of the body. The overriding rationale of this rule is that a Goalkeeper should have the ability to move freely within their Goal Crease without being hindered by the actions of an attacking Player. If an attacking Player enters the Goal Crease and, by their actions, impairs the Goalkeeper’s ability to defend their goal, and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed. If an attacking Player is in the Goal Crease and does not leave immediately, the Referee has the possibility to stop the game and the subsequent “face-off” shall take place at the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone of the offending Team. If an attacking Player has been pushed, shoved, or fouled by a defending Player so as to cause them to come into contact with the Goalkeeper, such contact will not be deemed contact initiated by the attacking Player for purposes of this rule, provided the attacking Player has made a reasonable effort to avoid such contact. If a defending Player has been pushed, shoved, or fouled by an attacking Player so as to cause the defending Player to come into contact with their own Goalkeeper, such contact shall be deemed contact initiated by the attacking Player for purposes of this rule, and if necessary, a penalty assessed to the attacking Player and if a goal is scored it would be disallowed.

qas.question: What are the two main criteria for disallowing a goal due to interference on the goalkeeper?

answers.text: The two main criteria for disallowing a goal due to interference on the goalkeeper are: (I) when an attacking player impairs the goalkeeper's ability to move freely or defend the goal, either by positioning or relevant contact, and (II) when an attacking player intentionally or deliberately initiates contact with the goalkeeper.

qas.question: When is "incidental contact" with a goalkeeper permitted, and resulting goals allowed?

answers.text: "Incidental contact with a goalkeeper is permitted when initiated outside the Goal Crease, as long as the attacking player makes a reasonable effort to avoid contact. Resulting goals are allowed in this scenario."

qas.question: What action can the referee take if an attacking player does not leave the goal crease immediately after impairing the goalkeeper's ability to defend their goal?

answers.text: If an attacking player does not leave the goal crease immediately after impairing the goalkeeper's ability to defend, the referee can stop the game, and the subsequent face-off will take place at the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone of the offending team.

qas.question: How is "contact / relevant contact" defined in the context of interference on the goalkeeper?

answers.text: "Contact / relevant contact" in the context of interference on the goalkeeper is defined as any contact made between a goalkeeper and attacking player(s) using a stick or any part of the body that impairs the goalkeeper's ability to move freely within the goal crease or defend their goal.

qas.question: In what situation would contact between a defending player and their own goalkeeper be deemed contact initiated by the attacking player for the purpose of this rule?

answers.text: Contact between a defending player and their own goalkeeper would be deemed contact initiated by the attacking player if the defending player has been pushed, shoved, or fouled by the attacking player, causing contact with their own goalkeeper.

paragraphs.context: In all cases in which an attacking Player initiates “intentional or deliberate” contact with a Goalkeeper, whether or not the Goalkeeper is inside or outside the Goal Crease, and whether or not a goal is scored, the attacking Player will receive a penalty (Minor or Major, as the Referee deems appropriate). In all cases where the infraction being imposed is to the attacking Player for hindering the Goalkeeper’s ability to move freely in their Goal Crease, the penalty to be assessed is for “Goalkeeper interference”. In exercising their judgment, the Referee should give more significant consideration to the degree and nature of the relevant contact with the Goalkeeper than to the exact location of the Goalkeeper at the time of the contact.

qas.question: What penalty will an attacking Player receive if they intentionally make contact with the Goalkeeper, regardless of the Goalkeeper's position or whether a goal is scored?

answers.text: An attacking Player will receive a penalty for "Goalkeeper interference" if they intentionally make contact with the Goalkeeper, regardless of the Goalkeeper's position or whether a goal is scored. The penalty assessed can be a Minor or Major penalty, as determined by the Referee.

qas.question: When will a penalty for "Goalkeeper interference" be assessed to an attacking Player?

answers.text: A penalty for "Goalkeeper interference" will be assessed to an attacking Player when they intentionally or deliberately make contact with the Goalkeeper, hindering their ability to move freely in the Goal Crease, regardless of the Goalkeeper's position or whether a goal is scored.

qas.question: According to the rule, what factor should the Referee prioritize when determining the appropriate penalty for interference on the Goalkeeper?

answers.text: The Referee should prioritize the degree and nature of the contact with the Goalkeeper when determining the appropriate penalty for interference.

qas.question: Does the rule specify that the attacking Player must be inside the Goal Crease to receive a penalty for interfering with the Goalkeeper?

answers.text: No, the rule does not specify that the attacking Player must be inside the Goal Crease to receive a penalty for interfering with the Goalkeeper.

qas.question: How should the Referee assess the penalty for interference on the Goalkeeper based on the degree and nature of the contact, according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: The Referee should assess the penalty for interference on the Goalkeeper based on the degree and nature of the contact, regardless of the Goalkeeper's location, by considering intentional or deliberate contact by the attacking Player.

paragraphs.context: If an attacking Player initiates "a relevant contact" with a Goalkeeper, incidental or otherwise, while the Goalkeeper is in their Goal Crease, and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed. If a Goalkeeper, in the “act of establishing their position” within their Goal Crease, initiates contact with an attacking Player who is in the Goal Crease, and this results in an impairment of the Goalkeeper’s ability to defend their goal, and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed. If, after any contact by a Goalkeeper who is attempting to establish position in their Goal Crease, the attacking Player does not immediately vacate their current position in the Goal Crease (i.e., give ground to the Goalkeeper), and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed. In all such cases, whether or not a goal is scored, the attacking Player will receive the appropriate penalty for Goalkeeper “interference”. If an attacking Player establishes a “significant position” within the Goal Crease, so as to obstruct the Goalkeeper’s vision and impair their ability to defend their goal, and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed. For this purpose, a Player “establishes a significant position within the crease” when, in the Referee’s judgment, their body, or a substantial portion thereof, is within the Goal Crease for more than an instantaneous period of time.

qas.question: What happens if an attacking player makes contact with a goalkeeper inside the goal crease and a goal is scored?

answers.text: If an attacking player makes contact with a goalkeeper inside the goal crease and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed due to goalkeeper interference.

qas.question: If a goalkeeper initiates contact with an attacking player in the goal crease, resulting in an impairment of the goalkeeper's ability to defend, and a goal is scored, what is the ruling?

answers.text: If a goalkeeper initiates contact with an attacking player in the goal crease, resulting in an impairment of the goalkeeper's ability to defend, and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed.

qas.question: What penalty does an attacking player receive for goalkeeper interference if they do not vacate the goal crease after contact by the goalkeeper and a goal is scored?

answers.text: The attacking player would receive a penalty for goalkeeper interference if they do not vacate the goal crease after contact by the goalkeeper and a goal is scored.

qas.question: When does a player establish a significant position within the goal crease according to the rule?

answers.text: A player establishes a significant position within the goal crease when their body, or a substantial portion thereof, is within the crease for more than an instantaneous period of time.

qas.question: If an attacking player obstructs the goalkeeper's vision and impairs their ability to defend by establishing a significant position within the goal crease, what is the outcome if a goal is scored?

answers.text: If an attacking player obstructs the goalkeeper's vision and impairs their ability to defend by establishing a significant position within the goal crease and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed.

paragraphs.context: If an attacking Player initiates any "relevant contact" with a Goalkeeper, other than “incidental contact”, while the Goalkeeper is outside their Goal Crease, and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed. A Goalkeeper is not “fair game” just because they are outside the Goal Crease. The appropriate penalty should be assessed in every case where an attacking Player makes “unnecessary contact” with the Goalkeeper. However, “incidental contact” will be permitted when the Goalkeeper is in the act of playing the puck outside their Goal Crease provided the attacking Player has made a “reasonable effort” to avoid such unnecessary contact. When a Goalkeeper has played the puck outside of their Goal Crease and is then prevented from returning to their Goal Crease area due to the deliberate actions of an attacking Player, such Player may be penalized for “Goalkeeper interference”. Similarly, the Goalkeeper may be penalized, if by their actions outside of their Goal Crease they deliberately interfere with an attacking Player who is attempting to play the puck or an opponent.

qas.question: What happens if an attacking player initiates relevant contact with a goalkeeper outside their goal crease and a goal is scored?

answers.text: If an attacking player initiates relevant contact with a goalkeeper outside their goal crease and a goal is scored, the goal will be disallowed.

qas.question: Is a goalkeeper considered "fair game" when they are outside their goal crease?

answers.text: No, a goalkeeper is not considered "fair game" when they are outside their goal crease in hockey.

qas.question: Under what circumstances is incidental contact permitted between an attacking player and a goalkeeper playing the puck outside their goal crease?

answers.text: Incidental contact between an attacking player and a goalkeeper playing the puck outside their goal crease is permitted as long as the attacking player has made a reasonable effort to avoid unnecessary contact.

qas.question: When can a player be penalized for goalkeeper interference according to the rule?

answers.text: A player can be penalized for goalkeeper interference when they make unnecessary contact with the goalkeeper outside the goal crease, preventing the goalkeeper from returning to the crease or interfering with an opponent trying to play the puck.

qas.question: Can a goalkeeper be penalized for interfering with an attacking player who is attempting to play the puck outside the goal crease?

answers.text: Yes, a goalkeeper can be penalized for interfering with an attacking player who is attempting to play the puck outside the goal crease if the interference is deemed unnecessary or deliberate.

paragraphs.context: Whenever the Referee stops play to disallow a goal as a result of “relevant contact” with the Goalkeeper (incidental or otherwise), the resulting “face-off” shall take place at the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone of the offending Team.

qas.question: Where does the face-off take place if a goal is disallowed due to interference with the goalkeeper?

answers.text: If a goal is disallowed due to interference with the goalkeeper, the face-off will take place at the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone of the offending Team.

answers.text: After relevant contact with the goalkeeper results in a disallowed goal, the face-off will take place at the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone of the offending Team.

answers.text: The nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot for the ensuing face-off after interference with the goalkeeper is outside the Attacking Zone of the offending Team.

qas.question: Following interference with the goalkeeper resulting in a disallowed goal, where is the face-off spot located in relation to the Attacking Zone of the offending team?

answers.text: The face-off spot is located at the nearest Neutral Zone Face-off Spot outside the Attacking Zone of the offending team.

paragraphs.context: In a rebound situation, or where a Goalkeeper and attacking Player(s) are simultaneously attempting to play a loose puck, whether inside or outside the Goal Crease, “incidental contact” with the Goalkeeper will be permitted, and any goal that is scored as a result thereof will be allowed. In the event a Goalkeeper has been pushed into the net together with the puck by an attacking Player after making a stop, the goal will be disallowed. If applicable, appropriate penalties will be assessed. If, however, in the opinion of the Referee, the attacking Player was pushed or otherwise fouled by a defending Player causing the Goalkeeper to be pushed into the net together with the puck, the goal can be permitted. In the event the puck is under a Player in or around the Goal Crease area (deliberately or otherwise), a goal cannot be scored by pushing this Player together with the puck into the goal. If applicable, the appropriate penalties will be assessed, including a “Penalty Shot” if deemed to be covered in the Goal Crease deliberately. (Rule 63 – Delaying the Game)

qas.question: What is the outcome if a Goalkeeper is pushed into the net together with the puck by an attacking Player after making a stop?

answers.text: If a Goalkeeper is pushed into the net together with the puck by an attacking Player after making a stop, the goal will be disallowed, and appropriate penalties may be assessed.

qas.question: When is "incidental contact" with the Goalkeeper permitted in a rebound situation or when both the Goalkeeper and attacking Player(s) are attempting to play a loose puck?

answers.text: "Incidental contact" with the Goalkeeper is permitted in a rebound situation or when both the Goalkeeper and attacking Player(s) are attempting to play a loose puck, whether inside or outside the Goal Crease. Any goal scored as a result of this contact will be allowed.

qas.question: What action will be taken if a defending Player pushes or fouls an attacking Player, causing the Goalkeeper to be pushed into the net together with the puck?

answers.text: If a defending player pushes or fouls an attacking player, causing the goalkeeper to be pushed into the net with the puck, the goal will be disallowed, and appropriate penalties will be assessed.

qas.question: Can a goal be scored by pushing a Player together with the puck into the goal when the puck is under a Player in or around the Goal Crease area?

answers.text: No, a goal cannot be scored by pushing a Player together with the puck into the goal when the puck is under a Player in or around the Goal Crease area.

qas.question: What penalties may be assessed if a Player deliberately covers the puck in the Goal Crease area to prevent a goal from being scored?

answers.text: If a Player deliberately covers the puck in the Goal Crease area to prevent a goal from being scored, penalties that may be assessed include a "Penalty Shot" as per Rule 63 – Delaying the Game.

data.title: OTHER INFRACTIONS - LEAVING THE PLAYERS’ BENCH OR PENALTY BOX

paragraphs.context: No Player may leave the Players’ Bench or Penalty Box at any time during an altercation or for the purpose of starting an altercation.

qas.question: Can a player leave the Players' Bench or Penalty Box during an altercation?

answers.text: No, a player cannot leave the Players' Bench or Penalty Box during an altercation.

qas.question: What is the rule regarding a player leaving the Players' Bench or Penalty Box for the purpose of starting an altercation?

answers.text: Players are not allowed to leave the Players' Bench or Penalty Box to start an altercation.

qas.question: Is it allowed for a player to exit the Penalty Box during a physical confrontation on the ice?

answers.text: No, a player is not allowed to exit the Penalty Box during a physical confrontation on the ice.

qas.question: What action is prohibited for a player in the Players' Bench or Penalty Box during an altercation?

answers.text: Players in the Players' Bench or Penalty Box are prohibited from leaving during an altercation or to instigate one.

qas.question: Are players permitted to leave the Players' Bench or Penalty Box to engage in a fight with an opponent?

answers.text: No, players are not permitted to leave the Players' Bench or Penalty Box to engage in a fight with an opponent.

paragraphs.context: A Player who has entered the game while play is in progress from – own Players’ Bench or legally from the Penalty Box (penalty time has expired) who starts an altercation may be subject to discipline in accordance with Rule 28 – Supplementary Discipline. A Player or Players who have entered the game on a legal line change during a stoppage of play, who line up in preparation for the ensuing “face-off”, and who participate in an altercation shall be penalized under the appropriate rule and will be subject to discipline in accordance with Supplementary Discipline (a Game Misconduct is not automatic in this situation unless provided for as a result of their actions in the altercation). (Rule 28 – Supplementary Discipline)

qas.question: What discipline may a player face if they start an altercation after entering the game from their own Players' Bench while play is in progress?

answers.text: A player who starts an altercation after entering the game from their own Players' Bench while play is in progress may face discipline under Rule 28 - Supplementary Discipline.

qas.question: How should players who have entered the game on a legal line change during a stoppage of play behave to avoid penalties for participating in an altercation?

answers.text: Players who have entered the game on a legal line change during a stoppage of play should avoid participating in an altercation to prevent penalties and potential disciplinary action.

qas.question: Under what circumstances may a player be subject to discipline in accordance with Rule 28 - Supplementary Discipline after entering the game from the Penalty Box?

answers.text: A player may be subject to discipline under Rule 28 - Supplementary Discipline if they start an altercation after entering the game from the Penalty Box.

qas.question: Are players automatically given a Game Misconduct if they participate in an altercation after entering the game on a legal line change during a stoppage of play?

answers.text: No, players are not automatically given a Game Misconduct if they participate in an altercation after entering the game on a legal line change during a stoppage of play.

qas.question: What actions can result in a player or players who have entered the game on a legal line change during a stoppage of play being penalized under the appropriate rule and subject to Supplementary Discipline?

answers.text: Players who have entered the game on a legal line change during a stoppage of play and participate in an altercation may be penalized under the appropriate rule and subject to Supplementary Discipline as outlined in Rule 28.

paragraphs.context: Players shall not be permitted to come on the ice during a stoppage of play or at the end of the first and second periods for the purpose of warming-up. The Referee will report any violation of this rule to the Proper Authorities for disciplinary action. Except at the end of each period or for entering the game legally, no Player may, at any time, leave the Players’ Bench. If it is necessary to proceed to the Dressing Room during the course of the game (and when it is required to proceed by way of the ice to access the Dressing Room), the Player must wait for a stoppage of play and ensure there are not altercations in progress before proceeding. The Player who was the first or second Player to leave the Players’ Bench (or Penalty Box) during an altercation or for the purpose of starting an altercation, from either or both Teams shall be assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: When are players allowed to come on the ice during a stoppage of play or at the end of the first and second periods for the purpose of warming up?

answers.text: Players are not allowed to come on the ice during a stoppage of play or at the end of the first and second periods for warming up.

qas.question: What action will the Referee take if a player violates the rule of leaving the players' bench during a stoppage of play?

answers.text: If a player violates the rule of leaving the players' bench during a stoppage of play, the Referee will report the violation to the Proper Authorities for disciplinary action.

qas.question: Under what circumstances can a player leave the players' bench during a game?

answers.text: A player can only leave the players' bench during a game to enter the game legally or to go to the dressing room during a stoppage of play, ensuring no altercations are in progress. Leaving the bench for any other reason can result in disciplinary action.

qas.question: What must a player do before proceeding to the Dressing Room during the course of the game if it is required to access the Dressing Room by way of the ice?

answers.text: Before proceeding to the Dressing Room during the course of the game if it is required to access the Dressing Room by way of the ice, a player must wait for a stoppage of play and ensure there are no altercations in progress.

qas.question: What penalty will be assessed to the player who was the first or second to leave the players' bench during an altercation or for the purpose of starting an altercation?

answers.text: A player who is the first or second to leave the players' bench during an altercation or to start an altercation will be assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty.

paragraphs.context: Except at the end of each period or on expiration of their penalty, no Player may, at any time, leave the Penalty Box. A Player serving a penalty in the Penalty Box, who is to be changed after the penalty has been served, must proceed at once by way of the ice and be at their own Players’ Bench before any change can be made.For any violation of this rule, a Bench Minor Penalty shall be imposed for “too many Players on the ice”. (Rule 74 – Too many Players on the Ice) A penalized Player who leaves the Penalty Box before their penalty has expired, whether play is in progress or not, shall incur an additional Minor Penalty after serving their unexpired penalty. Any Player who, having entered the Penalty Box, leaves the Penalty Box prior to the expiration of their penalty for the purpose of challenging an Official’s ruling, shall be assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty. If deemed appropriate, Supplementary Discipline can be applied by the Proper Authorities at their discretion. This rule does not replace any other more severe penalty that may be imposed for leaving the Penalty Box for the purpose of starting or participating in an altercation as outlined in this rule. (Rule 28 – Supplementary Discipline) Any penalized Player leaving the Penalty Box during a stoppage of play and during an altercation shall incur a Minor Penalty plus a Game Misconduct Penalty. The Minor Penalty plus the unexpired time remaining in their original penalty must be served by a replacement Player placed in the Penalty Box by the Coach of the offending Team. If a Player leaves the Penalty Box before their penalty is fully served, the Penalty Timekeeper shall note the time and signal the On-ice Officials who will stop play when the offending Player’s Team obtains “control of the puck”. An additional Minor Penalty must be served by this Player in addition to the time remaining in their original penalty (this unexpired time is calculated from the time they left the Penalty Box illegally). In the case of a Player returning to the ice before their time has expired through an error of the Penalty Timekeeper, they are not to serve an additional penalty, but must serve their unexpired time this unexpired time is calculated from the time they left the Penalty Box through the error of the Penalty Timekeeper. At a stoppage of play following the expiration of their penalties, if a Player or Players exiting the Penalty Box get involved in an altercation, those coming from the Penalty Box shall be assessed the penalties they incur in the altercation. Should a Player coming from the Penalty Box at a stoppage of play get involved with an opponent and the opponent is deemed to be the instigator of the altercation, then the Player coming from the Penalty Box would not be subject to the Game Misconduct Penalty. If deemed appropriate, Supplementary Discipline can be applied by the Proper Authorities at their discretion. (Rule 28 – Supplementary Discipline)

qas.question: What penalty is imposed for leaving the Penalty Box before the expiration of a player's penalty for the purpose of challenging an Official's ruling?

answers.text: A Player leaving the Penalty Box before their penalty expires to challenge an Official's ruling will be assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: What additional penalty does a penalized Player incur if they leave the Penalty Box before their penalty has expired, whether play is in progress or not?

answers.text: A penalized Player who leaves the Penalty Box before their penalty has expired incurs an additional Minor Penalty after serving their unexpired penalty, whether play is in progress or not.

qas.question: What penalty is assessed to a penalized Player leaving the Penalty Box during a stoppage of play and during an altercation?

answers.text: A penalized Player leaving the Penalty Box during a stoppage of play and during an altercation incurs a Minor Penalty plus a Game Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: How is the unexpired time remaining in a player's original penalty calculated if they leave the Penalty Box illegally before their penalty is fully served?

answers.text: If a player leaves the Penalty Box illegally before their penalty is fully served, the unexpired time remaining in their original penalty is calculated from the time they left the Penalty Box illegally.

qas.question: In what scenario would a Player coming from the Penalty Box not be subject to a Game Misconduct Penalty if they get involved in an altercation at a stoppage of play?

answers.text: A Player coming from the Penalty Box would not be subject to a Game Misconduct Penalty if they get involved in an altercation at a stoppage of play and the opponent is deemed to be the instigator of the altercation.

paragraphs.context: A Bench Minor Penalty shall be imposed on a Team whose Player(s) leave the Players’ Bench for any purpose other than a change of Players and when no altercation is in progress. If a Coach or team personnel gets on the ice, unless directed to do so by On-ice Official or Medical Personnel, to attend to an injured Player after the start of a period and before that period is ended, the Referee shall impose a Bench Minor Penalty against the Team and report the incident to the Proper Authorities for disciplinary action. Where an injury has occurred to a Player and there is a stoppage of play, a Team Doctor (or other Medical Personnel) may go onto the ice to attend to the injured Player without waiting for the Referee’s consent.

qas.question: When will a Bench Minor Penalty be imposed on a team according to the rule on leaving the players' bench or penalty box?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty will be imposed on a team if their player(s) leave the players' bench for any reason other than a player change and when there is no altercation in progress. Additionally, if a coach or team personnel enter the ice without permission to attend to an injured player during a period, a Bench Minor Penalty will be imposed.

qas.question: Under what circumstances can a Coach or team personnel go onto the ice without incurring a Bench Minor Penalty?

answers.text: A Coach or team personnel can go onto the ice without incurring a Bench Minor Penalty if they are attending to an injured Player after the start of a period and before that period is ended, or if a Team Doctor (or other Medical Personnel) attends to an injured Player during a stoppage of play.

qas.question: What action will the Referee take if a Coach or team personnel enters the ice to attend to an injured Player without being directed to do so by On-ice Official or Medical Personnel?

answers.text: The Referee will impose a Bench Minor Penalty on the Team if a Coach or team personnel enters the ice to attend to an injured Player without being directed to do so by On-ice Official or Medical Personnel.

qas.question: Can a Team Doctor or other Medical Personnel attend to an injured Player on the ice without waiting for the Referee's consent?

answers.text: Yes, a Team Doctor or other Medical Personnel can attend to an injured Player on the ice without waiting for the Referee's consent if there is a stoppage of play due to the injury.

qas.question: What is the consequence for a Team if their Player(s) leave the Players' Bench for a purpose other than a change of Players and no altercation is in progress?

answers.text: Consequence: A Bench Minor Penalty is imposed on a Team if their Player(s) leave the Players' Bench for a purpose other than a change of Players and no altercation is in progress.

paragraphs.context: A Game Misconduct Penalty shall be imposed on the Player who was the first or second Player to leave the Players’ Bench or Penalty Box during an altercation or for the purpose of starting an altercation, from either or both Teams. Any penalized Player leaving the Penalty Box during a stoppage of play and during an altercation shall incur a Minor Penalty plus a Game Misconduct Penalty. The Minor Penalty plus the unexpired time remaining in their original penalty must be served by a replacement Player placed in the Penalty Box by the Coach of the offending Team. Any Player who has been ordered to the Dressing Room by the Officials and returns to their Players’ Bench or to the ice surface for any reason before the appropriate time shall be assessed a Game Misconduct. If deemed appropriate, Supplementary Discipline can be applied by the Proper Authorities at their discretion. (Rule 28 – Supplementary Discipline) Once a Player enters the Penalty Box, they must not leave until their penalty expires and their Team is entitled to an additional Player on the ice, or, at the end of a period to proceed to their Dressing Room, or, when they have received permission from an On-ice Official. At any other time, they shall be assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty under this rule.

qas.question: What penalty is imposed on the first or second player to leave the players' bench or penalty box during an altercation or for the purpose of starting an altercation?

answers.text: The first or second player to leave the players' bench or penalty box during an altercation or to start one will receive a Game Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: What penalty does a penalized player incur for leaving the penalty box during a stoppage of play and during an altercation?

answers.text: A penalized player who leaves the penalty box during a stoppage of play and during an altercation incurs a Minor Penalty plus a Game Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: Who is responsible for placing a replacement player in the penalty box for a player who incurs a minor penalty plus a game misconduct penalty for leaving the penalty box during an altercation?

answers.text: The coach of the offending team is responsible for placing a replacement player in the penalty box for a player who incurs a minor penalty plus a game misconduct penalty for leaving the penalty box during an altercation.

qas.question: What penalty is assessed to a player who returns to their players' bench or the ice surface before the appropriate time after being ordered to the dressing room by the officials?

answers.text: A player who returns to their players' bench or the ice surface before the appropriate time after being ordered to the dressing room by officials will be assessed a Game Misconduct penalty.

qas.question: When can a player leave the penalty box before their penalty expires without incurring a game misconduct penalty under this rule?

answers.text: A player can leave the penalty box before their penalty expires without incurring a game misconduct penalty only when they have received permission from an On-ice Official.

paragraphs.context: If a Player of the attacking side in possession of the puck shall be in such a position as to have no opposition between them and the opposing Goalkeeper, and while in such position their shall be interfered with by a Player of the opposing Team who shall have illegally entered the game, the Referee shall impose a “Penalty Shot” against the Team to which the offending Player belongs.

qas.question: What action will the referee take if a player from the opposing team illegally enters the game and interferes with a player in possession of the puck who has a clear path to the opposing goalkeeper?

answers.text: The referee will impose a "Penalty Shot" against the team to which the illegally entering player belongs.

qas.question: In what situation would a penalty shot be awarded according to the rule regarding leaving the players' bench or penalty box?

qas.question: Who is responsible for imposing a penalty shot if a player from the attacking side is interfered with by an illegally entering player from the opposing team?

qas.question: What must be the positioning of a player from the attacking side in possession of the puck in order for a penalty shot to be awarded if interfered with by an illegally entering player from the opposing team?

qas.question: Which team will be penalized with a penalty shot if a player from the opposing team illegally enters the game and interferes with a player from the attacking side who has a clear path to the opposing goalkeeper?

answers.text: The team to which the offending player belongs will be penalized with a penalty shot.

paragraphs.context: If, when the opposing Goalkeeper has been removed from the ice, a Player of the side attacking the unattended goal is interfered with in the Neutral or Attacking Zone by a Player who shall have entered the game illegally, the Referee shall immediately award a goal to the non-offending Team.

qas.question: What action will the referee take if a player from the attacking team is interfered with in the Neutral or Attacking Zone by a player who entered the game illegally when the opposing goalkeeper has been removed from the ice?

answers.text: The referee will award a goal to the non-offending team if a player from the attacking team is interfered with in the Neutral or Attacking Zone by a player who entered the game illegally when the opposing goalkeeper has been removed from the ice.

qas.question: In what situation will a goal be immediately awarded to the non-offending team according to the rule about leaving the players' bench or penalty box?

answers.text: A goal will be immediately awarded to the non-offending team if a player illegally enters the game and interferes with an attacking player in the Neutral or Attacking Zone when the opposing goalkeeper has been removed from the ice.

qas.question: When can a goal be awarded to the non-offending team if a player is interfered with in the Neutral or Attacking Zone by an illegally entered player while the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice?

answers.text: A goal can be awarded to the non-offending team if a player is interfered with in the Neutral or Attacking Zone by an illegally entered player while the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice.

qas.question: What is the consequence if a player illegally enters the game and interferes with an attacking player in the Neutral or Attacking Zone when the opposing goalkeeper is removed from the ice?

answers.text: If a player illegally enters the game and interferes with an attacking player in the Neutral or Attacking Zone when the opposing goalkeeper is removed from the ice, the consequence is that the referee will immediately award a goal to the non-offending team.

qas.question: How does the referee handle a situation where a player from the attacking team is interfered with by an illegally entered player in the Neutral or Attacking Zone while the opposing goalkeeper is not on the ice?

answers.text: The referee awards a goal to the non-offending team if an illegally entered player interferes with an attacking player in the Neutral or Attacking Zone while the opposing goalkeeper is off the ice.

paragraphs.context: If a penalized Player returns to the ice from the Penalty Box before their penalty has expired by their own error or the error of the Penalty Timekeeper, any goal scored by their own Team while they are illegally on the ice shall be disallowed but all penalties imposed on either Team shall be served as regular penalties. paragraphs.context: When a Goalkeeper leaves their goal area and proceeds to their Players’ Bench for the purpose of substituting another Player, the Skater cannot enter the playing surface before the Goalkeeper is within 1.50 m of their Players’ Bench. If the substitution is made prematurely, the Official shall stop play immediately unless the non-offending Team has “possession of the puck” – in which event the stoppage will be delayed until the puck “changes possession”. There shall be no time penalty to the Team making the premature substitution, but the resulting “face-off” will take place at the Center ice Face-off Spot when play is stopped beyond the Center red line. When play is stopped prior to the Center red line, the resulting “face-off” shall be conducted at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the play was stopped. In all other situations not covered in the above, a Minor Penalty may result for “too many Players on the ice” (Rule 74 – Too Many Players on the Ice)

data.title: OTHER INFRACTIONS - REFUSING TO START PLAY

paragraphs.context: This rule applies to Teams who refuse to play while both Teams are on the ice or who withdraws from the ice and refuses to play or who refuses to come onto the ice at the start of the game or at the beginning of any period of the game, when ordered to do so by the Officials.

qas.question: What does the rule on refusing to start play apply to in hockey?

answers.text: The rule on refusing to start play in hockey applies to teams that refuse to play while both teams are on the ice, withdraw from the ice and refuse to play, or refuse to come onto the ice at the start of the game or any period when ordered by officials.

qas.question: When does the rule on refusing to start play come into effect during a game?

answers.text: The rule on refusing to start play comes into effect when a team fails to come onto the ice at the start of the game or at the beginning of any period when ordered to do so by the Officials.

qas.question: Which Teams are subject to the rule on refusing to start play while both Teams are on the ice?

answers.text: Teams that are subject to the rule on refusing to start play while both Teams are on the ice are those who refuse to come onto the ice at the start of the game or at the beginning of any period when ordered to do so by the Officials.

qas.question: What action constitutes a Team withdrawing from the ice and refusing to play according to the rule?

answers.text: A Team withdrawing from the ice and refusing to play constitutes not coming onto the ice when ordered by Officials at the start of the game or any period.

qas.question: In what situations can a Team be penalized for refusing to come onto the ice at the start of the game or at the beginning of any period of the game?

answers.text: A Team can be penalized for refusing to come onto the ice at the start of the game or at the beginning of any period if they do so when ordered by the Officials.

paragraphs.context: If, when both Teams are on the ice, one Team for any reason shall refuse to play when ordered to do so by the Referee, they shall warn the Captain and allow the Team so refusing fifteen (15) seconds within which to begin the play or resume play. If at the end of that time, the Team shall still refuse to play, the Referee shall impose a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” on a Player of the offending Team to be designated by the Coach of that Team through the playing Captain. Should there be a repetition of the same incident, the offending Coach shall be removed from the Players’ Bench and assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty by the Referee and a Bench Minor Penalty shall be assessed to the offending Team for “Delay of Game”. Should the offending Team still refuse to play, the Referee shall have no alternative but to declare that the game be forfeited to the non-offending Team and the case shall be reported to the Proper Authorities for further action (Rule 66 – Forfeit of Game) First Violation: (I) Warn the Captain of the offending Team and allow 15 seconds within which to resume play. (II) If at the end of the 15 seconds the Team still refuses to resume play, assess a Bench Minor Penalty to the offending Team for “Delay of Game”. Second Violation: (I) Warn the Captain of the offending Team and allow 15 seconds within which to resume play. (II) If at the end of the 15 seconds the Team still refuses to resume play, assess a Bench Minor Penalty to the offending Team for “Delay of Game”. (III) Referee is to notify the Coach of the offending Team that they have been assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty. (IV) If the Team still refuses to play, the Referee shall declare the game be forfeited to the non-offending Team. (Rule 66 – Forfeit of Game) Note: From the time a team enters the ice or player’s benches before a period is started until the period is over, this rule applies. Even if all player in a team leaves the ice surface for the player’s benches, the team is considered to be on the ice.

qas.question: What action should the Referee take if a Team refuses to play after being ordered to do so?

answers.text: If a Team refuses to play after being ordered to do so by the Referee, the Referee should first warn the Captain and allow 15 seconds to resume play. If the Team still refuses, a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" is imposed. If the refusal recurs, the Coach is removed, a Game Misconduct Penalty is assessed, and the game may be forfeited to the non-offending Team.

qas.question: How long does the Referee allow a Team to begin or resume play after being warned for refusing to start play?

answers.text: The Referee allows a Team 15 seconds to begin or resume play after being warned for refusing to start play.

qas.question: What penalty is imposed on a Player of the offending Team if they still refuse to play after the initial warning?

answers.text: If a Player of the offending Team still refuses to play after the initial warning, a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" is imposed on a Player designated by the Coach of that Team through the playing Captain.

qas.question: What penalty is assessed to the offending Team if there is a repetition of the refusal to play incident?

answers.text: If there is a repetition of the refusal to play incident, the offending Team will have a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" assessed to them, and the offending Coach will be removed from the Players' Bench and assessed a Game Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: What action does the Referee take if the offending Team still refuses to play after the Coach has been removed from the Players' Bench and a Game Misconduct Penalty has been assessed?

answers.text: If the offending Team still refuses to play after the Coach has been removed from the Players' Bench and a Game Misconduct Penalty has been assessed, the Referee will declare the game forfeited to the non-offending Team and report the incident to the Proper Authorities for further action.

paragraphs.context: If a Team, when ordered to do so by the Referee through its Coach, fails to go on the ice and start play within five (5) minutes, the game shall be forfeited, and the case shall be reported to the Proper Authorities for further action. (Rule 66 – Forfeit of Game) (I) Once it is apparent to the Referee that the Team is refusing to come onto the ice and begin play, a Bench Minor Penalty is to be assessed to the offending Team for “Delay of Game”. (II) Five (5) minutes will be provided for the offending Team to return to the ice and begin play. (III) After the five (5) minutes has elapsed and the offending Team still has not returned to the ice to resume play, the game shall be forfeited. (IV) Once the Coach has been notified of the five (5) minute warning, and the Team returns to the ice to resume play within that time frame, a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” must be assessed to the offending Team as stated in (I) above. Supplementary Discipline will be applied by the Proper Authorities at their discretion. (Rule 28 – Supplementary Discipline)

qas.question: What happens if a team fails to go on the ice and start play within five minutes after being ordered to do so by the Referee through its Coach?

answers.text: If a team fails to go on the ice and start play within five minutes after being ordered to do so by the Referee through its Coach, the game shall be forfeited, and the case will be reported to the Proper Authorities for further action.

qas.question: What penalty is assessed to a team if it is apparent to the Referee that they are refusing to come onto the ice and begin play?

answers.text: If a team refuses to come onto the ice and begin play, a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" is assessed to the offending team.

qas.question: How long is the grace period provided for the offending team to return to the ice and begin play after a Bench Minor Penalty is assessed for "Delay of Game"?

answers.text: The grace period provided for the offending team to return to the ice and begin play after a Bench Minor Penalty is assessed for "Delay of Game" is five (5) minutes.

qas.question: What action is taken if the offending team still has not returned to the ice to resume play after the five-minute grace period has elapsed?

answers.text: If the offending team has not returned to the ice to resume play after the five-minute grace period has elapsed, the game shall be forfeited, and the case will be reported to the Proper Authorities for further action.

qas.question: If a team returns to the ice to resume play within the five-minute warning after being notified by the Coach, what penalty must be assessed to the offending team as per the rule?

answers.text: If a team returns to the ice to resume play within the five-minute warning after being notified by the Coach, a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" must be assessed to the offending team as per the rule.

data.title: OTHER INFRACTIONS - TOO MANY PLAYERS ON THE ICE

paragraphs.context: Players may be changed at any time during the play from the Players’ Bench provided that the Player or Players leaving the ice shall be within 1.50 m of their Players’ Bench and out of the play before the change is made – refer also to Rule 71 – Premature Substitution. At the discretion of the On-ice Officials, should a substituting Player come onto the ice before their Teammate is within the 1.50 m limit of the Players’ Bench (and therefore clearly causing their Team to have “too many Players” on the ice), then a Bench Minor Penalty may be assessed. When a Player is retiring from the ice surface and is within the 1.50 m limit of their Players’ Bench, and their substitute is on the ice, then the retiring Player shall be considered off the ice for the purpose of Rule 70 – Leaving Players Bench or Penalty Box. If in the course of making a substitution, either the Player entering the game or the Player retiring from the ice surface plays the puck with their stick, skates or hands or who checks or makes any physical contact with an opposing Player while either the Player entering the game or the retiring Player is actually on the ice, then the infraction of “too many Players on the ice” will be called. If in the course of a substitution either the Player(s) entering the play or the Player(s) retiring is struck by the puck accidentally, the play will not be stopped, and no penalty will be called. During the play, the Player retiring from the ice must do so at the Players’ Bench and not through any other exit leading from the Rink. This is not a legal Player change and therefore when a violation occurs, a Bench Minor Penalty shall be imposed. A Player coming onto the ice as a substitute Player is considered on the ice once both of their skates are on the ice. If they play the puck or interfere with an opponent while still on the Players’ Bench, they shall be penalized under (Rule 56 – Interference) A retiring Player (coming off the ice) who has one skate on the ice and one skate off the ice in the Players’ Bench is considered as “off the ice”.

qas.question: What is the distance limit that a Player must be within their Players' Bench when leaving the ice during a substitution to avoid a penalty for having too many players on the ice?

answers.text: A Player must be within 1.50 meters of their Players' Bench when leaving the ice during a substitution to avoid a penalty for having too many players on the ice.

qas.question: When can players be changed during the play from the Players' Bench according to the rule on too many players on the ice?

answers.text: Players can be changed during play from the Players' Bench as long as the departing player is within 1.50 m of the bench and out of the play before the change is made to avoid having too many players on the ice.

qas.question: What action may result in a Bench Minor Penalty being assessed if a substituting Player comes onto the ice prematurely?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty may be assessed if a substituting Player comes onto the ice prematurely before their teammate is within 1.50 m of the Players' Bench.

qas.question: How is a retiring Player considered off the ice for the purpose of Rule 70 - Leaving Players Bench or Penalty Box?

answers.text: A retiring Player is considered off the ice for Rule 70 - Leaving Players Bench or Penalty Box when they are within 1.50 m of their Players’ Bench and their substitute is on the ice.

qas.question: When is a Player considered on the ice as a substitute Player according to the rule on too many players on the ice?

answers.text: A Player is considered on the ice as a substitute Player once both of their skates are on the ice.

paragraphs.context: A Bench Minor Penalty for “too many Players on the ice” shall be assessed for a violation of this rule. This penalty can be assessed by the Referees or the Linespersons. Should a goal be scored by the offending Team prior to the Referee or Linesperson blowing their whistle to assess the Bench Minor Penalty, the goal shall be disallowed, and the penalty assessed for “too many Players on the ice”.

qas.question: What penalty is assessed for having too many players on the ice in hockey?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty is assessed for having too many players on the ice in hockey.

qas.question: Who can assess a Bench Minor Penalty for "too many Players on the ice" according to the rule?

answers.text: Referees or Linespersons can assess a Bench Minor Penalty for "too many Players on the ice" according to the rule.

qas.question: What happens if a team scores a goal before the Bench Minor Penalty for too many players on the ice is assessed?

qas.question: Can the Referees or Linespersons assess a Bench Minor Penalty for too many players on the ice in hockey?

answers.text: Yes, the Referees or Linespersons can assess a Bench Minor Penalty for too many players on the ice in hockey.

paragraphs.context: A Player serving a penalty in the Penalty Box, who is to be changed after the penalty has been served, must proceed at once by way of the ice and be within 1.50 m of their own Players’ Bench before any change can be made. For any violation of this rule, a Bench Minor Penalty shall be imposed for “too many Players on the ice”.

qas.question: Where should a player in the Penalty Box proceed by way of before being changed after the penalty has been served?

qas.question: What distance must a player in the Penalty Box be within of their own Players' Bench for a change to be made after the penalty has been served?

answers.text: A player in the Penalty Box must be within 1.50 meters of their own Players' Bench for a change to be made after the penalty has been served.

paragraphs.context: If by reason of insufficient playing time remaining, or by reason of penalties already imposed, a Bench Minor Penalty is imposed for “deliberate illegal substitution” (“too many Players on the ice”) which cannot be served in its entirety within the legal playing time, or at any time in Overtime, a “Penalty Shot” shall be awarded against the offending Team.

qas.question: What penalty is imposed for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) if it cannot be served in its entirety within the legal playing time?

answers.text: A penalty shot is awarded against the offending team for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) if it cannot be served in its entirety within the legal playing time.

qas.question: When can a Penalty Shot be awarded against a team for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice)?

answers.text: A Penalty Shot can be awarded against a team for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) if a Bench Minor Penalty for this infraction cannot be served in its entirety within the legal playing time or during Overtime.

qas.question: In what situation would a Bench Minor Penalty be imposed for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice)?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) would result in a Penalty Shot being awarded against the offending team if it cannot be served in its entirety within the legal playing time or during overtime.

qas.question: What is the consequence for a team if they commit deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) and cannot serve the penalty within the legal playing time or in Overtime?

answers.text: Consequence: If a team commits deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) and cannot serve the penalty within the legal playing time or in Overtime, a Penalty Shot will be awarded against the offending Team.

qas.question: How is a Penalty Shot awarded against a team for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) different from other penalties?

answers.text: A Penalty Shot awarded for deliberate illegal substitution (too many players on the ice) is different from other penalties because it is given when a Bench Minor Penalty for this infraction cannot be fully served due to time constraints, resulting in a direct Penalty Shot against the offending team.

paragraphs.context: Once the Goalkeeper has been removed for an extra Attacker in Overtime during the game, they must wait for the next stoppage of play before returning to their position. Any attempt by the Goalkeeper to return to his position prior to the next stoppage of play (“on the fly”) shall be deemed to be an “illegal substitution” and a Bench Minor penalty shall be assessed for having an ineligible Player would apply.

qas.question: What penalty is assessed if a goalkeeper attempts to return to their position "on the fly" after being replaced by an extra attacker in overtime?

answers.text: If a goalkeeper attempts to return to their position "on the fly" after being replaced by an extra attacker in overtime, it results in an "illegal substitution" penalty, specifically a Bench Minor penalty.

qas.question: When can a goalkeeper who has been replaced by an extra attacker in overtime return to their position without incurring a penalty?

answers.text: The goalkeeper can return to their position without penalty during overtime only after the next stoppage of play.

qas.question: What is the consequence of a goalkeeper illegally substituting themselves back into the game before the next stoppage of play in overtime?

answers.text: The consequence of a goalkeeper illegally substituting themselves back into the game before the next stoppage of play in overtime is a Bench Minor penalty for having an ineligible player on the ice.

qas.question: In what situation would a Bench Minor penalty be assessed for having an ineligible player on the ice during overtime?

answers.text: A Bench Minor penalty would be assessed for having an ineligible player on the ice during overtime if the goalkeeper attempts to return to their position before the next stoppage of play.

qas.question: What action must a goalkeeper take if they have been replaced by an extra attacker in overtime and wish to return to their position legally?

answers.text: To return to their position legally after being replaced by an extra attacker in overtime, the goalkeeper must wait for the next stoppage of play. Any attempt to return "on the fly" results in an illegal substitution penalty.

paragraphs.context: Players, Coaches and team personnel are responsible for their conduct at all times and must endeavor to prevent disorderly conduct before, during or after the game, on or off the ice and any place in the Rink. The Referees may assess penalties to any of the above Team Personnel for failure to do so. When such conduct is directed at an official (Rule 39 – Abuse of Officials) shall be applied.

qas.question: Who is responsible for ensuring orderly conduct before, during, and after a hockey game, both on and off the ice?

answers.text: Players, coaches, and team personnel are responsible for ensuring orderly conduct before, during, and after a hockey game, both on and off the ice.

qas.question: What penalties can referees assess to players, coaches, and team personnel for failing to prevent disorderly conduct as outlined in the rule?

answers.text: Referees can assess penalties to players, coaches, and team personnel for failing to prevent disorderly conduct, especially if directed at an official, as outlined in the rule.

qas.question: In what situations can penalties be assessed for unsportsmanlike conduct directed at an official, according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: Penalties for unsportsmanlike conduct directed at an official can be assessed when players, coaches, or team personnel fail to prevent disorderly conduct before, during, or after the game, on or off the ice, or anywhere in the rink, as outlined in Rule 39 - Abuse of Officials.

qas.question: What specific type of conduct falls under the category of unsportsmanlike conduct as defined in the rule context?

answers.text: Unsportsmanlike conduct in hockey includes disorderly behavior by players, coaches, or team personnel on or off the ice, directed at officials, and can result in penalties being assessed.

qas.question: How does the rule address the responsibility of team personnel in maintaining proper conduct in the rink environment?

answers.text: The rule holds players, coaches, and team personnel accountable for maintaining proper conduct at all times in the rink environment. They are expected to prevent disorderly behavior before, during, and after the game, both on and off the ice. Referees can penalize team personnel who fail to uphold this responsibility, especially if the conduct is directed at an official.

paragraphs.context: A Minor Penalty for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) Any identifiable Player who uses obscene, profane or abusive language or gestures directed at any person. An additional Game Misconduct Penalty for use of obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks – refer to Rule 75.5 – Game Misconduct Penalty. (II) Any Player who is guilty of “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” including, but not limited to hair-pulling, grabbing hold of a face mask, banging with a stick or another object at the Boards or glass, etc. during the progress of the game or during a stoppage of play. Note: "If the Referee classifies physical offences committed to be serious and severe, based on the degree of force, the Referee may apply: (Rule 21 – Dangerous Actions) (III) Any Player who throws any object onto the ice from the Players’ or Penalty Box (or from any other off-ice location); (IV) A Player who deliberately removes their jersey or their helmet prior to participating in an altercation or who is clearly wearing a jersey that has been modified and does not conform to (Rule 9 – Uniforms) , shall be assessed a Minor Penalty for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” and a Game Misconduct. If the altercation never materializes, the Player shall receive a Minor Penalty for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” and a ten-minute (10) Misconduct Penalty for deliberately removing their jersey. If a penalized Player is assessed an additional “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” penalty either before or after they begin serving their original penalties, the additional Minor Penalty is added to their unexpired time and served consecutively.

qas.question: What specific actions can result in a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: Actions that can result in a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" include using obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures, engaging in unsportsmanlike behavior like hair-pulling or banging objects during play, throwing objects onto the ice, and deliberately removing a jersey or helmet before an altercation.

qas.question: When can a Player receive an additional Game Misconduct Penalty under the rule for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct"?

answers.text: A Player can receive an additional Game Misconduct Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" if they use obscene gestures, racial slurs, taunts, or sexual remarks, as outlined in Rule 75.5.

qas.question: What penalty can be assessed to a Player who throws an object onto the ice from the Players' or Penalty Box?

answers.text: A Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" is assessed to a Player who throws an object onto the ice from the Players' or Penalty Box.

qas.question: How is a Player penalized for deliberately removing their jersey or helmet prior to participating in an altercation?

answers.text: A player is penalized with a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" and a Game Misconduct if they deliberately remove their jersey or helmet before participating in an altercation. If the altercation does not happen, the player receives a Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" and a ten-minute Misconduct Penalty for removing their jersey.

qas.question: If a penalized Player receives an additional "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" penalty before or after serving their original penalties, how is the additional Minor Penalty served?

answers.text: The additional Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" is added to the penalized Player's unexpired time and served consecutively if received before or after serving their original penalties.

paragraphs.context: A Bench Minor Penalty for “Unsportsmanlike Conduct” shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) When any unidentifiable player, Coach or team personnel throws any object onto the ice from the Players’ or Penalty Box (or from any other off-ice location) or is banging with a stick or another object at the Boards or glass, etc. during the progress of the game or during a stoppage of play. (II) Any unidentifiable Player or any Coach or team personnel uses obscene, profane, or abusive language or gesture directed towards any person or is banging with a stick or another object at the Boards or glass, etc. (III) Whenever Coaches and/or non-playing Club personnel uses obscene or profane language or gestures anywhere in the Rink. An additional Game Misconduct Penalty for use of obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks – refer to Rule 75.5 – Game Misconduct Penalty.

qas.question: What specific actions can result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: Actions that can result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "Unsportsmanlike Conduct" include throwing objects onto the ice, banging objects at the boards or glass, using obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures, and using obscene language or gestures anywhere in the rink.

qas.question: When can a Bench Minor Penalty be assessed for unsportsmanlike conduct related to throwing objects onto the ice?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty can be assessed for unsportsmanlike conduct related to throwing objects onto the ice when any unidentifiable player, coach, or team personnel does so during the game or a stoppage of play.

qas.question: In what situations can a Bench Minor Penalty be given for using obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty can be given for using obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures when any unidentifiable player, coach, or team personnel directs such behavior towards any person during a game.

qas.question: Who can be penalized with a Bench Minor Penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct under the rule context?

answers.text: Players, coaches, and team personnel can be penalized with a Bench Minor Penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct if they throw objects onto the ice, bang objects at the boards or glass, or use obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures towards others during a game.

qas.question: What additional penalty can be given for the use of obscene gestures, racial slurs, taunts, or sexual remarks as outlined in the rule context?

answers.text: An additional Game Misconduct Penalty can be given for the use of obscene gestures, racial slurs, taunts, or sexual remarks as outlined in Rule 75.5.

paragraphs.context: Misconduct penalties shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) Any Player who persists in using obscene, profane, or abusive language directed towards any person after being assessed a minor or Bench Minor Penalty under this rule. An additional Game Misconduct Penalty for use of obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks – refer to Rule 75.5 – Game Misconduct Penalty. (II) Any Player who deliberately throws any equipment out of the playing area. At the discretion of a Game Official, a Game Misconduct Penalty may be imposed. (III) Any Player who persists in any course of conduct (including threatening or abusive language or gestures or similar actions) designed to incite an opponent into incurring a penalty. (IV) When a penalized Player challenges or disputes the ruling of an Official after they have already entered the Penalty Box and play has resumed. (V) In general, participants displaying this type of behavior are assessed a Minor Penalty, then a Misconduct Penalty and then a Game Misconduct Penalty if they persist.

qas.question: What type of penalties shall be assessed for a player who persists in using obscene, profane, or abusive language directed towards any person after being assessed a minor or Bench Minor Penalty under the unsportsmanlike conduct rule?

answers.text: A player persisting in using obscene, profane, or abusive language after receiving a minor or Bench Minor Penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct will be assessed a Misconduct Penalty. If the behavior includes obscene gestures, racial slurs, taunts, or sexual remarks, a Game Misconduct Penalty may also be given.

qas.question: When can a Game Misconduct Penalty be imposed on a player for deliberately throwing equipment out of the playing area according to the unsportsmanlike conduct rule?

answers.text: A Game Misconduct Penalty can be imposed on a player for deliberately throwing equipment out of the playing area as per the unsportsmanlike conduct rule.

qas.question: What type of conduct can result in a misconduct penalty for a player who persists in inciting an opponent into incurring a penalty?

answers.text: Persisting in inciting an opponent into incurring a penalty can result in a misconduct penalty for a player under the rule that addresses conduct designed to provoke opponents into penalties.

qas.question: When can a Game Misconduct Penalty be imposed on a penalized player challenging or disputing the ruling of an official after they have entered the Penalty Box and play has resumed?

answers.text: A Game Misconduct Penalty can be imposed on a penalized player challenging or disputing the ruling of an official after they have entered the Penalty Box and play has resumed.

qas.question: According to the unsportsmanlike conduct rule, what sequence of penalties are participants assessed for displaying threatening or abusive behavior towards opponents?

answers.text: Participants displaying threatening or abusive behavior towards opponents are assessed a Minor Penalty, followed by a Misconduct Penalty, and then a Game Misconduct Penalty if the behavior persists.

paragraphs.context: Game Misconduct penalties shall be assessed under this rule for the following infractions: (I) If a Player persists in any course of conduct for which they were previously assessed a Misconduct Penalty. (II) Any Player, Coach or team personnel who uses obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks, during or after the game, on or off the ice and any location while in the arena and its connected premises. The Referee shall report the circumstances to the Proper Authorities for further disciplinary action. (III) Coaches and team personnel who have previously been assessed a Bench Minor Penalty for the use obscene or profane language or gestures anywhere in the Rink. The Referee shall report the circumstances to the Proper Authorities for further disciplinary action. (IV) Any Player, Coach, or other team personnel whose actions, toward a Coach or other non-playing Team Personnel, could in any way cause injury. The Referee shall report the circumstances to the Proper Authorities for further disciplinary action. (V) Any Player, Coach, or non-playing Club personnel who directs obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures to any person after the expiration of the game. This action may occur on or off the ice. (VI) Any Player, Coach, or team personnel who spits on or at an opponent or anyone in the Rink during a game. (VII) A bleeding Player who intentionally smears blood from their body onto an opponent or anyone anywhere in the Rink.

qas.question: What type of conduct can result in a Game Misconduct penalty if a Player persists in it after being previously assessed a Misconduct Penalty?

answers.text: Persisting in conduct for which a Player was previously assessed a Misconduct Penalty can result in a Game Misconduct penalty.

qas.question: When can a Game Misconduct penalty be assessed for the use of obscene gestures, racial slurs, or sexual remarks by a Player, Coach, or team personnel?

answers.text: A Game Misconduct penalty can be assessed for the use of obscene gestures, racial slurs, or sexual remarks by a Player, Coach, or team personnel during or after the game, on or off the ice, and in any location within the arena and its connected premises. The Referee must report the incident to the Proper Authorities for further disciplinary action.

qas.question: In what situation can Coaches and team personnel receive a Game Misconduct penalty for using obscene or profane language or gestures in the Rink?

answers.text: Coaches and team personnel can receive a Game Misconduct penalty for using obscene or profane language or gestures in the rink if they have previously been assessed a Bench Minor Penalty for such behavior.

qas.question: When can a Game Misconduct penalty be given to a Player, Coach, or other team personnel for actions that could potentially cause injury to a Coach or other non-playing Team Personnel?

answers.text: A Game Misconduct penalty can be given to a Player, Coach, or other team personnel if their actions towards a Coach or other non-playing Team Personnel could potentially cause injury.

qas.question: What action can lead to a Game Misconduct penalty for a Player, Coach, or non-playing Club personnel directing obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures after the game has ended?

answers.text: Directing obscene, profane, or abusive language or gestures after the game has ended can lead to a Game Misconduct penalty for a Player, Coach, or non-playing Club personnel.

paragraphs.context: It is the responsibility of all Game Officials to send a report to the Proper Authorities setting out the full details concerning the use of obscene gestures, racial slurs or taunts or sexual remarks or language by any Player, Coach, team personnel or other Team official. If deemed appropriate, Supplementary Discipline can be applied by the Proper Authorities at their discretion. (Rule 28 – Supplementary Discipline)

qas.question: What type of behavior can result in Supplementary Discipline according to the rule on UNSPORTSMANLIKE CONDUCT?
