answers.text: The Proper Authorities handle incidents of unsportsmanlike conduct in hockey by receiving reports from Game Officials detailing inappropriate behavior and applying Supplementary Discipline as needed.

qas.question: How are obscene gestures, racial slurs, or sexual remarks addressed in the context of Supplementary Discipline in hockey?

answers.text: Obscene gestures, racial slurs, or sexual remarks in hockey are addressed by Game Officials reporting the incident to the Proper Authorities for potential Supplementary Discipline as per Rule 28.

paragraphs.context: The action of the Referee or Linesperson in dropping the puck between the sticks of two opposing Players to start or resume play is called a “face-off”. A “face-off” begins when the Official indicates the “location of the “face-off” and the Officials and Players take their appropriate positions. The “face-off” ends when the puck has been legally dropped. A Goalkeeper may not participate in a “face-off”.

qas.question: What is the action called when the Referee or Linesperson drops the puck between two opposing Players to start or resume play?

answers.text: The action is called a "face-off."

qas.question: When does a face-off begin according to the rule?

answers.text: A face-off begins when the Official indicates the location, and the Officials and Players take their positions.

qas.question: When does a face-off end based on the rule?

answers.text: A face-off ends when the puck has been legally dropped.

qas.question: Who is not allowed to participate in a face-off according to the rule context?

answers.text: Goalkeepers are not allowed to participate in a face-off according to the rule context.

qas.question: What must the Official indicate before a face-off can take place?

answers.text: Before a face-off can take place in hockey, the Official must indicate the location of the face-off.

paragraphs.context: All “face-off” must be conducted on one of the nine (9) Face-off Spots located on the Rink. If two (2) rule violations are the reason for the stoppage of play (e.g.: “high-sticking the puck” and “intentional off-side”), the ensuing “face-off location” shall be determined as the spot that provides the least amount of “territorial advantage” to the offending Team. When the play is stopped for any reason not specifically attributable to either Team while the puck is in the Neutral Zone, the ensuing “face-off” shall be conducted at the nearest Face-off Spot outside the Blue Line whenever possible. When it is unclear as to which of the four (4) Face-off Spots is the nearest, the spot that gives the Home Team the greatest “territorial advantage” in the Neutral Zone will be selected for the ensuing “face-off”. When Players are penalized at a stoppage of play so as to result in penalties being placed on the penalty time clock to one Team, the ensuing “face-off” shall be conducted at one of the two (2) Face-off Spots in the offending Team’s Defending Zone. There are only three (3) exceptions to this application: (I) when a penalty is assessed after the scoring of a goal – “face-off” shall be conducted at Center ice; (II) when a penalty is assessed at the end (or start) of a period – “face-off” shall be conducted at Center ice; (III) or when the defending Team is penalized, and the attacking Players enter the Attacking Zone beyond the outer edge of the End Zone Face-off Circle – “face-off” shall be conducted in the Neutral Zone. The Team awarded the “Power-Play” will have the choice of which End Zone spot the “face-off” will take place at to start the “Power-Play”. When an infringement of a rule has been committed by Players of both Teams in the play resulting in the stoppage, the ensuing “face-off” will be conducted at the nearest Face-off Spot in that zone. When stoppage occurs between the end Face-off Spots and near end of the Rink, the puck shall be faced-off at the end Face-off Spot on the side where the stoppage occurs unless otherwise expressly provided by these rules. No “face-off” shall be made within 4.50 m of the goal or side Boards nor anywhere other than at a Face-off Spot. When a goal is illegally scored as a result of a puck being deflected directly off an Official, the resulting “face-off” shall be made at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the puck deflected off of the Official. When a goal is illegally scored by the attacking Team by “directing”, “batting”, “kicking” or “high-sticking” the puck into the goal, the resulting “face-off” shall take place in the Neutral Zone at the nearest Face-off Spot. When the game is stopped for any reason not specifically covered in the official rules, the puck must be “faced-off” at a Face-off Spot in the zone nearest to where it was last played. Following a stoppage of play, should one or both defensemen who are the “point Players” or any Player coming from the Players’ Bench of the attacking Team, enter into the Attacking Zone beyond the outer edge of the End Zone Face-off Circle during an altercation, “gathering or scrum”, the ensuing “face-off” shall take place in the Neutral Zone near the Blue Line of the defending Team. This rule also applies when an “icing”, an “intentional off-side”, or a penalty has been assessed, and the ensuing “face-off” is to be in the offending Team’s Defending Zone. Should any of the non-offending Players enter the Attacking Zone beyond the outer edge of the End Zone Face-off Circle during an altercation, “gathering or scrum”, the ensuing “face-off” shall take place in the Neutral Zone near the Blue Line of the defending Team. For a violation of (Rule 71 – Premature Substitution) the resulting “face-off” will take place at the Center ice Face-off Spot when play is stopped beyond the Center red line. When play is stopped prior to the Center red line, the resulting “face-off” shall be conducted at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the play was stopped. When play is stopped for an injured Player, the ensuing “face-off” shall be conducted at the Face-off Spot in the zone nearest the location of the puck when the play was stopped. When the injured Player’s Team has “control of the puck” in the Attacking Zone, the “face-off” shall be conducted at one of the Face-off Spots outside the Blue Line in the Neutral Zone. When the injured Player is in their Defending Zone and the attacking Team is in “control of the puck” in the Attacking Zone, the “face-off” shall be conducted at one of the defending Team’s end-zone Face-off Spots.

qas.question: Where should a face-off be conducted if two rule violations are the reason for the stoppage of play?

answers.text: If two rule violations cause a stoppage of play in hockey, the face-off location will be determined to provide the least territorial advantage to the offending team.

qas.question: What determines the location of a face-off when play is stopped for any reason not specifically attributable to either team while the puck is in the Neutral Zone?

answers.text: When play is stopped for any reason not specifically attributable to either team while the puck is in the Neutral Zone, the face-off location will be conducted at the nearest Face-off Spot outside the Blue Line whenever possible.

qas.question: In what situations will the face-off be conducted at one of the two Face-off Spots in the offending team's Defending Zone?

answers.text: The face-off will be conducted at one of the two Face-off Spots in the offending team's Defending Zone when penalties are assessed resulting in penalties being placed on the penalty time clock to one team.

qas.question: Where will the face-off take place if a goal is illegally scored by the attacking team by directing, batting, kicking, or high-sticking the puck into the goal?

answers.text: If a goal is illegally scored by the attacking team by directing, batting, kicking, or high-sticking the puck into the goal, the resulting face-off shall take place in the Neutral Zone at the nearest Face-off Spot.

qas.question: What is the procedure for conducting a face-off when play is stopped for an injured player in different zones of the rink?

answers.text: When play is stopped for an injured player in different zones of the rink, the ensuing face-off shall be conducted at the Face-off Spot in the zone nearest the location of the puck when the play was stopped.

paragraphs.context: As soon as the line change procedure has been completed by the Referee and they lower their hand to indicate no further changes, the Linesperson conducting the “face-off” shall blow their whistle. This will signal to both Teams that they have no more than five (5) seconds to line up for the ensuing “face-off”. At the end of the five (5) seconds (or sooner if both centers are ready), the Linesperson will conduct a proper “face-off”. However if: (I) One or both centers are not positioned for the “face-off”, (II) One or both centers refrain from placing their stick on the ice, (III) Any Player has encroached into the Face-off Circle, (IV) Any Player makes physical contact with an opponent, (V) Any Player who lines up for the “face-off” in an off-side position, or (VI) One of the centers wins the face-off by using the skates, the Linesperson shall have the offending center(s) may assess a warning for a “face-off” violation prior to dropping the puck. In the last two (2) minutes of regulation time or any time in Overtime, the Linesperson will still blow their whistle to initiate the “face-off”, but the five (5) second time limit will not be enforced. However, Players must abide by the verbal directions given by the Linesperson in their attempt to conduct a fast and fair “face-off”.

qas.question: How long do teams have to line up for a face-off after the Linesperson blows their whistle?

answers.text: Teams have five (5) seconds to line up for a face-off after the Linesperson blows their whistle.

qas.question: What actions can result in a warning for a face-off violation before the puck is dropped?

answers.text: Actions that can result in a warning for a face-off violation before the puck is dropped include: not being positioned for the face-off, not placing the stick on the ice, encroaching into the Face-off Circle, making physical contact with an opponent, lining up off-side, or winning the face-off using skates.

qas.question: What happens if a player lines up for a face-off in an off-side position?

answers.text: If a player lines up for a face-off in an off-side position, the Linesperson may assess a warning for a "face-off" violation before dropping the puck.

qas.question: In the last two minutes of regulation time or during overtime, is the five-second time limit for lining up for a face-off still enforced?

answers.text: No, the five-second time limit for lining up for a face-off is not enforced in the last two minutes of regulation time or during overtime in hockey.

qas.question: What must players do in the last two minutes of regulation time or during overtime when the five-second time limit is not enforced for face-offs?

answers.text: In the last two minutes of regulation time or during overtime, players must follow verbal directions from the Linesperson for face-offs when the five-second time limit is not enforced.

paragraphs.context: The puck shall be faced-off by the Referee or the Linesperson dropping the puck on the ice between the sticks of the Players facing-off. Players facing-off will stand squarely facing their opponent’s end of the Rink approximately one stick length apart with the blade of their sticks on the ice. When the “face-off” takes place at any of the nine Face-off Spots, the Players taking part shall take their position so that they will stand squarely facing their opponent’s end of the Rink, and clear of the ice markings (where applicable). The sticks of both Players facing-off shall have the blade on the ice, within the designated white area. At the eight (8) Face-off Spots (excluding Center ice Faceoff Spot), the defending Player shall place their stick within the designated white area first followed immediately by the attacking Player. When the “face-off” is conducted at the Center ice Face-off Spot, the visiting Player shall place their stick on the ice first. If a Player facing-off fails to take their proper position immediately when directed by the On-ice Official, the Official may assess a warning for a “face-off” violation. If a center is not at the designated “face-off” area once the five (5) second time limit has elapsed, the Linesperson will drop the puck immediately. If the center is back from the Face-off Spot, is “quarterbacking” or refuses to come into the “face-off” area when instructed to do so by the Linesperson, or the center is simply slow getting to the Face-off Spot when the five (5) seconds has elapsed, the puck shall be dropped. If the center attempts to arrive at the Face-off Spot just as the five seconds elapses in an attempt to gain an advantage to win the “face-off”, the center will be warned by the Linesperson that they have committed a “face-off” violation. If a Player received a warning for a “face-off” violation, they must come into position quickly or risk having the puck dropped by the Linesperson without the Player being set or will result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” for a second “face-off” violation during the same “face-off”.

qas.question: What is the required distance between Players facing-off in a hockey game?

answers.text: Players facing-off in a hockey game must stand one stick length apart.

qas.question: In a face-off at the Center ice Face-off Spot, which Player should place their stick on the ice first?

answers.text: At the Center ice Face-off Spot, the visiting Player should place their stick on the ice first.

qas.question: What action may the On-ice Official take if a Player facing-off fails to take their proper position immediately when directed?

answers.text: If a Player facing-off fails to take their proper position immediately when directed, the On-ice Official may assess a warning for a "face-off" violation.

qas.question: What will happen if a center is not at the designated face-off area once the five-second time limit has elapsed?

answers.text: If a center is not at the designated face-off area once the five-second time limit has elapsed, the Linesperson will drop the puck immediately.

qas.question: When will the Linesperson drop the puck immediately during a face-off procedure?

answers.text: The Linesperson will drop the puck immediately during a face-off procedure if the center fails to take their proper position within five seconds or if they are slow to get to the Face-off Spot.

paragraphs.context: No other Player shall be allowed to enter the Face-off Circle or come within 4.5 m of the Players facing-off. All Players must stand on-side on all “face-offs”. During end-zone “face-offs”, all other Players on the ice must position their bodies on their own side of the restraining lines marked on the outer edge of the Face-off Circles. If a Player other than the Player taking the “face-off” moves into the Face-off Circle prior to the dropping of the puck, then the offending Team taking the “face-off” shall receive a warning for a “face-off” violation. Players on the attacking Team (exclusive of the center) must establish their position first and then the defending Team may counter and hold its position until the puck is dropped. A violation of this procedure shall be treated as “face-off” encroachment and the Linesperson shall assess a warning for a “face-off” violation to the offending Team. Should an attacking Player attempt to establish a new position prior to the “face-off”, and the defending center steps back from the Face-off Spot in order to reposition their Teammates, the “face-off” violation shall be charged to the attacking Team as they must establish their position first.

qas.question: What is the maximum distance allowed for any Player to come near the Players facing-off during a face-off?

answers.text: The maximum distance allowed for any Player to come near the Players facing-off during a face-off is 4.5 meters.

qas.question: What action will be taken if a Player from the offending Team enters the Face-off Circle before the puck is dropped?

answers.text: If a Player from the offending Team enters the Face-off Circle before the puck is dropped, the offending Team will receive a warning for a "face-off" violation.

qas.question: How should Players on the attacking Team position themselves in relation to the Face-off Circle before the puck is dropped?

answers.text: Players on the attacking Team (excluding the center) must establish their positions first around the Face-off Circle before the puck is dropped.

qas.question: What will happen if an attacking Player tries to change their position before the face-off while the defending center adjusts their teammates' positions?

answers.text: If an attacking Player tries to change their position before the face-off while the defending center adjusts their teammates' positions, the face-off violation will be charged to the attacking Team as they must establish their position first.

qas.question: What is the consequence of a face-off violation known as "face-off encroachment" according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: The consequence of a face-off violation known as "face-off encroachment" is that the offending Team taking the face-off shall receive a warning for the violation.

paragraphs.context: If a center should move prematurely prior to the “face-off”, or if the Referee or Linesperson shall have dropped the puck unfairly, the “face-off” shall be considered a “face-off” violation. A warning shall be issued to the offending Team and the “face-off” must be conducted again. When two (2) “face-off” violations” have been committed by the same Team during the same “face-off”, this Team shall be penalized with a Bench Minor Penalty to the offending Team. This penalty shall be announced as a “Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” – Face-off Violation.” “Face-off” violations shall be summarized as follows (any of the four (4) On-ice Officials may identify a “face-off” violation): (I) Encroachment by any Player other than the center into the “face-off” area prior to the puck being dropped. Players on the perimeter of the Face-off Circle must keep both skates outside the Face-off Circle – skate contact with the line is permitted. If a Player's skate crosses the line into the Face-off Circle prior to the drop of the puck, this shall be deemed as a “face-off” violation. A Player's stick may be inside the Face-off Circle provided there is no physical contact with their opponent or their opponent's stick. (II) Encroachment by any Player into the area between the hash marks on the outer edges of the Face-off Circle prior to the puck being dropped. Players must also ensure that both of their skates do not cross their respective hash marks. Contact with the line with their skate is permitted. If a Player's skate crosses the line into the area between the hash marks prior to the drop of the puck, this shall be deemed as a “face-off” violation. A Player's stick may be inside the area between the hash marks provided there is no physical contact with their opponent or their opponent's stick. (III) Any physical contact with an opponent prior to the puck being dropped. If either Player taking the “face-off” makes helmet-to-helmet contact with their opponent, they must receive a first “face-off” violation warning. If the Linesperson cannot differentiate which Player initiated the contact, both Players must receive a first “face-off” violation warning. (IV) Failure by either center taking the “face-off” to “properly position themself behind the restraining lines” or place their stick on the ice – as outlined in Rule 76.4 – Face-off Procedure – Centers. "Properly position themself behind the restraining lines" shall mean that the center must place their feet on either side of the restraining lines that are parallel to the side Boards (contact with the lines is permissible), and the toe of the blade of their skates must not cross over the restraining lines that are perpendicular to the side Boards as they approach the Face-off Spot. The blade of the stick must then be placed on the ice, at least the toe of the blade of the stick, in the designated white area of the Face-off Spot and must remain there until the puck is dropped. (V) Failure to comply with this positioning and “face-off” procedure will result in a “face-off” violation. Whenever a Team has committed two (2) “face-off” violations during the same “face-off”, the Referee shall immediately assess the offending Team a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game”. This penalty shall be announced as a Bench Minor Penalty for Delay of Game – Face-off Violation. Players who are late to the “face-off” location and therefore in an off-side position for the ensuing “face-off” will be warned once in the game by the Referee. This warning will also be given to the offending Team’s Coach. In this situation, the offending Team’s center will not receive a warning for a “face-off” violation. Any subsequent violation shall result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” being assessed to the offending Team. This penalty shall be announced as a “Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” – Slow Proceeding to Face-off Location. In the conduct of any “face-off” at any of the nine (9) Face-off Spots on the playing surface, no Player facing-off shall make any physical contact with their opponent’s body by means of their own body or by their stick except in the course of playing the puck after the “face-off” has been completed. For violation of this rule, the Referee may, at their discretion impose a Minor Penalty or penalties on the Player(s) whose action(s) caused the “physical contact”. Nonetheless, this “physical contact” prior to the dropping of the puck shall be deemed as a “face-off” violation and the center will be warned by the Linesperson that the Team has committed a “face-off” violation and any subsequent violation will result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” – “face-off” violation being assessed. “Face-off” encroachment may be applied during “face-offs” at any of the nine (9) Face-off Spots on the playing surface However, since no such lines are painted on the ice at the four (4) Face-off Spots adjacent to the Blue Lines, Linespersons shall use their judgment as to whether or not a violation has occurred. All Players, other than the centers, shall be uniformly back from the “face-off” location similar to being outside the Face-off Circle for “face-offs” in the End Zones.

qas.question: What constitutes a "face-off" violation related to encroachment by a player into the face-off area prior to the puck being dropped?

answers.text: A "face-off" violation related to encroachment occurs when any player other than the center enters the face-off area before the puck is dropped. This includes having both skates outside the face-off circle and no physical contact with opponents.

qas.question: How many "face-off" violations by the same team during the same "face-off" will result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game"?

answers.text: Two "face-off" violations by the same team during the same "face-off" will result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game."

qas.question: What specific actions by a player during a face-off would be considered a violation related to physical contact with an opponent?

answers.text: Any physical contact with an opponent prior to the puck being dropped during a face-off would be considered a violation related to physical contact with an opponent.

qas.question: What positioning requirements must the center taking the face-off adhere to in order to avoid a "face-off" violation?

answers.text: The center taking the face-off must position themselves behind the restraining lines with their feet on either side, ensuring their skate blade does not cross over the lines. Their stick must be placed on the ice in the designated white area of the Face-off Spot and remain there until the puck is dropped to avoid a face-off violation.

qas.question: How many warnings are given to a player who is late to the face-off location and in an off-side position before a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" is assessed?

answers.text: A player who is late to the face-off location and in an off-side position will receive one warning before a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" is assessed.

paragraphs.context: No substitution of Players shall be permitted until the “face-off” has been completed and play has resumed except when a penalty is imposed which affects the on-ice strength of either Team. Should an On-ice Official notice that the defending Team has not placed enough Players on the ice for the ensuing “face-off”, the Referee in the Neutral Zone shall be notified and they will instruct the offending Team to place another Player(s) on the ice. If, in the opinion of the Referee that this is being done as a “stalling tactic”, they will issue a warning to the offending Team’s Coach and any subsequent violations shall result in the assessment of a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game”. Should an On-ice Official notice that the attacking Team has not placed enough Players on the ice for the ensuing “face-off”, the Linesperson will proceed with conducting the “face-off” in the normal manner. The attacking Team must ensure they put the appropriate number of Players on the ice at all times.

qas.question: When can substitutions of Players be made during a face-off according to the rule?

answers.text: Substitutions of Players during a face-off can only be made after the face-off has been completed and play has resumed, except when a penalty affects the on-ice strength of a Team.

qas.question: What action will the Referee take if the defending Team does not have enough Players on the ice for a face-off?

answers.text: If the defending Team does not have enough Players on the ice for a face-off, the Referee will instruct them to add more Players. If it appears to be intentional, a warning may be issued, and repeated violations can lead to a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game."

qas.question: How does the rule address the situation where the attacking Team does not have enough Players on the ice for a face-off?

answers.text: If the attacking team does not have enough players on the ice for a face-off, the Linesperson will proceed with the face-off as usual. The attacking team must ensure they have the correct number of players on the ice at all times.

qas.question: What penalty may be assessed for a team using a "stalling tactic" by not having enough Players on the ice for a face-off?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" may be assessed for a team using a stalling tactic by not having enough Players on the ice for a face-off.

qas.question: Who is responsible for ensuring the attacking Team has the appropriate number of Players on the ice for a face-off according to the rule?

answers.text: The attacking team is responsible for ensuring they have the correct number of players on the ice for a face-off according to the rule.

paragraphs.context: Any loss of time on the game or penalty clocks due to a false “face-off” or a “face-off” violation must be replaced. The Video Review Consultant may be consulted to ensure the time is accurately replaced. (Rule 37.6 – Video Review to verify time on clock) The whistle will not be blown by the Official to start play. Playing time will commence from the instant the puck is “faced-off” and will stop when the whistle is blown, or a goal is scored.

qas.question: What must be done if there is a loss of time on the game or penalty clocks due to a false "face-off" or a "face-off" violation?

answers.text: If there is a loss of time on the game or penalty clocks due to a false "face-off" or a "face-off" violation, the lost time must be replaced. The Video Review Consultant may assist in ensuring accurate time replacement. The game clock will start when the puck is faced-off and stop when the whistle is blown or a goal is scored.

qas.question: Who may be consulted to ensure that time lost on the clocks is accurately replaced in the event of a false "face-off" or a "face-off" violation?

answers.text: The Video Review Consultant may be consulted to ensure accurate replacement of lost time on the clocks in the event of a false "face-off" or a "face-off" violation.

qas.question: When does playing time officially commence during a face-off procedure?

answers.text: Playing time officially commences during a face-off procedure from the instant the puck is "faced-off."

qas.question: When does playing time stop during a face-off procedure?

answers.text: Playing time stops during a face-off procedure when the whistle is blown or a goal is scored.

qas.question: Is the whistle blown by the Official to start play during a face-off procedure according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: No, the whistle is not blown by the Official to start play during a face-off procedure.

data.title: GAME FLOW - GAME AND INTERMISSION TIMING

paragraphs.context: The time allowed for a game shall be three (3) twenty-minute (20) periods of actual play with a rest intermission between periods.

qas.question: How many periods of actual play are allowed in a hockey game according to the rule?

answers.text: Answer: According to the rule, a hockey game allows for three periods of actual play.

qas.question: What is the duration of each period of actual play in a hockey game as specified in the rule?

answers.text: Each period of actual play in a hockey game lasts for twenty minutes.

qas.question: How long is the rest intermission between periods in a hockey game based on the rule?

answers.text: Answer: The rest intermission between periods in a hockey game is 15 minutes.

qas.question: What is the total duration of a standard hockey game, including both play time and intermissions, according to the rule?

answers.text: Answer: The total duration of a standard hockey game, including play time and intermissions, is approximately one hour and thirty minutes.

qas.question: How many minutes of actual play are there in a regulation hockey game as outlined in the rule?

answers.text: There are 60 minutes of actual play in a regulation hockey game as outlined in the rule.

paragraphs.context: Play shall be resumed promptly following each intermission upon the expiration of fifteen (15) minutes or a length of time designated by the IIHF from the completion of play in the preceding period. Timing of the intermission commences after termination of the period. (Rule 34 – Game Timekeeper) For the purpose of keeping the spectators informed as to the time remaining during intermissions, the Game Timekeeper will use the electronic clock to record length of intermissions.

qas.question: How long is the standard intermission time between periods in a hockey game according to the rule?

answers.text: The standard intermission time between periods in a hockey game is fifteen (15) minutes.

qas.question: When does the timing of the intermission officially begin according to the rule?

answers.text: The timing of the intermission officially begins after the termination of the period.

qas.question: Who is responsible for recording the length of intermissions using the electronic clock as per the rule?

answers.text: The Game Timekeeper is responsible for recording the length of intermissions using the electronic clock as per the rule.

qas.question: Can the intermission time be extended beyond the standard fifteen minutes as specified by the IIHF?

answers.text: No, the intermission time cannot be extended beyond the standard fifteen minutes specified by the IIHF.

qas.question: What specific action should be taken by the Game Timekeeper to resume play promptly following an intermission according to the rule?

answers.text: The Game Timekeeper should resume play promptly after an intermission by waiting for fifteen minutes or the IIHF-designated time from the end of the previous period and using the electronic clock to track intermission length.

paragraphs.context: If any unusual delay occurs within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods, the Referee may order the next regular intermission to be taken immediately. The balance of the period will be completed on the resumption of play with the Teams defending the same goals after which the Teams will change ends and resume play of the ensuing period without delay.

qas.question: What action can the Referee take if an unusual delay occurs within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods?

answers.text: The Referee can order the next intermission to be taken immediately if an unusual delay occurs within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods.

qas.question: When can the Referee order the next regular intermission to be taken immediately due to a delay?

answers.text: The Referee can order the next regular intermission to be taken immediately due to a delay if the delay occurs within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods.

qas.question: How is the balance of the period handled if an unusual delay occurs within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods?

answers.text: If an unusual delay occurs within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods, the Referee may order the next intermission to start immediately. The remaining time in the period will be completed when play resumes, with the teams defending the same goals. The teams will then switch ends and continue to the next period without delay.

qas.question: What happens to the Teams defending the goals if the Referee orders the next regular intermission to be taken immediately?

answers.text: If the Referee orders the next regular intermission to be taken immediately, the Teams defending the goals will continue to defend the same goals when play resumes.

qas.question: How should the Teams proceed after completing the balance of the period following an unusual delay within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods?

answers.text: After completing the balance of the period following an unusual delay within 10 minutes of the end of the first or second periods, the Teams should change ends and resume play of the ensuing period without delay.

paragraphs.context: It is the responsibility of the Referees to award goals and report the ”goal scorer” and “assists”, and their decision in this respect is final, notwithstanding the report of the Referee or any other Game Official. The Officials Scorekeeper, with the assistance of the Statistic staff will confirm the “goal scorer” and any Player deserving an “assist”. This decision is final in this regard and no changes can be made after the conclusion of the game. The use of video replay to verify the proper awarding of a goal or an assist is essential. Such awards shall be made or withheld strictly in accordance with the provisions of this rule. Therefore, it is essential that the Official Scorekeeper be thoroughly familiar with every aspect of this rule; be alerted to observe all actions which could affect the awarding of a goal or assist; and, above all, give or withhold awards with absolute impartiality. In case of an obvious error in awarding a goal or an assist that has been announced, it should be corrected promptly, but changes should not be made in the official scoring summary after the Referee has signed the game report. The Team scoring the greatest number of goals during the three (3) twenty-minute periods shall be the winner and shall be credited with three (3) points in the standings. In the event a winner during the Round Robin or Preliminary Round is determined in the Overtime period or the shootout, the winning Team shall be credited with two (2) points in the standings and the losing Team will be credited with one (1) point in the standings.

qas.question: Who is responsible for awarding goals and reporting the "goal scorer" and "assists" in a hockey game according to the rule?

answers.text: The Referees are responsible for awarding goals and reporting the "goal scorer" and "assists" in a hockey game according to the rule.

qas.question: What is the role of the Officials Scorekeeper and the Statistic staff in confirming the "goal scorer" and any Player deserving an "assist"?

answers.text: The Officials Scorekeeper and Statistic staff confirm the "goal scorer" and any Player deserving an "assist" in accordance with the Referees' decision. Their confirmation is final and no changes can be made after the game. Video replay is used to verify goal and assist awards, and corrections to obvious errors should be made promptly.

qas.question: How should the Official Scorekeeper handle the awarding or withholding of goals and assists according to the rule?

answers.text: The Official Scorekeeper should confirm the goal scorer and any players deserving an assist based on the Referees' decision, with the use of video replay if necessary. The decision is final and must be made impartially. Any errors should be promptly corrected, but changes cannot be made after the game concludes.

qas.question: When can changes be made to the official scoring summary after the conclusion of a hockey game?

answers.text: Changes to the official scoring summary cannot be made after the conclusion of a hockey game, as the decision on goals, assists, and scoring is final once the Referee has signed the game report.

qas.question: How are points awarded in the standings to teams based on the number of goals scored during the three twenty-minute periods and in overtime or shootout situations during the Round Robin or Preliminary Round?

answers.text: Teams are awarded three points in the standings for scoring the most goals during the three twenty-minute periods. In the event of a win in overtime or shootout during the Round Robin or Preliminary Round, the winning team gets two points, and the losing team gets one point.

paragraphs.context: A “goal” shall be credited in the scoring records to a Player who shall have propelled the puck into the opponent’s goal. Each “goal” shall count one point in the Player’s record. Only one point can be credited to any one Player on a goal.

qas.question: Who is credited with a goal in hockey scoring records?

answers.text: A goal in hockey scoring records is credited to the player who propels the puck into the opponent's goal, earning one point in the player's record. Only one point can be credited to any one player on a goal.

qas.question: How many points does a goal count for in a player's record?

paragraphs.context: When a Player scores a goal, an “assist” shall be credited to the Player or Players (maximum two) who touch the puck prior to the “goal scorer” provided no defender plays or has “control of the puck” subsequently. Each “assist” shall count one point in the Player’s record. Only one point can be credited to any one Player on a goal.

qas.question: How many assists can be credited on a goal in hockey?

answers.text: In hockey, a maximum of two assists can be credited on a goal.

qas.question: What condition must be met for a player to be credited with an assist on a goal?

answers.text: For a player to be credited with an assist on a goal in hockey, they must have touched the puck prior to the goal scorer without any defender subsequently playing or having control of the puck.

qas.question: How many points does each assist count for in a player's record?

answers.text: Each assist counts for one point in a player's record.

qas.question: Can more than one point be credited to a single player on a goal?

answers.text: No, only one point can be credited to any one player on a goal in hockey.

paragraphs.context: A goal shall be scored when the puck shall have been put between the Goal Posts by the stick of a Player of the attacking side, from in front and below the crossbar, and entirely across a red line the width of the diameter of the Goal Posts drawn on the ice from one Goal Post to the other with the goal frame in its proper position. The goal frame shall be considered in its proper position when at least a portion of the flexible peg(s) are still inside both the Goal post and the hole in the ice. The flexible pegs could be bent, but as long as at least a portion of the flexible peg(s) are still in the hole in the ice and the Goal Post, the goal frame shall be deemed to be in its proper position. The goal frame could be raised somewhat on one post (or both), but as long as the flexible pegs are still in contact with the holes in the ice and the Goal Posts, the goal frame shall not be deemed to be displaced. A goal shall be scored if the puck is shot into the goal by a Player of the defending side. The Player of the attacking side who last touched the puck shall be credited with the goal, but no assist shall be awarded. A goal shall be scored if the puck is put into the goal in any other manner by a Player of the defending side. The Player of the attacking side who last touched the puck shall be credited with the goal and assists may be awarded. If an attacking Player has the puck deflect into the net, off their skate or body, in any manner, the goal shall be allowed. The Player who deflected the puck shall be credited with the goal. Should a Player legally propel a puck into the Goal Crease of the opponent Team and the puck should become loose and available to another Player of the attacking side, a goal scored on the play shall be legal.

qas.question: How is a goal scored in hockey according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: A goal is scored in hockey when the puck is put between the goal posts by a player of the attacking side from in front and below the crossbar, entirely crossing a red line the width of the goal posts' diameter, with the goal frame in its proper position.

qas.question: What are the specific criteria for a goal to be considered legal in hockey based on the rule context?

answers.text: A goal in hockey is legal when the puck is put between the goal posts by a player of the attacking side from in front and below the crossbar, entirely crossing a red line the width of the goal posts' diameter, with the goal frame in its proper position.

qas.question: Who is credited with a goal if the puck is shot into the goal by a player of the defending side?

answers.text: If the puck is shot into the goal by a player of the defending side, the player of the attacking side who last touched the puck will be credited with the goal, with no assist awarded.

qas.question: In what scenario would a goal be allowed if the puck is deflected into the net off a player's skate or body?

answers.text: A goal would be allowed if the puck is deflected into the net off a player's skate or body.

qas.question: If a player legally propels a puck into the opponent team's Goal Crease and it becomes available to another attacking player, is a goal scored on the play considered legal according to the rule context?

answers.text: Yes, a goal scored in the described scenario is considered legal according to the rule context.

paragraphs.context: Apparent goals shall be disallowed by the Referee and the appropriate announcement made by the Public Address Announcer for the following reasons: (I) When the puck has been directed with any part of their body (excl. skates), batted or thrown into the net by an attacking Player other than with a stick. When this occurs, if it is deemed to be done deliberately, then the decision shall be NO GOAL. A goal cannot be scored when the puck has been deliberately batted with any part of the attacking Player’s body into the net (Rule 78.4 – Scoring a Goal) (II) When the puck has been kicked using a distinct kicking motion (Rule 49.2 – Kicking) (III) When the puck has deflected directly into the net off an official (Rule 85.4 – Puck Striking Official) (IV) When a goal has been scored and an ineligible Player is on the ice (Rule 68.5 – Disallowed Goal) (V) When an attacking Player has interfered with a Goalkeeper in their Goal Crease (Rule 69.1 – Interference on the Goalkeeper) (VI) When the puck has entered the net after making contact with an attacking Player’s stick that is above the height of the crossbar. Where the puck makes contact with the stick is the determining factor (Rule 80.3 – Disallowed Goal) (VII) When Video Review confirms the scoring of a goal at one end of the ice, any goal scored at the other end on the same play must be disallowed (Rule 37.2 – Video Review) (VIII) When a Linesperson reports a Double-minor Penalty for high-sticking or a Major Penalty to the Referee following the scoring of a goal by the offending Team, the goal must be disallowed, and the appropriate penalty assessed (Rule 32.4 – Reporting to Referee) (IX) When a Goalkeeper has been pushed into the net together with the puck after making a save (Rule 69.7 – Rebounds and Loose Pucks) (X) When the net becomes displaced accidentally. The goal frame is considered to be displaced if either or both goal pegs are no longer in their respective holes in the ice, or the net has come completely off one or both pegs, prior to or as the puck enters the goal. However, if this occurs as a result of the actions of a defending player, refer to (Rule 63.7 – Awarded Goal) (XI) During the delayed calling of a penalty, the offending Team cannot score unless the non-offending Team shoots the puck into their own net. This shall mean that a deflection off an offending Player or any physical action by an offending Player that may cause the puck to enter the non-offending Team’s goal, shall not be considered a legal goal. Play shall be stopped before the puck enters the net (whenever possible) and the signaled penalty assessed to the offending Team; (XII) When the Referee deems the play has been stopped, even if they have not physically had the opportunity to stop play by blowing their whistle; (XIII) Any goal scored, other than as covered by the official rules, shall not be allowed.

qas.question: When can a goal be disallowed if the puck has been directed into the net by an attacking Player using any part of their body other than a stick?

answers.text: A goal can be disallowed if the puck is directed into the net by an attacking player using any part of their body other than a stick, and it is deemed to be done deliberately.

qas.question: What is the specific reason for disallowing a goal if the puck has been kicked into the net with a distinct kicking motion?

answers.text: A goal is disallowed if the puck is kicked into the net with a distinct kicking motion, as per Rule 49.2 - Kicking.

qas.question: In what scenario would a goal be disallowed if the puck deflects directly into the net off an official?

answers.text: A goal would be disallowed if the puck deflects directly into the net off an official according to Rule 85.4 – Puck Striking Official.

qas.question: Why would a goal be disallowed if an ineligible Player is on the ice when a goal is scored?

answers.text: A goal would be disallowed if an ineligible player is on the ice when a goal is scored to maintain fairness and uphold the rules of the game.

qas.question: When can a goal be disallowed if the puck enters the net after making contact with an attacking Player's stick that is above the height of the crossbar?

answers.text: A goal can be disallowed if the puck enters the net after making contact with an attacking player's stick that is above the height of the crossbar.

paragraphs.context: A Player shall be permitted to stop or “bat” a puck in the air with their open hand, or push it along the ice with their hand, and the play shall not be stopped unless, in the opinion of the On-ice Officials, they have directed the puck to a Teammate, or have allowed their Team to gain an advantage, and subsequently possession and control of the puck is obtained by a Player of the offending Team, either directly or deflected off any Player or official. For violations related to “closing their hand on the puck”, refer to Handling Puck: (Rule 67 – Handling Puck)

qas.question: Can a player bat a puck in the air with their open hand according to the Hand Pass rule?

answers.text: No, a player cannot bat a puck in the air with their open hand according to the Hand Pass rule.

qas.question: When will a play involving a hand pass be stopped by the On-ice Officials?

answers.text: A play involving a hand pass will be stopped by the On-ice Officials if the player directs the puck to a teammate or gains an advantage, leading to possession by a player of the offending team.

qas.question: What actions by a player would lead to a play being stopped due to a hand pass violation?

answers.text: A play would be stopped due to a hand pass violation if a player directs the puck to a teammate or gains an advantage by using their hand, leading to their team gaining possession and control of the puck.

qas.question: In what situations can a player push a puck along the ice with their hand without the play being stopped?

answers.text: A player can push a puck along the ice with their hand without the play being stopped unless they direct it to a teammate or gain an advantage for their team.

qas.question: How can possession and control of the puck be regained by the offending Team after a hand pass violation?

answers.text: The offending Team can regain possession and control of the puck after a hand pass violation if a Player of the offending Team gains possession and control of the puck, either directly or through a deflection off any Player or official.

paragraphs.context: Play will not be stopped for any hand pass by Players in their own Defending Zone. The location of the puck when contacted by either the Player making the hand pass or the Player receiving the hand pass shall determine the zone it is in.

qas.question: Will play be stopped for a hand pass by a player in their own Defending Zone?

answers.text: No, play will not be stopped for a hand pass by a player in their own Defending Zone.

qas.question: How is the zone of a hand pass determined in the Defending Zone?

answers.text: The zone of a hand pass in the Defending Zone is determined by the location of the puck when it is contacted by the Player making the pass or the Player receiving the pass.

qas.question: Who determines the zone of a hand pass in the Defending Zone?

answers.text: The zone of a hand pass in the Defending Zone is determined by the location of the puck when contacted by the Player making the hand pass or the Player receiving the hand pass.

qas.question: Does the location of the puck when contacted by the player making the hand pass affect the zone determination in the Defending Zone?

answers.text: Yes, the location of the puck when contacted by the player making the hand pass determines the zone it is in, including the Defending Zone.

qas.question: What happens if a player in their own Defending Zone makes a hand pass to a teammate in the same zone?

answers.text: If a player in their own Defending Zone makes a hand pass to a teammate in the same zone, play will continue as hand passes are allowed within the Defending Zone. The zone where the puck is when contacted by either player determines the legality of the pass.

paragraphs.context: When a hand pass violation has occurred, the ensuing “face-off” shall take place at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the offense occurred, unless the offending Team gains a territorial advantage, then the “face-off” shall be at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the stoppage of play occurred, unless otherwise covered in the rules. When a hand pass violation occurs by a Team in their Attacking Zone, the ensuing “face-off” shall be conducted at one of the Face-off Spots outside the defending Team’s Blue Line in the Neutral Zone.

qas.question: Where does the face-off take place after a hand pass violation in the attacking team's zone?

answers.text: After a hand pass violation in the attacking team's zone, the face-off takes place at one of the Face-off Spots outside the defending team's Blue Line in the Neutral Zone.

qas.question: What determines the location of the face-off after a hand pass violation if the offending team gains a territorial advantage?

answers.text: The location of the face-off after a hand pass violation is determined by whether the offending team gains a territorial advantage. If they do, the face-off will be at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the stoppage of play occurred.

qas.question: In which zone does the face-off occur if a hand pass violation happens in the attacking team's zone?

answers.text: If a hand pass violation occurs in the attacking team's zone, the face-off will take place at one of the face-off spots outside the defending team's blue line in the neutral zone.

qas.question: Where is the face-off conducted if a hand pass violation occurs in the attacking team's zone but the offending team gains a territorial advantage?

answers.text: If a hand pass violation occurs in the attacking team's zone and they gain a territorial advantage, the face-off will be conducted at one of the face-off spots outside the defending team's blue line in the neutral zone.

qas.question: What is the specific location for the face-off after a hand pass violation by a team in their Attacking Zone?

answers.text: After a hand pass violation by a team in their Attacking Zone, the face-off will take place at one of the Face-off Spots outside the defending Team’s Blue Line in the Neutral Zone.

paragraphs.context: Batting the puck above the normal height of the shoulders with a stick is prohibited. When a puck is struck with a “high stick” and subsequently comes into the “possession and control” of a Player from the offending Team (including the Player who made contact with the puck), either directly or deflected off any Player or official, there shall be a whistle. When a puck has been contacted by a “high stick”, the play shall be permitted to continue, provided that: (I) The puck has been batted to an opponent (when a Player bats the puck to an opponent, the Referee shall give the “washout” signal immediately – otherwise, they will stop the play). (II) A Player of the defending side shall bat the puck into their own goal in which case the goal shall be allowed. Cradling the puck on the blade of the stick (“lacrosse style”) above the normal height of the shoulders shall be prohibited and a stoppage of play shall result. If this is done by a Player on a “Penalty Shot” or Shootout attempt, the shot shall be stopped immediately and considered complete. (Rule 60 – High-sticking)

qas.question: What is the consequence if a player bats the puck above the normal height of the shoulders with a stick?

answers.text: Consequence: If a player bats the puck above the normal height of the shoulders with a stick, play will be stopped, and there will be a whistle.

qas.question: When a puck is struck with a "high stick" and comes into the possession and control of a player from the offending team, what action should the referee take?

answers.text: The referee should blow the whistle when a puck is struck with a "high stick" and comes into the possession and control of a player from the offending team.

qas.question: In what situations is play permitted to continue after a puck has been contacted by a "high stick"?

answers.text: Play is permitted to continue after a puck has been contacted by a "high stick" if the puck has been batted to an opponent or if a defending player bats the puck into their own goal.

qas.question: What is the result if a player bats the puck to an opponent after making contact with a "high stick"?

answers.text: If a player bats the puck to an opponent after making contact with a "high stick," the referee will give the "washout" signal immediately, and play will be stopped.

qas.question: When cradling the puck on the blade of the stick above the normal height of the shoulders, what will be the outcome according to the rule?

answers.text: Cradling the puck on the blade of the stick above the normal height of the shoulders is prohibited, and it will result in a stoppage of play according to Rule 60 - High-sticking in hockey.

paragraphs.context: When the play is stopped for the “high-sticking the puck” violation, the ensuing “face-off” must take place at the spot that provides the least amount of “territorial advantage” to the Team striking the puck, either where the puck was contacted illegally, or where it was last played by the offending Team. If the attacking Team is at fault and the play is stopped while the puck is in the Attacking Zone, the ensuing “face-off” must be moved to the nearest Face-off Spot in the Neutral Zone.

qas.question: Where must the ensuing face-off take place if the play is stopped for a high-sticking violation in the Attacking Zone by the attacking Team?

answers.text: The ensuing face-off must take place at the nearest Face-off Spot in the Neutral Zone if the play is stopped for a high-sticking violation in the Attacking Zone by the attacking Team.

qas.question: What determines the location of the face-off after a high-sticking violation is called during play?

answers.text: The location of the face-off after a high-sticking violation during play is determined by providing the least territorial advantage to the team that committed the violation, either at the spot of the illegal contact or where the puck was last played by the offending team. If the attacking team is at fault and the play is stopped in the Attacking Zone, the face-off is moved to the nearest Face-off Spot in the Neutral Zone.

qas.question: If a player high-sticks the puck in the Attacking Zone, where should the face-off be moved to according to the rule?

answers.text: The face-off should be moved to the nearest Face-off Spot in the Neutral Zone if a player high-sticks the puck in the Attacking Zone.

qas.question: In the case of a high-sticking violation, where should the face-off be placed if the offending Team last played the puck in the Neutral Zone?

answers.text: The face-off should be placed at the nearest Face-off Spot in the Neutral Zone if the offending Team last played the puck in the Neutral Zone during a high-sticking violation.

qas.question: How is the location of the face-off determined when play is stopped due to high-sticking the puck in hockey?

answers.text: The face-off location after a high-sticking violation in hockey is determined by moving it to the nearest face-off spot in the Neutral Zone if the attacking team is at fault and the play is stopped in the Attacking Zone.

paragraphs.context: When an attacking Player causes the puck to enter the opponent’s goal by contacting the puck above the height of the crossbar, either directly or deflected off any Player or official, the goal shall not be allowed. The determining factor is where the puck makes contact with the stick. If the puck makes contact with the stick at or below the level of the crossbar and enters the goal, this goal shall be allowed. A goal scored as a result of a defending Player striking the puck with their stick carried above the height of the crossbar of the goal frame into their own goal shall be allowed.

qas.question: If a player strikes the puck above the height of the crossbar and it enters the opponent's goal, will the goal be allowed?

answers.text: No, if a player strikes the puck above the height of the crossbar and it enters the opponent's goal, the goal will not be allowed.

qas.question: What is the determining factor for whether a goal scored by a player contacting the puck above the crossbar is disallowed?

answers.text: A goal scored by a player contacting the puck above the crossbar is disallowed if the puck makes contact with the stick above the crossbar.

qas.question: Can a goal be scored if the puck makes contact with a player's stick at or below the level of the crossbar and enters the goal?

answers.text: Yes, a goal can be scored if the puck makes contact with a player's stick at or below the level of the crossbar and enters the goal.

qas.question: Is a goal allowed if a defending player accidentally strikes the puck with their stick above the height of the crossbar into their own goal?

answers.text: Yes, a goal is allowed if a defending player accidentally strikes the puck with their stick above the height of the crossbar into their own goal.

qas.question: In the context of high-sticking the puck, what happens if the puck is deflected off an official and enters the opponent's goal?

answers.text: If the puck is deflected off an official and enters the opponent's goal after being high-sticked by an attacking player, the goal shall not be allowed.

paragraphs.context: For the purpose of this rule, the center red line will divide the ice into halves. Should any Player of a Team, equal or superior in “numerical strength” (power-play) to the opposing Team, shoot, bat or deflect the puck from their own half of the ice beyond the Goal Line of the opposing Team, play shall be stopped. For the purpose of deflected pucks, this only applies when the puck was originally propelled down the ice by the offending Team. For the purpose of this rule, the point of last contact with the puck by the Team in possession shall be used to determine whether icing has occurred or not. As such, the Team in possession must “gain the line” in order for the icing to be nullified. “Gaining the line” shall mean that the puck, while on the Player’s stick (not the Player’s skate) must make contact with the center red line in order to nullify a potential icing. For the purpose of interpretation of the rule, there are two judgments required for "icing the puck". The Linesperson must first determine that the puck will cross the Goal Line. Once the Linesperson determines that the puck will cross the Goal Line, “icing” is completed upon the determination as to which Player (attacking or defending) would first touch the puck. This decision by the Linesperson will be made by no later than the instant the first Player reaches the End Zone “face-off” dots with the Player's skate being the determining factor. Should the puck be shot down the ice in such a manner that it travels around the Boards and/or back towards the End Zone “face-off” dots, the same procedure shall be in effect in that the Linesperson shall determine within a similar distance as to who will have touched the puck first. For clarification, the determining factor is which Player would first touch the puck, not which Player would first reach the End Zone “face-off” dots. If the “race for the puck” is too close to determine by the time the first Player reaches the End Zone “face-off” dots, “icing” shall be called. The puck striking or deflecting off an Official does not automatically nullify a potential “icing”. If there is no “race” for the puck, icing will be not called until a defending skater crosses its defending blue line and the puck crosses the goal line (not between the goal posts).

qas.question: According to the rule, when is play stopped due to icing?

answers.text: Play is stopped due to icing when a player shoots, bats, or deflects the puck from their own half of the ice beyond the goal line of the opposing team, and the opposing team would be the first to touch the puck.

qas.question: How is "gaining the line" defined in relation to nullifying icing?

answers.text: "Gaining the line" in relation to nullifying icing is defined as the puck, while on a player's stick, making contact with the center red line to nullify a potential icing.

qas.question: What is the determining factor for icing when the puck is shot down the ice and travels around the boards?

answers.text: The determining factor for icing when the puck is shot down the ice and travels around the boards is which player would first touch the puck, not which player would first reach the End Zone "face-off" dots.

qas.question: How does the Linesperson determine if icing has occurred when the puck is shot down the ice?

answers.text: The Linesperson determines icing by judging which player would first touch the puck after it crosses the goal line, with the decision made by the time the first player reaches the end zone face-off dots.

qas.question: In what situation would icing not be called until a defending skater crosses its defending blue line and the puck crosses the goal line?

answers.text: Icing would not be called until a defending skater crosses its defending blue line and the puck crosses the goal line when there is no "race" for the puck.

paragraphs.context: Following an “icing”, the attacking Team will have the choice of which End Zone dot the “face-off” will take place. If, in the opinion of the Referee, the defending side intentionally abstains from playing the puck promptly when they are in a position to do so, they shall stop the play and order the resulting “face-off” on the adjacent corner Face-off Spot nearest the goal of the Team at fault. If the Linesperson shall have erred in calling an “icing the puck” infraction (regardless of whether either Team is “short-handed”), the puck shall be “faced-off” on the Center ice Face-off Spot.

qas.question: What choice does the attacking team have regarding the face-off location after an icing violation?

answers.text: After an icing violation, the attacking team can choose the End Zone dot for the face-off location.

qas.question: When will the referee order the face-off to take place on the adjacent corner face-off spot after an icing infraction?

answers.text: The referee will order the face-off to take place on the adjacent corner face-off spot after an icing infraction if the defending side intentionally abstains from playing the puck promptly when they could have done so.

qas.question: In what situation will the linesperson face-off the puck at the center ice face-off spot after an incorrect icing call?

answers.text: The linesperson will face-off the puck at the center ice face-off spot after an incorrect icing call.

qas.question: What action by the defending side may lead to the play being stopped and the face-off location being adjusted after an icing violation?

answers.text: The defending side intentionally abstaining from playing the puck promptly after an icing violation may lead to the play being stopped and the face-off location being adjusted to the adjacent corner face-off spot nearest the goal of the defending team at fault.

qas.question: Who has the authority to determine if the defending side intentionally abstained from playing the puck promptly after an icing infraction?

answers.text: The referee has the authority to determine if the defending side intentionally abstained from playing the puck promptly after an icing infraction.

paragraphs.context: If, in the opinion of the Linesperson, the Goalkeeper feigns playing the puck, attempts to play the puck, or skates in the direction of the puck on an icing at any time, the “potential icing” shall not be called, and play shall continue. If, however, a Goalkeeper is legitimately out of the crease in an attempt to go to the Players’ Bench to be substituted for an extra attacker and in no way makes an attempt to play the puck, the “icing” should not be nullified under this section. If the Goalkeeper is out of their crease prior to the shot being taken, and simply retreats to their crease making no attempt to play the puck or feign playing the puck, the “potential icing” shall remain in effect.

qas.question: What action by the Goalkeeper would cause the Linesperson to not call an icing during a game?

answers.text: The Linesperson would not call an icing if the Goalkeeper feigns playing the puck, attempts to play the puck, or skates towards the puck during an icing.

qas.question: When can a Goalkeeper leave the crease without nullifying an icing call?

answers.text: A Goalkeeper can leave the crease without nullifying an icing call if they are legitimately going to the Players' Bench for a substitution and do not attempt to play the puck.

qas.question: In what situation would a Goalkeeper's retreat to the crease not nullify a potential icing call?

answers.text: A Goalkeeper's retreat to the crease would not nullify a potential icing call if they are out of the crease before the shot is taken and retreat back without attempting to play the puck.

qas.question: How does a Goalkeeper's attempt to play the puck affect the enforcement of an icing call?

answers.text: A Goalkeeper's attempt to play the puck nullifies an icing call if they feign playing or make an attempt towards the puck.

qas.question: What specific scenario allows a Goalkeeper to skate towards the puck without canceling an icing call?

answers.text: A Goalkeeper can skate towards the puck without canceling an icing call if they are legitimately out of the crease in an attempt to be substituted for an extra attacker and do not make any attempt to play the puck.

paragraphs.context: A Team that is in violation of this rule shall not be permitted to make any Player substitutions prior to the ensuing “face-off”. However, a Team shall be permitted to make a Player substitution to replace a Goalkeeper who had been substituted for an extra attacker, to replace an injured Player, a Player with a broken skate, or when a penalty has been assessed which affects the on-ice strength of either Team. The determination of Players on ice will be made when the puck leaves the offending Player’s stick.

qas.question: When can a team make a player substitution after an icing violation?

answers.text: A team can make a player substitution after an icing violation when replacing a goalkeeper who was substituted for an extra attacker, an injured player, a player with a broken skate, or when a penalty affects the on-ice strength of either team.

qas.question: Under what circumstances can a team replace a goalkeeper after an icing violation?

answers.text: A team can replace a goalkeeper after an icing violation if the goalkeeper had been substituted for an extra attacker, if there is an injured player, a player with a broken skate, or when a penalty affects the on-ice strength of either team.

qas.question: What are the exceptions that allow a team to make player substitutions following an icing violation?

answers.text: Exceptions allowing a team to make player substitutions following an icing violation include replacing a goalkeeper after an extra attacker, injured players, those with broken skates, or due to penalties affecting on-ice strength.

qas.question: How is the determination of players on ice made after an icing violation?

answers.text: Players on ice are determined when the puck leaves the offending player's stick after an icing violation.

qas.question: Can a team make player substitutions before the ensuing face-off if they are in violation of the icing rule?

answers.text: No, a team cannot make player substitutions before the ensuing face-off if they are in violation of the icing rule, except in specific circumstances like replacing an injured player or a goalkeeper who was substituted for an extra attacker.

paragraphs.context: When the puck is shot and rebounds from the body or stick of an opponent in their own half of the ice so as to cross the Goal Line of the Player shooting, it shall not be considered “icing”. When a puck is shot by a Team from their own half of the ice and is deflected several times before crossing the center red line, icing shall be nullified if at least one of these deflections was off an opposing Player. If the puck shall go beyond the Goal Line in the opposite half of the ice directly from either of the Players while facing-off, it shall not be considered a violation of this rule. If, in the opinion of the Linesperson, any Player (other than the Goalkeeper) of the opposing Team is able to play the puck before it passes their Goal Line, but has not done so, play shall continue and the “icing” violation shall not be called. This includes the situation whereby the opposing Team, while in the process of making Player substitutions during the play, are able to play the puck, but choose not to do so to avoid being called for “too many Players on the ice”. “Icing” should not be called. If the puck touches any part of a Player of the opposing side, including their skates or their stick, or if it touches any part of the opposing Team’s Goalkeeper, including their skates or their stick, at any time before or after crossing the Goal Line, it shall not be considered “icing”. If a Goalkeeper takes any action to dislodge the puck from the back of the net, “icing” shall not be called.

qas.question: When is a puck shot by a team from their own half of the ice not considered "icing"?

answers.text: A puck shot by a team from their own half of the ice is not considered "icing" if it rebounds off an opponent in their own half and crosses the goal line of the team shooting.

qas.question: How can icing be nullified if a puck is shot by a team and deflected several times before crossing the center red line?

answers.text: Icing can be nullified if a puck is shot by a team and deflected several times before crossing the center red line, as long as at least one of these deflections was off an opposing player.

qas.question: In what situation would a puck going beyond the goal line in the opposite half of the ice directly from players during a face-off not be considered a violation of the icing rule?

answers.text: A puck going beyond the goal line in the opposite half of the ice directly from players during a face-off is not considered a violation of the icing rule.

qas.question: When can play continue without calling an "icing" violation, even if a player of the opposing team is able to play the puck before it passes their goal line?

answers.text: Play can continue without calling an "icing" violation if a player of the opposing team is able to play the puck before it passes their goal line but chooses not to do so.

qas.question: Under what circumstances is a puck not considered "icing" if it touches any part of a player of the opposing side or the opposing team's goalkeeper before or after crossing the goal line?

answers.text: A puck is not considered "icing" if it touches any part of a player of the opposing side or the opposing team's goalkeeper before or after crossing the goal line, as long as the opposing player or goalkeeper has the opportunity to play the puck but chooses not to do so.

paragraphs.context: If the puck was so shot by a Player of a side below the numerical strength of the opposing Team, play shall continue, and the “icing” violation shall not be called. When a Team is “short-handed” as the result of a penalty and the penalty is about to expire, the decision as to whether there has been an “icing” shall be determined at the instant the penalty expires. Should the puck be released from the stick of the Player shooting the puck down the ice prior to the penalty expiring, the “icing” infraction shall not apply. The action of the penalized Player remaining in the Penalty Box will not alter the ruling.

qas.question: When can an "icing" violation be called if a team is short-handed due to a penalty about to expire?

answers.text: An "icing" violation cannot be called if a team is short-handed due to a penalty about to expire, as the decision is determined at the instant the penalty expires. If the puck is shot down the ice before the penalty expires, the "icing" infraction does not apply.

qas.question: How does the numerical strength of a team affect the enforcement of the "icing" rule in hockey?

answers.text: The numerical strength of a team affects the enforcement of the "icing" rule in hockey by allowing play to continue without calling an icing violation if the team shooting the puck is below the numerical strength of the opposing team. If a team is short-handed due to a penalty, the decision on icing is determined when the penalty expires, and if the puck is shot down the ice before the penalty expires, icing is not called. The presence of a penalized player in the penalty box does not change this ruling.

qas.question: What happens if a player shoots the puck down the ice before a penalty expires in relation to the "icing" infraction?

answers.text: If a player shoots the puck down the ice before a penalty expires, the "icing" infraction will not be called, regardless of the penalty status.

qas.question: Does the presence of a penalized player in the Penalty Box impact the ruling on an "icing" violation?

answers.text: No, the presence of a penalized player in the Penalty Box does not impact the ruling on an "icing" violation.

qas.question: In what specific scenario will play continue without calling an "icing" violation based on the numerical strength of the opposing team?

answers.text: Play will continue without calling an "icing" violation when a team is short-handed due to a penalty, and the puck is shot down the ice by a player on the penalized team before the penalty expires.

paragraphs.context: Following the stoppage of play, the visiting Team shall promptly place a line-up on the ice ready for play and no substitution shall be made from that time until play has been resumed. The Home Team may then make any desired substitution, except in cases following an “icing”, which does not result in the delay of the game. “Placing a line-up on the ice” shall mean that both Teams shall place the full complement of Players (and not exceed) to which they are entitled within the line change time frame. If there is any undue delay by either Team in changing Players, the Referee shall order the offending Team or Teams to take their positions immediately and not permit any further Player changes. When a substitution has been made under the above rule, no additional substitution may be made until play commences. Once the line change procedure has been completed, no additional Player substitutions shall be permitted until the “face-off” has been completed legally and play has resumed, except when a penalty or penalties are imposed that affect the “on-ice strength” of either or both Teams. This may include penalties imposed following the completion of the line change and prior to the “face-off”, or due to a penalty assessed for a “face-off” violation – refer to Rule 82.2 – Line Change – Procedure. A Team that is in violation of (Rule 63.8 – Delaying the Game) or (Rule 81 – Icing) shall not be permitted to make any Player substitutions prior to the ensuing “face-off”. However, a Team shall be permitted to make a Player substitution to replace a Goalkeeper who had been substituted for an extra attacker, to replace an injured Player, or when a penalty has been assessed which affects the “on-ice strength” of either Team. The determination of Players on ice will be made when the puck leaves the offending Player’s stick. Goalkeepers’ substitution during a game will be conducted within the same time frame as a regular line change. No extra time will be allotted to the Goalkeeper coming off the bench, except in the case where an injury to a Goalkeeper occurs.

qas.question: What action must the visiting Team take immediately following a stoppage of play according to the Line Change rule?

answers.text: The visiting Team must promptly place a full line-up on the ice following a stoppage of play, and no substitutions are allowed until play resumes.

qas.question: When can the Home Team make any desired substitution following a stoppage of play?
