answers.text: The Home Team can make any desired substitution following a stoppage of play, except after an icing that does not delay the game.

qas.question: What does "placing a line-up on the ice" entail for both Teams during a line change time frame?

answers.text: "Placing a line-up on the ice" during a line change time frame means both Teams must have their full complement of Players ready for play without exceeding their entitlement. No substitutions are allowed until play resumes, except for the Home Team after an icing call that doesn't delay the game. Any undue delays will result in the Referee ordering immediate positions without further changes. Substitutions can only occur after the line change is completed and until play resumes, except for penalties affecting on-ice strength.

qas.question: In what situations can a Team make additional Player substitutions after completing the line change procedure?

answers.text: A Team can make additional Player substitutions after completing the line change procedure in situations such as penalties affecting on-ice strength, replacing an injured Player, or substituting a Goalkeeper for an extra attacker.

qas.question: Under what circumstances can a Team be permitted to make a Player substitution prior to the ensuing face-off, despite being in violation of delaying the game or icing rules?

answers.text: A Team can be permitted to make a Player substitution prior to the ensuing face-off despite violating delaying the game or icing rules when replacing a Goalkeeper who was substituted for an extra attacker, replacing an injured Player, or due to penalties affecting on-ice strength.

paragraphs.context: Following a stoppage of play, the Referee will enforce the following line change procedure once they have determined that this procedure may begin: (I) The Referee shall give the visiting Team up to five (5) seconds to make its line change. (II) The Referee shall raise their hand to indicate no further changes by the visiting Team and to commence the Home Team’s line change. (III) The Referee shall give the Home Team up to eight (8) seconds to make its line change. (IV) The Referee shall lower their hand to indicate no further changes by the Home Team. (V) Any attempt by the either Team to make a change after the Referee’s signal, attempt to place too many Players on the ice for the subsequent line change, or attempt to make additional personnel changes, shall not be permitted and the Referee will send the Players who have attempted to change back to their Players’ Bench. The Referee will then issue a warning to the offending Team (through the Coach) indicating that any subsequent violations during the rest of the game (including Overtime), shall result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “delaying the game”. This penalty shall be announced as a “Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” – Improper Line Change.” (VI) The Linesperson conducting the “face-off” will blow their whistle (once the Referee has lowered their hand for the line changes) to indicate that all Players must be in position and on-side for the “face-off” within five (5) seconds. The “faceoff” will then be conducted (Rule 76 – Face-offs) (VII) Players who are slow (after the five-second warning whistle given by the Linesperson) getting to the “face-off” location or who are in an off-side position for the ensuing “face-off” will be warned once in the game by the Referee. This warning will also be given to the offending Team’s Coach. In this situation, the offending Team’s center is not ejected from the “face-off”. Any subsequent violation shall result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” being assessed to the offending Team. (VIII) In the last two (2) minutes of regulation time and any time in the Overtime period(s), points (vi) and (vii) above are not applicable. The Linesperson shall give the Teams a reasonable amount of time to set up for the ensuing “face-off” after points (i) through (v) above have been enforced.

qas.question: How long does the Referee give the visiting Team to make its line change following a stoppage of play?

answers.text: The Referee gives the visiting Team up to five (5) seconds to make its line change following a stoppage of play.

qas.question: What signal does the Referee use to indicate no further changes by the visiting Team and to commence the Home Team's line change?

answers.text: The Referee raises their hand to indicate no further changes by the visiting Team and to start the Home Team's line change.

qas.question: How much time does the Referee give the Home Team to make its line change after the visiting Team has completed theirs?

answers.text: The Referee gives the Home Team up to eight (8) seconds to make its line change after the visiting Team has completed theirs.

qas.question: What action does the Referee take if either Team attempts to make a change after the Referee's signal for no further changes?

answers.text: If either Team attempts to make a change after the Referee's signal for no further changes, the Referee will send the Players who tried to change back to their bench and issue a warning. Subsequent violations may result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "delaying the game" due to an improper line change.

qas.question: In what situation are points (vi) and (vii) regarding face-off procedures not applicable according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: Points (vi) and (vii) regarding face-off procedures are not applicable in the last two minutes of regulation time and during Overtime according to the rule context provided.

paragraphs.context: The Home Team is entitled to “last change”. This means the visiting Coach must put their Players out on the ice first, after which time the home Coach must do so. If either Team does not make its changes promptly, the Referee will not permit the change. Failure by either Team to comply, or tardiness to comply, or deliberate error in complying with this rule will result first in a warning from the Referee and then a Bench Minor Penalty shall be assessed for “Delay of Game”. Players must proceed directly to the location of the “face-off” to participate in the ensuing “face-off”. Any attempts to delay the game by stalling or otherwise unnecessary actions by either Team shall result in the assessment of a Bench Minor Penalty for “delaying the game”. This penalty shall be announced as a “Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” – Slow Proceeding to “Faceoff Location (or Slow Proceeding to Players’ Bench).” During the play, if a Player wishes to retire from the ice and be replaced by a substitute, they must do so at the Players’ Bench and not through any other exit leading from the Rink. This is not a legal Player change and therefore when a violation occurs, a Bench Minor Penalty shall be imposed.

qas.question: What is the consequence for a team that fails to promptly make their line changes as per the rule on "last change"?

answers.text: Consequence for a team that fails to promptly make their line changes as per the rule on "last change": The Referee will not permit the change, issue a warning, and then assess a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game."

qas.question: What action will the referee take if either team attempts to delay the game by stalling during line changes?

answers.text: If either team attempts to delay the game by stalling during line changes, the referee will first issue a warning and then assess a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game."

qas.question: How should players proceed if they need to be replaced during play according to the rule on line changes?

answers.text: Players should retire from the ice and be replaced by a substitute at the Players' Bench during play according to the rule on line changes.

qas.question: What type of penalty will be assessed for deliberate errors in complying with the rule on line changes?

answers.text: A Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" will be assessed for deliberate errors in complying with the rule on line changes.

qas.question: When must the visiting coach put their players out on the ice according to the rule on "last change"?

answers.text: The visiting coach must put their players out on the ice first when the home team is entitled to "last change" in hockey.

paragraphs.context: Players of the attacking Team must not precede the puck into the Attacking Zone. The position of the Player’s skates and not that of their stick shall be the determining factor in all instances in deciding an “off-side”. A Player is “off-side” when both skates are completely over the leading edge of the Blue Line involved in the play. A Player is on-side when either of their skates are in contact with the Blue Line, or on their “own side” of the line, at the instant the puck completely crosses the leading edge of the Blue Line. On their “own side” of the line shall be defined by a “plane” of the Blue Line which shall extend from the leading edge of the Blue Line upwards. If a Player’s skate has yet to “break the plane” prior to the puck completely crossing the leading edge, they are deemed to be “on-side” for the purpose of the “off-side” rule. If, during a delayed off-side, an attacking player in the attacking zone elects to proceed to his players’ bench (which extends into the attacking zone) to be replaced by a teammate, he shall be considered to have cleared the zone when both skates are off the ice and the Linesperson judges him to have left the playing surface. A Player controlling the puck who shall cross the line ahead of the puck shall not be considered “off-side,” provided they have “possession and control” of the puck prior to their skates crossing the leading edge of the Blue Line. It should be noted that while the position of the Player’s skates is what determines whether a Player is “off-side,” nevertheless the question of an “off-side” never arises until the puck has completely crossed the leading edge of the Blue Line at which time the decision is to be made. If a Player legally carries, passes, or plays the puck back into their own Defending Zone while a Player of the opposing Team is in such Defending Zone, the “off-side” shall be ignored, and play permitted to continue.

qas.question: What is the determining factor in deciding an "off-side" according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: The determining factor in deciding an "off-side" in hockey is the position of the player's skates in relation to the Blue Line.

qas.question: When is a Player considered "off-side" in relation to the Blue Line involved in the play?

answers.text: A Player is considered "off-side" in relation to the Blue Line involved in the play when both skates are completely over the leading edge of the Blue Line.

qas.question: How is a Player deemed to be "on-side" for the purpose of the "off-side" rule if their skate has not yet "broken the plane"?

answers.text: A Player is deemed to be "on-side" for the off-side rule if their skate has not yet "broken the plane" of the Blue Line before the puck completely crosses the leading edge of the Blue Line.

qas.question: In what situation is a Player controlling the puck allowed to cross the Blue Line ahead of the puck without being considered "off-side"?

answers.text: A Player controlling the puck can cross the Blue Line ahead of the puck without being off-side if they have "possession and control" of the puck before their skates cross the leading edge of the Blue Line.

qas.question: When can the "off-side" rule be ignored and play permitted to continue, as per the rule context?

answers.text: The "off-side" rule can be ignored and play permitted to continue if a player legally carries, passes, or plays the puck back into their own Defending Zone while a player of the opposing team is in that Defending Zone.

paragraphs.context: For the purposes of this section, it is stipulated that an attacking Player has preceded the puck into the Attacking Zone. When a defending Player propels the puck out of their Defending Zone and the puck clearly rebounds off a defending Player in the Neutral Zone back into the Defending Zone, all attacking Players are eligible to play the puck. However, any action by an attacking Player that causes a “deflection/rebound” off a defending Player in the Neutral Zone back into the Defending Zone (i.e. stick check, body check, physical contact), a “Delayed Off-side” shall be signaled by the Linesperson. A puck that deflects back into the Defending Zone off an Official who is in the Neutral Zone will be “off-side” (or “Delayed Off-side”, as appropriate). A puck which deflects off an attacking Player outside the Blue Line into the Attacking Zone, regardless of who originally propelled it or where it was propelled from, shall be ruled “off-side” or “Delayed Off-side”, as appropriate. A puck which is propelled by the attacking Team and deflects off any Player into the Attacking Zone” shall be ruled “off-side” or “Delayed Off-side”, as appropriate.

qas.question: What action by an attacking Player in the Neutral Zone can cause a "Delayed Off-side" to be signaled by the Linesperson?

answers.text: An attacking player causing a "deflection/rebound" off a defending player in the Neutral Zone back into the Defending Zone triggers a "Delayed Off-side" signal by the Linesperson.

qas.question: If a defending Player propels the puck out of their Defending Zone and it rebounds off a defending Player in the Neutral Zone back into the Defending Zone, are attacking Players allowed to play the puck?

answers.text: Yes, attacking Players are allowed to play the puck if it rebounds off a defending Player in the Neutral Zone back into the Defending Zone.

qas.question: In what scenario would a puck deflected back into the Defending Zone off an Official in the Neutral Zone be considered "off-side"?

answers.text: A puck deflected back into the Defending Zone off an Official in the Neutral Zone would be considered "off-side" in hockey.

qas.question: When is a puck ruled "off-side" or "Delayed Off-side" if it deflects off an attacking Player outside the Blue Line into the Attacking Zone?

answers.text: A puck is ruled "off-side" or "Delayed Off-side" if it deflects off an attacking Player outside the Blue Line into the Attacking Zone.

qas.question: What happens if a puck propelled by the attacking Team deflects off any Player into the Attacking Zone according to the rule context provided?

answers.text: If a puck propelled by the attacking team deflects off any player into the Attacking Zone, it shall be ruled "off-side" or "Delayed Off-side," as appropriate.

paragraphs.context: A situation where an attacking Player (or Players) has (have) preceded the puck across the attacking Blue Line, but the defending Team is in a position to bring the puck back out of its Defending Zone without any delay or contact with an attacking Player or the attacking Players are in the process of clearing the Attacking Zone. If an “off-side” call is delayed, the Linesperson shall drop their arm to nullify the “off-side” violation and allow play to continue if: (I) All Players of the offending Team clear the zone at the same instant (skate contact with the Blue Line, "3D" judgement is not used in this situation) permitting the attacking Players to re-enter the Attacking Zone, or (II) the defending Team passes or carries the puck into the Neutral Zone. If, during the course of the “Delayed Off-side”, any member of the attacking Team touches the puck, attempts to “gain possession of a loose puck”, forces the defending puck carrier further back into their own zone, or who is about to make physical contact with the defending puck carrier, the Linesperson shall stop play for the “off-side” violation. If, during a “Delayed Off-side”, an attacking Player in the Attacking Zone elects to proceed to their Players’ Bench (which extends into the Attacking Zone) to be replaced by a Teammate, they shall be considered to have cleared the zone when both skates are off the ice and the Linesperson judges them to have left the playing surface. If their replacement comes onto the ice in the Attacking Zone, while the “Delayed Off-side” is still in effect, they too must clear the Attacking Zone. Once all attacking Players have cleared the Attacking Zone and the Linesperson have lowered their arm for the “Delayed Off-side”, all attacking Players may legally enter the Attacking Zone and pursue the puck.

qas.question: What actions by the defending team can nullify an "off-side" violation during a delayed off-side situation?

answers.text: Actions by the defending team that can nullify an "off-side" violation during a delayed off-side situation include all players of the offending team clearing the zone simultaneously or the defending team passing or carrying the puck into the Neutral Zone.

qas.question: When can the Linesperson drop their arm to nullify an "off-side" violation during a delayed off-side scenario?

answers.text: The Linesperson can drop their arm to nullify an "off-side" violation during a delayed off-side scenario when all Players of the offending Team clear the zone simultaneously or when the defending Team passes or carries the puck into the Neutral Zone.

qas.question: What specific actions by an attacking Player during a delayed off-side will result in the Linesperson stopping play for an "off-side" violation?

answers.text: An attacking Player touching the puck, attempting to gain possession, forcing the defending puck carrier back, or about to make physical contact will result in the Linesperson stopping play for an "off-side" violation during a delayed off-side.

qas.question: How is an attacking Player considered to have cleared the zone during a delayed off-side when proceeding to their Players' Bench for a replacement?

answers.text: An attacking player is considered to have cleared the zone during a delayed off-side when proceeding to their Players' Bench for a replacement by having both skates off the ice and judged by the Linesperson to have left the playing surface.

qas.question: Once all attacking Players have cleared the Attacking Zone during a delayed off-side, what are they allowed to do according to the rule?

answers.text: Once all attacking Players have cleared the Attacking Zone during a delayed off-side, they are allowed to legally re-enter the Attacking Zone and pursue the puck.

paragraphs.context: If the puck is shot into the Attacking Zone creating a “Delayed Off-side”, the play shall be allowed to continue under the normal “clearing-the-zone” rules. Should the puck, as a result of this shot, enter the defending Team’s goal, either directly or off the Goalkeeper, a Player, the Boards, the glass, a piece of equipment or an official on the ice, the goal shall be disallowed as the original shot was “offside”. The fact that the attacking Team may have “cleared the zone” prior to the puck entering the goal has no bearing on this ruling. The “face-off” will be conducted at the Face-off Spot in the zone closest to the point of origin of the shot that gives the offending Team the least amount of “territorial advantage”. The only way an attacking Team can score a goal on a “Delayed Off-side” situation is if the defending Team shoots or puts the puck into their own net without action or contact by the offending Team. Other than in situations involving a “Delayed Off-side” and the puck entering the goal or a successful Coach’s Challenge, no goal can be disallowed after the fact for an “off-side” violation, except for the human factor involved in blowing the whistle. (Rule 38 – Coach’s Challenge)

qas.question: What happens if the puck is shot into the Attacking Zone creating a "Delayed Off-side" situation?

answers.text: If the puck is shot into the Attacking Zone creating a "Delayed Off-side" situation, the play continues under normal rules. If the puck enters the defending Team's goal directly or off a player, the goal is disallowed due to the offside shot. The face-off occurs at the spot closest to the original shot, minimizing territorial advantage. The only way the attacking Team can score is if the defending Team puts the puck into their own net.

qas.question: In what scenarios will a goal be disallowed due to an off-side violation according to the rule?

answers.text: A goal will be disallowed due to an off-side violation if the puck enters the defending team's goal directly or off a player, equipment, or official after a shot from the Attacking Zone during a "Delayed Off-side" situation.

qas.question: How is the face-off location determined after a goal is disallowed for being off-side?

answers.text: After a goal is disallowed for being off-side, the face-off location is determined at the Face-off Spot in the zone closest to where the original off-side shot was taken, minimizing territorial advantage for the offending team.

qas.question: Can an attacking team score a goal during a "Delayed Off-side" situation under normal circumstances?

answers.text: No, an attacking team cannot score a goal during a "Delayed Off-side" situation under normal circumstances.

qas.question: When can a goal be disallowed for an off-side violation other than in situations involving a "Delayed Off-side" or a successful Coach's Challenge?

answers.text: A goal can be disallowed for an off-side violation in situations where the puck enters the defending team's goal directly from an off-side shot, regardless of whether the attacking team cleared the zone before the goal was scored.

paragraphs.context: (Rule 38 – Coach’s Challenge)

qas.question: What section and rule cover the Coach's Challenge for an off-side call in hockey?

answers.text: Section: Rule 38 covers the Coach's Challenge for an off-side call in hockey.

qas.question: Under what subrule can a coach challenge an off-side call during a game?

answers.text: Answer: A coach can challenge an off-side call during a game under Rule 38 of the hockey rulebook.

qas.question: Which specific rule number outlines the Coach's Challenge for off-side situations in hockey?

answers.text: Rule 38 outlines the Coach's Challenge for off-side situations in hockey.

qas.question: What is the title of the section that includes the Coach's Challenge for off-side in hockey?

answers.text: The title of the section that includes the Coach's Challenge for off-side in hockey is "Rule 38 – Coach’s Challenge."

qas.question: In what circumstances can a coach use the Coach's Challenge for an off-side call according to the rulebook?

answers.text: A coach can use the Coach's Challenge for an off-side call if they believe the play leading to a goal was off-side.

paragraphs.context: For violation of this rule, the play is stopped and the puck shall be “faced-off” in the Neutral Zone at the Face-off Spot nearest the Attacking Zone of the offending Team when the violation occurs as a result of the attacking Team carrying the puck over the attacking Blue Line, or from the Face-off Spot in the zone closest to the point of origin of the shot or pass (even if deflected off an attacking or defending Player or an official). For every “Delayed Off-side” situation, including an “intentional off-side”, the Linesperson will raise their non-whistle arm. They will allow play to continue and, if a stoppage of play occurs, there will be four possible “face-off” locations: (I) If carried over the Blue Line – “face-off” outside the Blue Line. (II) If shot into the Attacking Zone (or errant pass) – nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from which the pass or shot originated that gives the offending Team the least amount of “territorial advantage” (even if deflected off an attacking or defending Player or an official). (III) If the defending Player is pressured or about to be checked by an attacking Player – nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from which the pass or shot originated that gives the offending Team the least amount of “territorial advantage” (even if deflected off an attacking or defending Player or an official). (IV) If deemed to be an “intentional off-side” – Face-off Spot in the offending Team’s End Zone. When the Linesperson signals a “Delayed Off-side” and a defending Player shoots the puck which goes over the Protection Glass and out of play, the ensuing “face-off” shall be conducted at one of the Defending Zone End Zone Face-off Spots and the defending Player would be assessed a Minor Penalty. (Rule 63 – Delaying the Game) When the Linesperson signals a “Delayed Off-side” and the original shot deflects off a defending Player and out of play, the ensuing “face-off” shall take place at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from where the puck was shot. When the defending Team is about to be penalized in the Defending Zone and the Linesperson has a “Delayed Off-side” signaled against the attacking Team on the same play, the ensuing “face-off” shall be conducted at one of the Defending Zone End Zone Face-off Spots.

qas.question: What happens when a player from the attacking team carries the puck over the attacking Blue Line resulting in an off-side violation?

answers.text: When a player from the attacking team carries the puck over the attacking Blue Line resulting in an off-side violation, play is stopped, and the puck is faced-off in the Neutral Zone at the Face-off Spot nearest the Attacking Zone of the offending Team.

qas.question: How does a Linesperson indicate a "Delayed Off-side" situation during play?

answers.text: A Linesperson indicates a "Delayed Off-side" situation by raising their non-whistle arm while allowing play to continue.

qas.question: Where is the face-off location when a shot is made into the Attacking Zone or an errant pass is made, causing a "Delayed Off-side" situation?

answers.text: When a shot is made into the Attacking Zone or an errant pass is made, causing a "Delayed Off-side" situation, the face-off location is at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from which the pass or shot originated that gives the offending Team the least amount of "territorial advantage."

qas.question: In what scenario would a face-off take place in the offending team's End Zone for an intentional off-side violation?

answers.text: A face-off would take place in the offending team's End Zone for an intentional off-side violation.

qas.question: What is the consequence for a defending player shooting the puck over the Protection Glass and out of play when a "Delayed Off-side" is signaled by the Linesperson?

answers.text: When a defending player shoots the puck over the Protection Glass and out of play during a "Delayed Off-side," the consequence is a Minor Penalty for the defending player, and the ensuing face-off will be conducted at one of the Defending Zone End Zone Face-off Spots.

paragraphs.context: An “intentional off-side” is one which is made for the purpose of securing a stoppage of play regardless of the reason, whether either Team is “short-handed”. If, while an “off-side call is delayed”, a Player of the offending Team deliberately touches the puck to create a stoppage of play, the Linesperson will signal an “intentional off-side”. If, in the judgement of the Linesperson, the attacking Player(s) are making an effort to exit the Attacking Zone and are in close proximity to the Blue Line at the time the puck is shot into the zone, the play will not be deemed to be an “intentional off-side”.

qas.question: What constitutes an "intentional off-side" according to the rule?

answers.text: An "intentional off-side" in hockey is when a player deliberately touches the puck to stop play, regardless of the circumstances, or if a team is short-handed.

qas.question: When will a Linesperson signal an "intentional off-side" if an off-side call is delayed?

answers.text: A Linesperson will signal an "intentional off-side" if, while an off-side call is delayed, a Player of the offending Team deliberately touches the puck to create a stoppage of play.

qas.question: How does the rule define the actions of a Player from the offending Team to create a stoppage of play intentionally?

answers.text: A Player from the offending Team creates an intentional off-side by deliberately touching the puck to stop play, regardless of the reason or team's shorthanded status.

qas.question: In what situation will the play not be deemed an "intentional off-side" according to the judgement of the Linesperson?

answers.text: The play will not be deemed an "intentional off-side" if the attacking players are making an effort to exit the Attacking Zone and are near the Blue Line when the puck is shot into the zone, according to the Linesperson's judgement.

qas.question: Can a Player deliberately touching the puck to create a stoppage of play be considered an "intentional off-side" regardless of the reason?

answers.text: Yes, a player deliberately touching the puck to create a stoppage of play can be considered an "intentional off-side" regardless of the reason, as per the hockey rule.

paragraphs.context: If at the end of the three (3) regular twenty (20) minutes periods in a single Round Robin IIHF Championship or the Preliminary Round of a top category IIHF Championship, the two (2) playing Teams are tied, the Teams will then play a “sudden death” Overtime period of not more than five (5) minutes with the Team scoring first declared the winner. The Overtime period shall be played with each Team at a numerical strength of three (3) Skaters and one (1) Goalkeeper. The Overtime period will commence following a three-minute (3) intermission during which time a “shoveling” of the ice surface by arena personnel will be performed utilizing the same procedure as during “television commercial breaks”. Once the intermission has been completed, the clock will be reset to 5:00 minutes and the Overtime period will begin immediately. Teams will not change ends. The players will remain at their respective Players’ Benches during the 3-minute (3) intermission in which the “shoveling” of the ice surface takes place. Goalkeepers must go to their respective Players’ Benches during this rest period; however, penalized Players must remain in the Penalty Box. Should a penalized Player exit the Penalty Box, they shall be returned immediately by the Game Officials with no additional penalty being assessed, unless they commit an infraction of any other rule. Teams are not permitted to return to the Dressing Room during this time.

qas.question: How long is the sudden death Overtime period in a Round Robin IIHF Championship or the Preliminary Round of a top category IIHF Championship if the two playing Teams are tied after three regular periods?

answers.text: In a Round Robin IIHF Championship or the Preliminary Round of a top category IIHF Championship, the sudden death Overtime period is not more than five (5) minutes if the two Teams are tied after three regular periods.

qas.question: How many Skaters and Goalkeepers are on the ice for each Team during the Overtime period in a tied Round Robin or Preliminary Round game?

answers.text: During the Overtime period in a tied Round Robin or Preliminary Round game, each Team has three (3) Skaters and one (1) Goalkeeper on the ice.

qas.question: What is the duration of the intermission before the start of the Overtime period in a tied Round Robin or Preliminary Round game?

answers.text: The intermission before the start of the Overtime period in a tied Round Robin or Preliminary Round game is three minutes.

qas.question: Are Teams allowed to change ends during the Overtime period in a Round Robin or Preliminary Round game?

answers.text: No, teams are not allowed to change ends during the Overtime period in a Round Robin or Preliminary Round game.

qas.question: Where do the players and Goalkeepers remain during the 3-minute intermission before the start of the Overtime period in a tied Round Robin or Preliminary Round game?

answers.text: During the 3-minute intermission before the start of the Overtime period in a tied Round Robin or Preliminary Round game, players remain at their respective Players' Benches, while Goalkeepers go to their respective Players' Benches.

paragraphs.context: A Team shall be allowed to pull its Goalkeeper in favor of an additional Skater in the Overtime period.

qas.question: Can a team pull their goalkeeper in favor of an additional skater during the Overtime period?

answers.text: Yes, a team can pull their goalkeeper in favor of an additional skater during the Overtime period in hockey.

qas.question: What is the specific rule regarding allowing a team to have an extra attacker in Overtime?

answers.text: In Overtime, a team is allowed to pull its Goalkeeper and add an extra Skater.

qas.question: When can a team decide to have an additional skater instead of a goalkeeper during Overtime?

answers.text: A team can decide to have an additional skater instead of a goalkeeper during Overtime.

qas.question: Is it permissible for a team to replace their goalkeeper with an extra skater in the Overtime period?

answers.text: Yes, a team is allowed to replace their goalkeeper with an extra skater in the Overtime period.

qas.question: What action is allowed for a team in terms of player positioning when opting for an extra attacker in Overtime?

answers.text: When opting for an extra attacker in Overtime, a team is allowed to pull its Goalkeeper in favor of an additional Skater.

paragraphs.context: When regulation time ends, and the Teams are 5 on 3, teams will start the Overtime period with 5 on 3. Once player strength reaches 5 on 4 or 5 on 5, at the next stoppage of play, player strength is adjusted to 4 on 3 or 3 on 3, as appropriate. When regulation time ends, and Teams are 4 on 4 Teams will start Overtime 3 on 3. Once Player strength reaches 4 on 4, at the next stoppage Player strength is adjusted to 3 on 3 as appropriate. If at the end of regulation time Teams are 3 on 3, Overtime starts 3 on 3. Once Player strength reaches 4 on 4, 5 on 4 or 5 on 5, at the next stoppage player strength is adjusted to 3 on 3 or 4 on 3 as appropriate. At no time will a Team have less than three (3) Skaters on the ice. This may require a fourth (4th) and/or fifth (5th) Skater to be added in the event penalties are assessed. If a Team is penalized in Overtime, Teams play 4 on 3. If both Teams are penalized with Minor Penalties at the same stoppage of play (with no other penalties in effect), Teams will continue to play 3 on 3. In Overtime, if a team is penalized such that a two-man (2) advantage is called for, then the offending Team will remain at three (3) Skaters while the non-offending Team will be permitted five (5) Skaters. At the first stoppage of play after the two-man (2) advantage is no longer in effect, the “numerical strength” of the Teams will revert back to 4 on 3 or 3 on 3, as appropriate.

qas.question: What happens if a team is penalized in Overtime?

answers.text: If a team is penalized in Overtime, they will play with 4 skaters while the opposing team will have 3 skaters.

qas.question: How does player strength change if Teams start Overtime with 5 on 3 and then reach 5 on 4?

answers.text: Player strength changes in Overtime based on the number of players on the ice at the end of regulation time. If Teams start Overtime with 5 on 3 and then reach 5 on 4, player strength is adjusted to 4 on 3 at the next stoppage of play.

qas.question: What is the player strength adjustment if Teams start Overtime 4 on 4 and then reach 4 on 4?

answers.text: If Teams start Overtime 4 on 4 and then reach 4 on 4, the player strength adjustment will be to play 3 on 3 at the next stoppage of play.

qas.question: In Overtime, what happens if both Teams are penalized with Minor Penalties at the same stoppage of play?

answers.text: If both teams are penalized with minor penalties at the same stoppage of play in Overtime, they will continue to play 3 on 3.

qas.question: If a team is penalized with a two-man advantage in Overtime, how does the numerical strength of the Teams change?

answers.text: If a team is penalized with a two-man advantage in Overtime, the non-offending team will have a five-man advantage while the offending team will have three skaters. Once the two-man advantage ends, the numerical strength will revert to 4 on 3 or 3 on 3 at the next stoppage of play.

paragraphs.context: If following the completion of regulation time in any IIHF Championship game and the score of the game is tied, the Teams will then play an Overtime period with a maximum duration and number of players as specified in this rule with the Team scoring first declared the winner. If no goal is scored in the Overtime period, then the IIHF Penalty Shot Shootout Procedure will apply. The following procedure will be utilized: (I) Shots will be taken at both ends of the ice surface. The fourteen (14) meter wide longitudinal center section of the Rink, between the Face-off Spots in the Neutral and End Zones, will be dryscraped by the ice-resurfacing machine prior to the Penalty Shot Shootout during the time required to organize the program accordingly. (II) The procedure will begin with five (5) different shooters from each Team taking alternate shots. The Skaters do not need to be named beforehand. Eligible to participate in the “Penalty Shot” Shootout will be all Players from both Teams listed on the Official Game Sheet except as specified in article 3 below. (III) Any Skater whose penalty had not been completed when the Overtime period ended is not eligible to be one of the Players selected to take the shots and must remain in the Penalty Box or in the Dressing Room. Also, Players serving penalties assessed during the “Penalty Shot” Shootout must remain in the Penalty Box or in the Dressing Room until the end of the procedure. (IV) The Referee will call the two Captains to the On-ice Officials’ Crease and flip a coin to determine which Team takes the first shot. The winner of the coin toss will have the choice whether their Team will shoot first or second. (V) The Goalkeepers shall defend the same goal as in the Overtime period and remain in the goal when their own team is taking a shot. (VI) The Goalkeepers from each Team may be changed after each shot. (VII) The shots will be taken in accordance with (Rule 24 – Penalty Shot) (VIII) The Players of both Teams will take the shots alternately until a decisive goal is scored. The remaining shots will not be taken. (IX) If the score is still tied after all shots are taken by each Team, the procedure shall continue with a “tiebreak shoot-out”, using the same or new Players. The Team that shot second in the first five Penalty Shot will start first in the “tie-break shots”. The game shall be finished as soon as a duel of two Players brings the decisive result. The same Player can be used for each shot by a Team in the “tie-break shoot-out”. (X) The Official Scorekeeper will record all shots taken, indicating the Players and goals scored. (XI) Only the decisive goal will count in the result of the game. It shall be credited to the Team that scored the goal and charged against the Team that was scored upon. (XII) If a Team declines to participate in the “Penalty Shot” Shootout, the game will be declared as a loss for that Team and the other Team will be awarded 3 points for a win. If a Player declines to take a shot it will be declared "no score" for their Team.

qas.question: How many different shooters from each team will take alternate shots during the Penalty Shot Shootout procedure in an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: During the Penalty Shot Shootout procedure in an IIHF Championship game, five different shooters from each team will take alternate shots.

qas.question: What must happen if a Team declines to participate in the Penalty Shot Shootout following the completion of the Overtime period in an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: If a Team declines to participate in the Penalty Shot Shootout following the completion of the Overtime period in an IIHF Championship game, the game will be declared as a loss for that Team, and the other Team will be awarded 3 points for a win.

qas.question: What is the maximum duration of the Overtime period in an IIHF Championship game before the Penalty Shot Shootout procedure is implemented?

answers.text: The maximum duration of the Overtime period in an IIHF Championship game is 20 minutes before the Penalty Shot Shootout procedure is implemented.

qas.question: What happens if a Skater's penalty had not been completed when the Overtime period ended in an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: If a Skater's penalty had not been completed when the Overtime period ended in an IIHF Championship game, they are not eligible to participate in the Penalty Shot Shootout and must remain in the Penalty Box or Dressing Room until the end of the procedure.

qas.question: How are the two Captains involved in determining which Team takes the first shot during the Penalty Shot Shootout in an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: The two Captains determine which Team takes the first shot in the Penalty Shot Shootout by flipping a coin. The winner of the coin toss chooses whether their Team shoots first or second.

paragraphs.context: If at the end of the three (3) regular twenty (20) minutes periods in a Playoff Game, a Relegation Round Game, a Classification Round Game or in a Bronze Medal Game and the two playing teams are tied, the teams will then play a ‘sudden death’ overtime period of not more than 10 minutes with the team scoring first declared the winner. The overtime period shall be played with each team at a numerical strength of three (3) skaters and one (1) Goalkeeper. The overtime period will commence following a three-minute intermission during which time a shoveling of the ice surface will be performed by arena personnel utilizing the same procedure as during television time-outs. Once the intermission has been completed, the clock will be reset to 10:00 minutes and the overtime period will begin immediately. Teams will not change ends. The players will remain at their respective player benches during the 3-minute intermission in which the shoveling of the ice surface takes place. Goalkeepers must go to their respective players’ benches during this rest period; however, penalized players must remain on the penalty bench. Should a penalized player exit the penalty bench, the player shall be returned immediately by the game officials with no additional penalty being assessed, unless the player commits an infraction of any other rule. Teams are not permitted to return to the dressing room during this time.

qas.question: How long is the sudden death overtime period in a Playoff Game, Relegation Round Game, Classification Round Game, or Bronze Medal Game if the two teams are tied after the three regular periods?

answers.text: The sudden death overtime period in a Playoff Game, Relegation Round Game, Classification Round Game, or Bronze Medal Game is a maximum of 10 minutes, with the first team to score declared the winner.

qas.question: How many skaters and goalkeepers are on the ice for each team during the overtime period in the mentioned games?

answers.text: During the overtime period in the mentioned games, each team has three (3) skaters and one (1) goalkeeper on the ice.

qas.question: What is the duration of the intermission between the end of the third period and the start of the overtime period in the specified games?

answers.text: The intermission between the end of the third period and the start of the overtime period in the specified games is three minutes.

qas.question: Are teams allowed to change ends during the sudden death overtime period in the mentioned games?

answers.text: No, teams are not allowed to change ends during the sudden death overtime period in the mentioned games.

qas.question: Where do players and goalkeepers need to be during the 3-minute intermission before the start of the overtime period in the specified games?

answers.text: Players and goalkeepers must remain at their respective player benches during the 3-minute intermission before the start of the overtime period. Goalkeepers go to their player benches, while penalized players stay at the penalty bench.

paragraphs.context: If at the end of the three (3) regular twenty (20) minutes periods in a Gold Medal Game of a top category championship and the two playing teams are tied, the teams will then play a ‘sudden death’ overtime with the team scoring first declared the winner. The overtime period(s) shall be played with each team at a numerical strength of three (3) skaters and one (1) Goalkeeper. The overtime period will commence following an ice resurfacing during a 15-minute intermission where the teams will return to their dressing room before the start of the overtime period. Teams will not change ends. If at the end of the first overtime period the two playing teams are still tied, the teams will then continue to play a second overtime period following an ice resurfacing during a 15-minute intermission where the teams will return to their dressing room before the start of the 2nd overtime period. Teams will change ends. If at the end of the 2nd overtime period the two playing teams are still tied, the teams will then continue to play a third overtime period following an ice resurfacing during a 15-minute intermission where the teams will return to their dressing room before the start of the 3rd overtime period. Teams will change ends. This procedure will go on until a winner is declared.

qas.question: What happens if the two playing teams are tied at the end of the three regular twenty-minute periods in a Gold Medal Game of a top category championship?

answers.text: In a Gold Medal Game of a top category championship, if the two playing teams are tied at the end of the three regular twenty-minute periods, they will play sudden death overtime periods until a winner is declared.

qas.question: How many skaters and goalkeepers are on the ice for each team during the sudden death overtime in a Gold Medal Game?

answers.text: During sudden death overtime in a Gold Medal Game, each team has 3 skaters and 1 goalkeeper on the ice.

qas.question: When does the overtime period commence in a Gold Medal Game after the end of the regular periods?

answers.text: The overtime period in a Gold Medal Game commences after the regular periods end, with a sudden death format where the first team to score wins.

qas.question: What happens if the two playing teams are still tied at the end of the first overtime period in a Gold Medal Game?

answers.text: If the two playing teams are still tied at the end of the first overtime period in a Gold Medal Game, they will proceed to play additional overtime periods until a winner is declared.

qas.question: How long is the intermission between overtime periods in a Gold Medal Game, and what happens during this time?

answers.text: The intermission between overtime periods in a Gold Medal Game is 15 minutes. During this time, the teams return to their dressing rooms before the start of the next overtime period.

data.title: GAME FLOW - PUCK OUT OF BOUNDS

paragraphs.context: When a puck goes outside the playing area at either end or either side of the Rink, strikes any obstacles above the playing surface other than the Boards or Protective Glass, causes the glass, lighting, timing device or the supports to break, it shall be “faced-off” at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from where it was shot or deflected out of play. Should the On-ice Officials rule that the shot or deflection that caused the puck to go out of play originated from the neutral or Defending Zones, the resulting “face-off” location shall be the nearest Face-off Spot closest to the origin of the shot or deflection that gives the offending Team the least amount of “territorial advantage”. If the puck comes to rest on top of the Boards surrounding the playing area, it shall be considered to be in play and may be played legally by hand or stick. When the puck goes outside the playing area directly off the “face-off”, regardless as to which Player may have last contacted the puck, the “face-off” shall remain in the same spot and no penalty will be assessed to either Team for delaying the game. When the puck is shot and it makes contact with the gloves or the body of a Player hanging over the Players’ Bench, or if the puck enters the Players’ Bench through an open bench door, the “face-off” shall take place at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from where the puck was shot, however, if the puck hits an opposing Player’s glove or body that is hanging over the opposing Team’s Players’ Bench or enters the opposing Team’s Players’ Bench through an open bench door, the “face-off” shall take place in the Neutral Zone adjacent to the opponent’s Players’ Bench. Should the puck strike the curved glass located at the end of either Players’ Bench, play shall be stopped when observed by any of the On-ice Officials. The ensuing “face-off” shall be determined as if the puck went outside the playing area. Should the puck strike the spectator netting at the ends and the corners of the arena, play shall be stopped, and the ensuing “faceoff” shall be determined as if the puck went outside the playing area. Players must not stop playing the game until they hear the whistle to do so.

qas.question: What is the procedure for a puck that goes outside the playing area at either end or side of the rink?

answers.text: When a puck goes outside the playing area at either end or side of the rink, it will be faced off at the nearest face-off spot in the zone from where it was shot or deflected out of play.

qas.question: Where is the face-off location if the shot or deflection causing the puck to go out of play originated from the neutral or defending zones?

answers.text: The face-off location if the shot or deflection causing the puck to go out of play originated from the neutral or defending zones is the nearest Face-off Spot closest to the origin of the shot or deflection that gives the offending Team the least amount of "territorial advantage."

qas.question: What happens if the puck comes to rest on top of the boards surrounding the playing area?

answers.text: If the puck comes to rest on top of the boards surrounding the playing area, it is considered in play and can be legally played by hand or stick.

qas.question: When does the face-off location remain the same after the puck goes outside the playing area directly off a face-off?

answers.text: The face-off location remains the same after the puck goes outside the playing area directly off a face-off.

qas.question: Where is the face-off location if the puck makes contact with a player hanging over the players' bench or enters the players' bench through an open door?

answers.text: If the puck makes contact with a player hanging over the players' bench or enters the players' bench through an open door, the face-off location will be at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from where the puck was shot.

paragraphs.context: When the puck becomes lodged in the netting on the outside of either goal so as to make it “unplayable”, or if it is “frozen” between opposing Players intentionally or otherwise, the Referee shall stop the play. The puck may be played off the goal netting by either Team. However, should the puck remain on the goal netting for more than three (3) seconds, play shall be stopped. Should the Goalkeeper use their stick or glove to “freeze” the puck on the back of the net or should a defending Player shield an attacking Player from playing the puck off the back of the net, the “face-off” shall take place at one of the Face-off Spots in the Defending Zone. Should the puck go under the goal either from behind or the side, or through the mesh from behind or the side, if this is witnessed by an On-ice Official, play should be stopped immediately, and the ensuing “face-off” should take place at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone nearest to the location where the play was stopped.

qas.question: What action should the referee take if the puck becomes lodged in the netting on the outside of either goal and is deemed "unplayable"?

answers.text: If the puck becomes lodged in the netting on the outside of either goal and is deemed "unplayable," the referee should stop play.

qas.question: How long can the puck remain on the goal netting before play is stopped?

answers.text: The puck can remain on the goal netting for a maximum of three (3) seconds before play is stopped.

qas.question: Where should the face-off take place if the goalkeeper freezes the puck on the back of the net?

answers.text: If the goalkeeper freezes the puck on the back of the net, the face-off should take place at one of the Face-off Spots in the Defending Zone.

qas.question: What should happen if the puck goes under the goal from behind or the side, as witnessed by an On-ice Official?

answers.text: If the puck goes under the goal from behind or the side, witnessed by an On-ice Official, play should be stopped immediately, and the ensuing face-off should take place at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone nearest to where the play was stopped.

qas.question: Can either team play the puck off the goal netting if it becomes lodged there?

answers.text: Yes, either team can play the puck off the goal netting, but if it remains there for more than three seconds, play will be stopped.

paragraphs.context: Should a scramble take place, or a Player accidentally fall on the puck and the puck be out of sight of the Referee, they shall immediately blow their whistle and stop the play. The puck shall then be “faced-off” at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the play was stopped unless otherwise provided for in the rules.

qas.question: What action should the Referee take if a Player accidentally falls on the puck and it becomes out of sight during a scramble?

answers.text: The Referee should blow the whistle and stop play if a Player accidentally falls on the puck and it becomes out of sight during a scramble.

qas.question: When the puck is out of sight of the Referee due to a scramble, what is the immediate response required by the official?

answers.text: The immediate response required by the official when the puck is out of sight due to a scramble is to blow the whistle and stop the play.

qas.question: In the scenario where the puck is not visible to the Referee because of a scramble, what is the appropriate course of action to stop play?

answers.text: If the puck is not visible to the Referee due to a scramble, they should immediately blow the whistle to stop play.

qas.question: Where should the puck be faced-off if it becomes out of sight during a scramble and play is stopped by the Referee?

answers.text: The puck should be faced-off at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the play was stopped if it becomes out of sight during a scramble and play is stopped by the Referee.

qas.question: What is the procedure for restarting play when the puck is out of sight of the Referee due to a scramble situation?

answers.text: When the puck is out of sight of the Referee due to a scramble situation, play is stopped immediately, and the puck is faced-off at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where the play was stopped.

paragraphs.context: Play shall not be stopped if the puck touches an On-ice Official anywhere on the Rink, regardless of whether a Team is “short-handed” or not. A puck that deflects back into the Defending Zone off an On-ice Official who is in the Neutral Zone, will be deemed to be “off-side”. (Rule 83 – Off-side) The puck striking or deflecting off an On-ice Official does not automatically nullify a “potential icing”. When a puck deflects off an On-ice Official and goes out of play, the ensuing “face-off” will take place at the Face-off Spot in the zone nearest to where the puck deflected off the Official. If a goal is scored as a result of being deflected directly into the net off an On-ice Official, the goal shall not be allowed.

qas.question: What happens if the puck touches an On-ice Official anywhere on the Rink during play?

answers.text: If the puck touches an On-ice Official anywhere on the rink during play, play continues, but if the puck deflects into the Defending Zone off the Official in the Neutral Zone, it is deemed off-side. If the puck deflects out of play off an Official, the face-off occurs at the nearest zone. Goals directly deflected into the net off an Official are not allowed.

qas.question: How is a puck that deflects back into the Defending Zone off an On-ice Official who is in the Neutral Zone treated in terms of off-side?

answers.text: A puck that deflects back into the Defending Zone off an On-ice Official in the Neutral Zone is treated as off-side.

qas.question: Does the puck striking or deflecting off an On-ice Official nullify a potential icing?

answers.text: No, the puck striking or deflecting off an On-ice Official does not nullify a potential icing in hockey.

qas.question: Where does the ensuing face-off take place when a puck deflects off an On-ice Official and goes out of play?

answers.text: The ensuing face-off takes place at the Face-off Spot in the zone nearest to where the puck deflected off the On-ice Official.

qas.question: If a goal is scored as a result of being deflected directly into the net off an On-ice Official, is the goal allowed according to the rule context?

answers.text: No, a goal scored as a result of being deflected directly into the net off an On-ice Official is not allowed according to the rule context.

paragraphs.context: Should any Player cause the puck to go out of play or become “unplayable” in any zone, the “face-off” shall take place at the Face-off Spot in the zone from which the puck was shot. If deflected out of play, at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where it deflected out of play. If this stoppage is caused by an attacking player in the attacking zone, the face-off will take place at the closest face-off spot in the attacking zone (if the player did not make an infraction as per (Rule 63 – delaying the game)) If the zone happens to be the Neutral Zone, the Face-off Spot selected shall be the one that gives the offending Team the least amount of “territorial advantage”. For a puck that is “unplayable” due to being lodged in the netting or as a result of it being “frozen” between opposing Players, the resulting “face-off” shall be at either of the adjacent Face-off Spots or at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from which the puck was shot, unless otherwise covered in these rules. If the attacking Team shoots the puck into the zone and a “Delayed Off-side” is indicated, or if the attacking Team commits a game flow infraction such as contacting the puck with a “high-stick” or “batting the puck with a glove” (causing a stoppage of play), the ensuing “face-off” shall be in the Neutral Zone outside the offending Team’s Attacking Zone.

qas.question: Where does the face-off take place if a player causes the puck to go out of play in the attacking zone without committing an infraction?

answers.text: If a player causes the puck to go out of play in the attacking zone without committing an infraction, the face-off will take place at the closest face-off spot in the attacking zone.

qas.question: What is the face-off location if the puck is deflected out of play in a specific zone?

answers.text: If the puck is deflected out of play in a specific zone, the face-off location will be at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone where it deflected out of play.

qas.question: In what zone does the face-off occur if a player causes the puck to become "unplayable" due to being lodged in the netting?

answers.text: The face-off would occur at either of the adjacent Face-off Spots or at the nearest Face-off Spot in the zone from which the puck was shot if it becomes "unplayable" due to being lodged in the netting.

qas.question: Where is the face-off spot selected if the puck is shot into the zone by the attacking team and a "Delayed Off-side" is indicated?

answers.text: If the attacking team shoots the puck into the zone and a "Delayed Off-side" is indicated, the face-off spot selected will be in the Neutral Zone outside the offending team's Attacking Zone.

qas.question: If the attacking team commits a game flow infraction like contacting the puck with a "high-stick," where does the ensuing face-off take place?

answers.text: The ensuing face-off takes place in the Neutral Zone outside the offending team's Attacking Zone if the attacking team commits a game flow infraction like contacting the puck with a "high-stick."

paragraphs.context: A Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” shall be imposed on a Goalkeeper who “deliberately” drops the puck on the goal netting to cause a stoppage of play. (Rule 67.3 – Handling the Puck)

qas.question: What penalty will be imposed on a goalkeeper who deliberately drops the puck on the goal netting to cause a stoppage of play?

answers.text: A goalkeeper who deliberately drops the puck on the goal netting to cause a stoppage of play will receive a Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game."

qas.question: Under what circumstances will a minor penalty for "Delay of Game" be given to a goalkeeper?

answers.text: A goalkeeper will receive a minor penalty for "Delay of Game" if they intentionally drop the puck on the goal netting to stop play.

qas.question: Which specific action by a goalkeeper will result in a Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" according to Rule 67.3?

answers.text: A goalkeeper will receive a Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" if they intentionally drop the puck on the goal netting to stop play, as per Rule 67.3.

qas.question: What is the consequence for a goalkeeper who intentionally causes a stoppage of play by dropping the puck on the goal netting?

answers.text: The consequence for a goalkeeper who intentionally causes a stoppage of play by dropping the puck on the goal netting is a Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" as per Rule 67.3 - Handling the Puck in hockey.

qas.question: In what situation would a goalkeeper receive a Minor Penalty for handling the puck in a way that leads to a stoppage of play?

answers.text: A goalkeeper would receive a Minor Penalty for handling the puck in a way that leads to a stoppage of play if they deliberately drop the puck on the goal netting to cause the stoppage.

paragraphs.context: Any loss of time on the game or penalty clocks due to the puck going out of play must be replaced. The Video Goal Consultant may be consulted to ensure the time is accurately replaced. (Rule 37.6 – Video Review to verify time on clock)

qas.question: Who may be consulted to ensure that any lost time on the game or penalty clocks due to the puck going out of play is accurately replaced?

answers.text: The Video Goal Consultant may be consulted to ensure accurate replacement of lost time on the game or penalty clocks due to the puck going out of play.

qas.question: What specific action must be taken to replace any lost time on the game or penalty clocks when the puck goes out of play?

answers.text: To replace any lost time on the game or penalty clocks when the puck goes out of play, the time must be accurately replaced, and the Video Goal Consultant may be consulted for verification.

qas.question: Which rule allows for video review to verify the time on the clock in case of the puck going out of play?

answers.text: Rule 37.6 allows for video review to verify the time on the clock if the puck goes out of play.

qas.question: What is the purpose of consulting the Video Goal Consultant regarding the time replacement when the puck goes out of play?

answers.text: The purpose of consulting the Video Goal Consultant regarding time replacement when the puck goes out of play is to ensure accurate replacement of lost time on the game or penalty clocks as per Rule 37.6.

qas.question: In what situation is it necessary to ensure that any lost time on the game or penalty clocks due to the puck going out of play is accurately replaced?

answers.text: Lost time on the game or penalty clocks due to the puck going out of play must be accurately replaced, and the Video Goal Consultant may be consulted to verify the time.

data.title: GAME FLOW - START OF GAME AND PERIODS

paragraphs.context: In game facilities during IIHF Championship events where the participating Teams enter and depart the ice surface using the same common door and hallway system, the procedure is proposed to ensure that the Teams enter and depart the ice surface in an orderly fashion and without incident. The game clock will be the only timing device used in the timing of all activities including the “pre-game warm-up”, the period intermissions and the actual game itself. The game shall be commenced at the time scheduled by a “face-off” in the Center of the Rink and shall be renewed promptly at the conclusion of each intermission in the same manner.

qas.question: How are participating Teams expected to enter and depart the ice surface during IIHF Championship events where they use the same common door and hallway system?

answers.text: Teams participating in IIHF Championship events are expected to enter and depart the ice surface using the same common door and hallway system in an orderly fashion to prevent incidents.

qas.question: What timing device is used for all activities, including the "pre-game warm-up," period intermissions, and the actual game itself?

answers.text: The game clock is the timing device used for all activities, including the "pre-game warm-up," period intermissions, and the actual game itself during IIHF Championship events.

qas.question: At what specific location does the game commence according to the rule?

answers.text: The game commences with a face-off at the Center of the Rink.

qas.question: How is the game renewed at the conclusion of each intermission?

answers.text: The game is renewed promptly at the conclusion of each intermission by starting with a face-off at the center of the rink.

qas.question: What is the proposed procedure to ensure that Teams enter and depart the ice surface in an orderly fashion and without incident during IIHF Championship events?

answers.text: Teams entering and departing the ice surface during IIHF Championship events will do so in an orderly fashion and without incident by following a proposed procedure that utilizes the game clock as the sole timing device for activities such as pre-game warm-up, intermissions, and the game itself. The game will start with a face-off at the scheduled time and resume promptly after each intermission.

paragraphs.context: A Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” shall be imposed on either or both Teams if: (I) They are not on the ice or can be seen proceeding to the ice to start the second, third or any Overtime period when the intermission time on the clock has expired. (II) At the start of the second, third and any Overtime period, all Players with the exception of the starting Players must proceed directly to their respective Players’ Benches. Skating, warm-ups or on-ice activities by non-starters is not permitted. (III) When the visiting Team must proceed by the way of the ice to their Dressing Room at the end of a period, they must wait for a signal from one of the Officials before proceeding. Failure to wait for the Official’s signal shall result in a penalty.

qas.question: What action will result in a Bench Minor Penalty for "Delay of Game" at the start of the second period if the Teams are not on the ice when the intermission time has expired?

paragraphs.context: At the conclusion of the first and second periods, upon hearing the buzzer, the away team will return to its players’ bench and remain there until the entire home team has departed the ice surface and entered the common hallway. paragraphs.context: At the beginning of the second and third periods, and Overtime periods in playoffs (0:00 on the clock), Teams must be on the ice or be observed to be proceeding to the ice. Failure to comply with this regulation will result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game”. Before the start of the second and third periods (and Overtime) the Teams will proceed directly to their respective Players’ Benches. The visiting Team will immediately place its Skaters at the Face-off Circle, then the Home Team will follow, with the Referee allowing the Home Team to make a line change if so desired prior to the “face-off”. Skating, warm-ups, or on-ice activities by non-starters will result in a Bench Minor Penalty for “Delay of Game” to the offending Team. No warm-up involving pucks on the ice shall be permitted for a Goalkeeper at the start of any period. If, after one warning, this continues, the Referee shall assess a “Delay of Game” penalty to the offending Team. To notify the teams that it is time to return to the ice surface at the beginning of each period, the official game Timekeeper will sound a buzzer in the Dressing Room area.

paragraphs.context: Each Team shall be permitted to take one thirty-second (30 s) “time-out” during the course of any game. All Players including Goalkeepers on the ice at the time of the “time-out” will be allowed to go to their respective benches. This “time-out” must be taken during a normal stoppage of play. Only one “time-out” ("television commercial break / power break" or Team “time-out”), shall be permitted at any one stoppage of play. For the purpose of this rule, a “television commercial break” is deemed an “official time-out” and not charged to either Team. Any Player designated by the Coach or the Coach will indicate to the Referee that their Team is exercising its option. The “time-out” must be requested by the team before the Referee has completed the players change procedure, before the Referee lowers his hand and points to the respecting face-off location. The Referee will report the “time-out” to the Game Timekeeper who shall be responsible for signaling the termination of the “time-out”. No “time-out” shall be granted following a “face-off” violation. No “time-out” shall be granted to the defensive Team following an icing, following the Goalkeeper causing a stoppage of play from a shoot-in from beyond the center red line, or when a defending Player accidentally dislodges the net causing a stoppage of play. No “time-out” shall be granted when a “Penalty Shot” has been awarded to either Team by the Referee, once instructions have been given to the Player taking the shot and the Goalkeeper defending the shot. No “time-out” will be granted during the shootout. No warm-up involving pucks on the ice shall be permitted for a Goalkeeper or replacement Goalkeeper during a “time-out”. If, after one warning, this continues, the Referee shall assess a “Delay of Game” penalty to the offending Team.

qas.question: How long is a team's "time-out" allowed to last during a hockey game?

answers.text: A team's "time-out" during a hockey game is allowed to last for thirty seconds (30 s).

qas.question: When can a team request a "time-out" during a game according to the rules?

answers.text: A team can request a "time-out" during a game once, for 30 seconds, during a normal stoppage of play. The request must be made before the referee completes the player change procedure and points to the face-off location.

qas.question: Can a team request a "time-out" following a face-off violation?

answers.text: No, a team cannot request a "time-out" following a face-off violation in hockey.

qas.question: Are there any specific situations where a team is not allowed to request a "time-out" during a game?

answers.text: Teams are not allowed to request a "time-out" following a "face-off" violation, after an icing, when the Goalkeeper causes a stoppage of play from a shoot-in beyond the center red line, when a defending Player accidentally dislodges the net, when a "Penalty Shot" has been awarded, during a shootout, or for warm-up involving pucks on the ice.

qas.question: What penalty may be assessed if a team continues to have warm-up involving pucks on the ice during a "time-out" after receiving a warning from the Referee?

answers.text: If a team continues to have warm-up involving pucks on the ice during a "time-out" after receiving a warning from the Referee, a "Delay of Game" penalty may be assessed to the offending Team.

paragraphs.context: During each regular period of the games in an IIHF Championship there shall be a maximum of three (3) commercial breaks, each with a maximum duration of seventy (70) seconds but can be subject to change for specific events. Commercial breaks shall be taken at the first stoppage of play after the following times on the game clock as it counts down: (I) Break number 1: 14.00 (min.) (II) Break number 2: 10.00 (min.) (III) Break number 3: 06.00 (min.) Despite the above indicated time slots, commercial breaks shall not be taken if: a) A goal is scored; b) A penalty shot is called; c) One of the Teams is playing short-handed; d) A fight breaks out on ice; e) An icing infraction is called; f) The net is dislodged accidentally by a defending player (incl. goalkeeper); and g) The puck is shot into the end zone from beyond the center red line and the goalkeeper freezes the puck resulting in a stoppage of play. Exceptions from point e-g above is when a penalty or penalties are assessed in the stoppage that affects the on-ice strength of either team. In the event that a commercial break is not taken during the time slot prescribed above, because of the exceptions above, the missed commercial opportunity shall be made up at the first stoppage of play in the next commercial break time slot. If there is another incident where the second commercial break is missed, this procedure shall continue to repeat itself until all commercial breaks are taken. However, there must always be at least 60 seconds between two commercial breaks. Any extra commercial break taken during a time slot shall follow the procedure described above and they shall be eliminated from the last remaining time slot of that period. They shall not be used to create extra commercial inventory for broadcasters. However, in such instances, the Commercial Coordinator will be instructed to turn on the light and signal the truck that an optional commercial opportunity is being taken. No commercial breaks shall be taken in the final thirty (30) seconds of the first and second periods, as well as during the final two (2) minutes of the third period. No commercial breaks shall be granted during overtime. The Teams shall comply with the following provisions during commercial breaks: a) Goalkeepers will be allowed to go to their respective players’ bench. b) Teams are allowed to change lines once the referee blows the whistle signaling the teams to return to the face-off with 20 seconds remaining in the commercial stoppage. c) These line changes will follow the same protocol as a normal line change during a stoppage of play.

qas.question: When can commercial breaks be taken during a regular period of an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: Commercial breaks can be taken during a regular period of an IIHF Championship game at the first stoppage of play after the game clock reaches 14:00, 10:00, and 06:00 minutes, with a maximum of three breaks lasting 70 seconds each. Exceptions include goals, penalty shots, penalties affecting on-ice strength, short-handed play, fights, icing infractions, accidental net dislodgement, and specific puck handling scenarios. No breaks in the final 30 seconds of the first and second periods, final 2 minutes of the third period, or during overtime.

qas.question: What are the specific events that prevent a commercial break from being taken during a game?

answers.text: Specific events that prevent a commercial break during an IIHF Championship game include: a goal being scored, a penalty shot being called, a team playing short-handed, a fight breaking out on the ice, an icing infraction being called, the net being accidentally dislodged by a defending player, and the puck being shot into the end zone from beyond the center red line resulting in the goalkeeper freezing the puck.

qas.question: How many commercial breaks are allowed during each regular period of an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: Three commercial breaks are allowed during each regular period of an IIHF Championship game.

qas.question: What is the maximum duration of each commercial break during an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: The maximum duration of each commercial break during an IIHF Championship game is 70 seconds.

qas.question: What are the provisions that Teams must comply with during commercial breaks in an IIHF Championship game?

answers.text: Teams must comply with the following provisions during commercial breaks in an IIHF Championship game: Goalkeepers can go to their bench, and teams can change lines once the referee signals 20 seconds remaining in the break, following normal line change protocol.

paragraphs.context: According to the IIHF Statutes and Bylaws, the Player eligibility and age categories are defined as follows: Women’s Hockey “Senior”-Age Category Players participating in any IIHF Ice Hockey Women’s World Championship must be eligible to compete as a female athlete and be at least eighteen (18) years old by December 31 of the year in which the Championship Season ends. Players who do not meet the minimum age requirements, but who will have their 16th or 17th birthday in the year in which the Championship Season ends, may participate if they have a signed an “Under-age” waiver as stipulated in IIHF Bylaw 10.6.2. Women’s Hockey “Under 18” and “Under-aged” Category Players participating in any IIHF Ice Hockey U18 Women’s World Championship must be eligible to compete as a female athlete and be no younger than fifteen (15) years of age, and no older than eighteen (18) years of age, by December 31 of the year in which the Championship Season ends. No “Under-age” waiver is permitted. ( » For more information refer to IIHF Statutes & Bylaws.)

qas.question: What is the minimum age requirement for players participating in the IIHF Ice Hockey Women’s World Championship?

qas.question: Can players who will turn 16 or 17 during the Championship Season participate without meeting the minimum age requirement?

answers.text: Players who will turn 16 or 17 during the Championship Season can participate without meeting the minimum age requirement if they have signed an "Under-age" waiver as stipulated in IIHF Bylaw 10.6.2.

qas.question: What is the age range for players eligible to participate in the IIHF Ice Hockey U18 Women’s World Championship?

answers.text: Players eligible to participate in the IIHF Ice Hockey U18 Women’s World Championship must be between the ages of fifteen (15) and eighteen (18) years old by December 31 of the year in which the Championship Season ends.
